author: philbarnes
content:
Whenever I recommend this discord to someone, it's followed up with the comment that you're interacting with people who are actually making records. Not YouTube producers. Not "download my e-book" guys. This space is a rare resource and a gift in the world we work in, and it's not always going to confirm your opinion. I don't post every day because I don't always have something to say or to add value, but I do gain a beautiful new perspective on a subject from reading through here at least a few times a week that I wouldn't have had the thought of without this space.

If you're gonna go after this job for real, you're gonna have the craziest shit thrown at you from clients, collaborators, peers and heroes that you've ever heard. 

Your feelings will not be protected when you operate in this industry at a professional level. 

So, learning to take it on the chin and ask "what is there to learn here?" in a moment you're challenged is what will make you grow and be resilient. 

I just re-printed a stem an hour ago for a background vocal I fucked up "fixing" the timing of in the chorus. The client was incredibly direct and insensitive of my feelings about it, and if I hit them back to argue what was "technically correct" based on the grid and subdivisions I was looking at, and why I was right, they wouldn't care. They wanted it different, so I saw it through their lens of how they wrote the part and corrected it to deliver for the artist. And you know what? That result was better than my feeling of what was "technically correct." They were right. A beautiful reminder to serve the song rather than to check the box. 

The older I get the more I equally trust my taste and remain open to learning something based on new information. Adopting that mindset will only serve you in the process of experimentation of self and collaboration with others.

author: cian riordan
content: Prefacing this unsolicited tip with 'always use your ears, not your eyes, yadda yadda' -- but a few months ago I set my Pro-Q3 default to have the Lead Vocal bus in my template as the external spectrum on the display and BOY does help with mixing dense arrangements. Wish I would have done this years ago.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
imho, a lot of the vocals I'm hearing from younger record makers are sounding heavily  processed in the same way. "Lack of dynamics" doesn't really explain it because people think of dynamics as dynamic range compression. It's more that everyone is chopping, clip gaining, and RXing to an evenness that softens and linearizes performances. 

These tools work beautifully when shitty mic technique makes things boomy, or there's a few weird ss's on the pre-hyped TLM mic through the focusrite pre.

But it sounds like most people who learn the tools are overusing them like crazy. 

I'm trying these days to get off the details and try as much macro-mixing as possible. When I let performances breathe in their imperfections, I find that I'm drawn in more as a listener.

"Music is the space between the notes". 
-Claude Debussy

"Music is the space between RX moves." 
-Ruairí (probably)

author: chrissorem
content: After a good nights rest, I realized if I’m going to talk a bit of shit I better add something positive.  So I had something interesting happen on a new record I’m mixing. The artist and I met and listened to some of the tunes and we chatted about sonic direction. Upon my first listen I had some specific ideas of where to go with the mixes, in particular with the vocal sounds.  On the first day of mixing I still felt the same way about notes I had made. After about a couple hours of mixing I found myself taking a left turn from the original direction I had in mind and I stopped and chatted with the artist and I felt the music was taking me elsewhere and was surprised where we ended up.  Luckily the artist was chill and also felt the same way and we were psyched where we ended up.  This was a reminder to myself that the music usually tells you what works and what doesn’t and just because you have an idea doesn’t mean that’s what the track wants. This is what I do love about in person mixing, we all have ideas and you don’t know if they are any good until you try them.

author: philbarnes
content: If you get too into the weeds with a shit-ton of plugins, don't be afraid to start it over with just a single EQ and compressor. I surprise myself with how often a break and reset gets me to a better vocal mix in a fraction of the moves.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Working on a mix today, we’ve been grinding on it a lot, a song recorded in lets say a “less than ideal way”. First half of the first verse just wasn’t right on the vocal. Threw everything I had it. Compressor after compressor, soothes, spectres, automations, eq before and after, still not quite right. Took off all the compressors. 1 eq. Readjusted the levels. Perfect. 

Sometimes the best thing you can do is get perspective and be willing to undo everything you’ve done.

author: cian riordan

author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean, beating my dead horse from my soap box from the light at the end of the tunnel from… I think again again again the most important thing is to have the TASTE to know the difference. Any clown (not referring to you) can find out from Colt Copernicus on YouTube how to widen their mix… the thing to me that sets the pros apart is knowing if it should be done. 

Ruairi talks a lot about mastering engineers giving the artist and label confidence that the record is DONE, cause it’s gone through his hands. It’s not just that Ruairi has great ears, he knows what those ears are supposed to be listening for. (I remember this idea crystallized a bit for me when Noah mentioned when we did a song together I was looking to achieve things in the vocal that he hadn’t even considered yet, rather than us just agreeing if it needs 5k). I send songs to Cian not because I want to make sure it still holds up on his garbage speakers, but because I want his input on whether we were right to have the vocals out front or the drums destroyed or whatever. And I feel like he has the confidence to (gently) suggest that maybe we missed the forest for the trees in 3 months of production and THIS keyboard line should be the thing that carries the chorus.

It’s all part of the wider conversation of what are we trying to bring to the table? Do we want to just do whatever we can to have our name on as many things as possible, or do we want to be the kind of artist/producer/mixer whose involvement actually matters, even if that j evolvement is “yeah, you got it mostly right, just bumped up 60hz a bit not because I’m lazy but because I genuinely think the rough works”

author: BatMeckley
content:
Sunday reminder: don’t apply global eq on a track to fix one thing on the track.

I’ve been kicking around this mix and there was a resonance in some of the vocal bits, so I had an eq or 2 on the track to even them out. Maybe some multiband. And after an hour of frustration I bypassed everything and it sounded better (also your reminder to bypass). I went in and just printed some specific eq in the two or three words that were bothering me, and a little ess editing, and it was all much better. (Also, don’t be afraid to start from zero again,, especially if you find yourself editing an edit).

author: Slow Hand
content:
A few strategies that I have yet to hear mentioned:

1) Listen very *very* low and see if the vocals get lost.

2) Listen to your mix from down the hall or in the next room. Or listen while doing some other activity that occupies your mind. Note whether anything stands out.

3) Put your mix on a tiny-ass speaker with no bass and see how it feels.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Soothe2 is great:

I spent a couple hours on a vocal the other night. It had some fucked up sibilance, weird resonances, catawampus high end. Used pro-q 3 for taming some resonances. Got some good additional results with two bands of weiss. Did a little saturating with de emphasis on specter. Got it significantly improved.

Opened it up tonight and hated it. Saved a new version and started over. Put on Soothe. All the resonances were solved on the default setting. I added some high after with spectre. Magic in 3 minutes. 🤷

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man this thread was a roller coaster. I think a lot of people have touched on it here, but at least for me there was no “this blog” or “this YouTube”, which in some ways is a bummer, but it’s also liberating. Truthfully EVERY SINGLE PROJECT I do, to this day, I learn something new on. And my workflow is just the accumulation of all those different little moments. For instance, this last matt Maeson live record thing, there was a cymbal bleed problem that led me to figuring out how to use soothe on the vocal mic sidechained to the overheads to duck specific frequencies. I’ll use that technique more often from here on out, and I shared it with the group here to maybe help someone else take a shortcut the next time.

EVERY blog has given me an insight or two, even if it’s a Streaky video where I go “well shit I DONT wanna do that”. There’s a million different water stations along the route of this marathon, rather than one big firehouse around mile 10. 

Second, this thread feels like a good place to remind everyone that mixing is a people business; you’re literally hired to make sure someone is pleased at the end of the process. Learning how to debate/take or givecriticism/get or give notes without coming off as a dick is quite possible the single most valuable lesson. No matter how good your 26hz is if people don’t want to work with you you’re not gonna have much of a career.

author: cian riordan
content:
Other:
* Lower the tambourine volume during the guitar solo, shouldn’t stick out as much: Tambourine, nobody likes a show-off. Time to tone it down.
* Increase xx's main piano part volume slightly (can get buried): Louie's piano might be going for a hide-and-seek championship. Let's make it easier for listeners to find.
* Soften the tone of walking-down harmonies from 2:41-2:46 as they sound out of tune: The harmonies are rebelling – they want to be unique, even if it means being a little out of tune.
* Increase the main Vox volume/make it more "over the top" throughout the song: The main vocals are ready for their Oscar moment. Get ready for some award-winning singing!
* Synth starting at 1:11 should be quieter in the background & panned towards one side: Because who needs a balanced mix when you can have a synth playing hide-and-seek in the background?

author: bobby k
content: shifting gears for a sec - something i've been a big fan of this year is duplicating a lead vocal and stripping back any compression / dynamic control to a secondary track with no output, then putting any reverb sends on that track instead of the main ldv. this saves pretty much any instinctual reverb automation "throws" and the such because the vocals natural dynamic is lighting up the reverb the same way it would in real life. it now strikes me how odd and unnatural it would sound to have a vocal hitting the reverb about as hard during soft moments as during dynamic moments. unfortunately there are many cases where this is simply not possible as i'm already starting with a heavily compressed vocal. maybe i'm late to this, but anybody else do this or something similar with success?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Buddy. I feel your pain. @cian riordan didn’t say it with words, but his attitude is kinda everything. It starts with you remembering that this shit is fun. Your client may be an idiot, but if you let them steal your joy that’s on you. 

I’m 109% giving myself this advice rn btw.

I produced a song for a Disney artist this week and was STOKED on the direction. Took it from a sensitive guitar vocal to a smacking neo-disco vibe track, and she loved it, but wanted to change the chords and arrangement of the verses to go from lovely to nasty. Deep breath,  channeled all that shit Cian and Matt talk about all the time and treated it like a puzzle to solve. Interpreted the notes not as a repudiation of my ideas but an opportunity to try some shit. Did a save as and went hard, legit made her cry over a Listento stream cause she was so excited. All because I chose curiosity over judgement. 

Tl;dr: Ted Lasso that shit. 

One other thought- when someone comes at you with that kinda energy, it’s ALWAYS a story they’re telling about themselves. THEY feel insulted, they feel insecure, and your bad ass mix just reminded them how imposter they feel. So if you came back with love and patience and excitement to find the thing they’re missing, not only will their attitude change, you’re gonna be grateful cause 90% of the time when a client tells you there’s something wrong, they’re right. (And when they tell you how to fix it, 90% of the time they’re wrong.) @oaklandmatt said that and it fucked me up.

author: popaganda.
content: I feel like the job of a mixer for many people doing the work is to meet an artist where they are and help them get the song to mastering. For many that means cleaning up the session and doing some arranging. Most artists can’t budget for editors, arrangers, vocal producers, etc. nor do they even know these are different jobs. But they’ve done the best they can and they need help and are spending money, so if you can improve the song with some editing why not? Work fast, raise your rates when you can. Guys like Cian and Jon don’t need to edit, but for so many of us that’s the bulk of the job. @peterlabberton walked back his statement, but I think he’s 100% right that mixing is producing, mastering is mixing, tuning, whatever it was. We’re hired to finish something that someone else can’t….why not go all the way?

author: chrissorem
content:
I called someone Hammond organ tech a while back,  to add an FX loop to my Hammond. His response was” that sounds fucking stupid why would you want to do that?” My response was “ it’s sounds like you don’t know how to do that” I hung the phone up and had someone else do it.  Don’t be the first guy.   As a mixer I’m not always going to agree with everyone’s taste, but it’s important to know how to do the tasks im being asked to do, I feel it’s also important to for me to explain to the artist, when I’m “following orders” if you will. And if  I’m  feeing l it’s not making the mix feel better to explain what I’m hearing and why I feel it’s taking a step backwards. This is a tricky  balancing act, as you don’t want necessarily have a lengthy conversation about every mix note. But I’ve found that  when I’m not feeling a particular note,  the artist isn’t necessarily hearing how  this particular move is affecting the whole pie. So usually will say something like “ that’s great that the  snare is brighter but it also making the guitars and vocals feel
Brighter too, maybe we should find some relief somewhere.”  And they usually say,” oh shit I didn’t even notice that, let’s do that or let’s not brighten the snare”.   The artist hired you for your experience so I feel it’s my role to bring these things up and let them be the decision makers. And they will feel your support through this process. This will most likely lead to returning artists and recommendations. Checking out and following orders and responding with.  
“Is this what you want?  Will likely lead to your last interaction with them.

author: cian riordan
content: This song showed up on Eric Valentine's desk almost a decade ago when I was engineering for him. We were in this sweet spot after I graduated out of assisting him and before we got sick of being a room together... so I got to be a lot more hands on. The files came in *roooughhh*. Eric's response was simply "it has to sound great, they're paying us a ton of money"... so everyone in the studio divided and conquered... I replayed the bass and some drum stuff, Eric replayed a lot of the guitars, we both added to the background vocals. The parts were all bone headed but it made such a huge difference sonically to be working with real sounds as opposed to the demo recordings that got greenlit by the label. I think Eric ended up asking for an extra production credit and he got it -- they were just so stoked with the results, they didn't care. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X2BYmmTI04I

author: Adam Thein
content: Pretty sure I stole this trick somewhere from someone but repeating here cause it's been saving me time getting reverbs slotted but basically put spectre in 100% wet and move a band around after a reverb to find a good little slot for the vocal EQ while also controlling the dynamics a bit with the saturation and then you can flip through the styles to find a good texture that works in that range.  Been getting my verbs slotted quickly since figuring this one out.

author: wald
content: This now reminded me of how he achieved this, which is such a powerful practice: listening to the ‘star’ element while eq’ing the competing element. He’d take the vocal and take turns solo’ing it with the other elements (like vocal & loop, vocal & drums etc) and notch competing freqs out of those elements. Again, not touching the vocal. The end result was quite astonishing

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot lately (after seeing the very talented Matt Huber’s mix template) about how I fundamentally hate what the modern mix deliverables requirements have done to how songs sound and more importantly feel these days. 

How you can clearly hear the music and the vocals were mixed separately, tracked separately, considered separately; Where a record sounds like a drum bus and an instro bus and a bv bus and a vocal bus, because someone somewhere down the line might need to make edits. Great for commerce, kinda a bummer for creativity and art. 

Sometimes a heavier hand with processing on the final mixbus can help those things gel a bit, to blur those lines. When I got to work with Zedd he said he basically mixes and masters all his own stuff because if you were to take off his mixbus schmutz the whole thing falls apart, and no one else can put it back together to his satisfaction. But he’s basically involved in every inch of his mix from writing to programming to mixing. 

What exactly are we doing anymore, what are we trying to achieve with the mix. The how is easy. What’s the why?

Old man yells at cloud.

author: bobby k
content: i learned something new about Soothe yesterday that I found valuable - the "soft" vs "hard" mode doesn't affect ratio so much as it affects how the threshold behaves. Soft has what I understand to be a "smart" floating threshold that kind of rides the signal, versus hard is closer to a fixed threshold (and I believe depth then affects the ratio and threshold in it's own way). So, if you were trying to zone in on a frequency that only occasionally rears it's head, hard mode with a lower depth will be generally more accurate and not affect the other parts of the audio nearly as much. I don't like using Soothe on sibilance, but I actually found it quite effective after learning this by setting it to hard mode with a very broad "sharpness".

author: sethearnest
content:
The main stereo verb swimming the whole time has a lot of pre-delay on it and it doesn’t have any of the high freq info in it. A dark, pre-delayed verb will tuck behind a vocal well and allow the verb to be noticed but not push back the vocal b/c the vocal itself is bright and “dry” for 50ms or 80ms or however long the pre-delay is, both of which keep things “close” to our ears. There also doesn’t seem to be any center of that verb—it’s all wide, so that helps keep the vocal clear. There’s a mono dark delay throw happening here and there, too, which gives some good front to back depth. 

Also sounds like some compression or ducking (or however they did it) on the verb that opens up between the lyric spaces, so yet another thing that helps keep the vocal dry-but-also-wet feeling.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: Any of you all ever used the Gaffel Synced Band Splitter? I was treated to a bit of a real life MWTM with Chris Coady last night (super kind guy) and he was showing me this plugin to mix a big pop vocal sound. He duplicated the lead vocal twice to have three tracks and had this plugin as the first insert on each track, split into three bands for each channel, low vocal, mid vocal, high end vocal. The plugin auto syncs the band settings in all instances whenever you adjust a band. He was saying Serban uses this plugin and does that exact thing on some songs. After treating each track with some eq/comp/saturation the vocal sounded really big but balanced. And it’s like $60 so I think I’m going to have to grab it. Probably could do this with other plugins but I appreciated the auto-syncing function and also didn’t notice any weird phase issues which you could maybe run into trying to create the bands by hand?

author: BatMeckley
content:
Look, I value my anonymity. But I can tell you that I’ve put my team of assistants on pause (I had them watch the new episode of succession early and had them all learn the lines word for word and they’re recreating it one of the live rooms for my enjoyment. I got an early copy because along with my Grammys I have multiple Emmy’s for mixing AND scoring your favorite tv shows and even some shows you don’t even know you like yet.) just to give you this ONE mix tip. I know technically it’s my second One mix tip of the day but if you knew me you’d know I’m just used to having multiple Number Ones at the same time 😉. 

We tend to hear exciting things as more exciting so if you really want your vocal to pop run it through ~~[my signature]~~ CLA vocals plugin.

author: cian riordan
content: In my humble experience, if this is the case, fiddling with the master bus is a bandaid… the issue is with the individual elements. Pick one, go to the extremes with it… see how it pushes you to change other elements. For me, drums and vocals are the ones I’ll lean into the hardest… this will usually give you a good North Star for the rest of the tracks.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: This is a great idea. Also in the same vein- If you get delivered a dry & wet vocal, but no separate wet fx track- you can load them both and flip the phase, all you’re left with is the verb. Commit and treat accordingly!

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I picked up Jon and @oaklandmatt ‘s tip and started doing throws pretty exclusively directly on tracks. 

When the lead vocal is most of the way there (maybe there’ll be subtle adjustments to the LV processing, but it’s more or less up to EU regulations), I do a *commit up to this insert* (which keeps it mono, rather than a right click commit on the track title) on the whole vocal. 

I mute the entire resulting clip, then just unmute the bits I need for a given throw. I’ll duplicate this track (without inserts), maybe end up with 4 of them with different FX chains. It’s no biggie just for a H-Delay and a vintageverb/metaflanger/ whatever.

Like they mentioned on the podcast, this method encourages more experimentation for me, and also circumvents niggly things like trying to get a word to echo on the downbeat if it was sung on an offbeat - you just move the clip forward or backward in time. And if an Ess is too apparent, you can clip gain it down in the source etc.

Plus once you have your verb throw set, when you in turn commit that throw, whatever it is about seeing the audio just suggests further details like having it cut abruptly on a beat, or reverse it, or fade it in, or EQ it etc.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I’ve been staunchly against clip-gaining for “compression” on vocals until today.

Tracked a vocal yesterday without compressing on the way in for the first time in forever. Clip gaining into ITB compression ended up sounding like good mic technique. Clip gaining *after* compression just sounds like… bad volume rides?

author: Adam Thein
content:
Something that resonated with what @BatMeckley said an hour ago - “don’t be afraid to start from zero again”

Especially while you are learning maybe trying a few approaches is worth the extra time when there is not a deadline you are up against.

I’ve had a few mixes this year where I’m toward the end of the mix and have been living with a vocal chain for a while and just pull everything off it only to realize it just needed a little more top end and a touch of automation here and there when I had 8 plugins on it before.  That’s maybe an exaggeration but the idea is lean into what’s great about digital mixing - save a version, try something new.  If you are versioning there is always a way back to where you were.  Repetition and experimentation will help you find ways to solve problems and speed things up for you down the road.

author: Nomograph Mastering

author: Josh Bowman
content: Been struggling with a live song mix where the vocal on one of the tunes has just been seemingly impossible for me to figure out. Tried a few diff approaches yesterday, clip EQ, pro Q band automation on/off for words, nothing really felt like a step forward.. I woke up and @BatMeckley 's posts about automating EQ popped into my head. Setup two bands and went through the performance in touch mode, rode them like faders. Job done. Discord FTW.

author: Adam Thein
content:
If there's some breath there, if you have RX Advanced there's a module called "Deconstruct" that Ruairi mentioned to me once when I had the opposite problem where there was a ton of air being pushed and not a lot of resonance.  It separates between tonal and noisy parts of the signal and gives you volume slider.  This will only help you if there's some breathiness to bring up that isn't buried at the level of the noise floor.

If you don't want to do a whisper track + vocalign you can also play around with a Vocoder with the carrier being noise or a sample of breath and blend that in parallel.

I think new whisper track plus vocalign will get you there the fastest and most convincing.

author: chrissorem
content: This happens to me every mix, I’d say it’s a big part of figuring out the mix for me. It’s an area of discovery, trial and error. Some songs/singers it’s immediately obvious and there is often the safe choices that will work but I often think to myself, is this it ? Does it feel special, interesting? Does it feel like it lives in the word of the song and production? It’s a part of the work and I think when you start thinking this way you are really approaching mixing in the right direction. thinking about how it feels rather than how it sounds or what your “approach” is with vocals. For me, I’ve seen over the years that I get faster at recognizing when it’s feeling right and when it’s feeling wrong. And if I’m unsure which is often I try not to obsess over and leave it for a bit and keep mixing. If it’s not feeling right it will continue to not feel right, but sometimes it informs other mix moves that lets the vocal than work, and feel more supported.

author: cian riordan
content: I find that super low volume listening helps with this. Take a 5 min break, turn your shit all the way down, and have a listen. If you can make out the vocals amongst the arrangement, you’re in a good place. If not? First angle of attack is volume. If it’s still sounding swamped, then start picking out offending parts of the arrangement with eq cuts — almost anywhere in the midrange.

author: cian riordan
content: They're a useful tool, but certainly not the key to having a wide sounding mix. For that, LCR hard-panning is the real move. As for wideners, I use them all the time to get things out of the middle. In mixing, I'll often use S1 or the neutron widener to spread out synth pads, reverbs, background vocals... etc. It keeps the sound in the mix, but gets it out of the way of the important stuff like Ld Vocal, drums, bass, etc. Will it collapse in mono? Sure, but who honestly gives a fuck.

author: ALXCPH
content:
theres so many ways to interpret this question. so here's my take. Mixing to me at least, is all about bringing out the intent of the record to the best of your abilities. Fx. if you are mixing a Classical record, all you aim for is probably getting something as close to being in the room as possible, and therefore fidelity. If you are mixing some new urban underground cultural music, you want to respect the grittiness as that can sometimes be part of the sound and/or culture, and you never want to remove the inherent DNA of what makes that thing exciting(even tho it might be unconventional). So in the end, it's OUR job to make the decisions on when to be rough and when to be high fidelity. It's all about what you want out of the music. For most mainstream music(aka. radio oriented) i would personally get a bit of both. Get the mix sounding somewhat exciting as to pull in the listener, but also have certain aspects be high fidelity as to make it easy to listen to. FX, in a pop record, Vocal intelligibility is super important if you want people to sing along, where are in a techno track or hyperpop track you can have some grittier vocals, as they aren't as intended to be the in the car sing along song. They would be much more about the energy and feeling. 

IMO theres nothing more boring than a perfect mix, where every sound is perfectly inline and has no personality that makes it memorable. 

The creativity of a mix is just as, if not more important, than the technicals. Thats what those cyborgs called Mastering Engineers are for.

author: cian riordan
content: This approach is solid. But sometimes you have so many BGVs that you can use panning as a way to create a little separation. My rule of thumb is lower voicing tend to occupy center-mid, and the higher voicings out wide to create a wider spread. Like if I was making a Queen record, I'd probably stick to your approach because the arrangement would be airtight -- and LCR would work great. But if I was fucking with some indie pop producer that has a boner for a million tracks in his session, then it's warfare and I'm just trying to place things where they work.

author: aemaury
content: RX Connect in audiosuite is my jam. Send clips to the offline, work the magic by hand and fly it back. soundflow+streamdeck can really cut down on the clicking around for this process. I also find littering the vocal chain with several deessers, each catching like 1-2 db, can sound very natural. It’s a lot to juggle but i do it near the end of the mix once everything is sitting nicely and gain structure is unlikely to change. If that’s not enough, I’ll start manually clip gaining sibilance down 2-5db, or more if the compression is silly.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: I find soothe can be really good for catching low end resonances. I actually much prefer it for that than using it to tame upper mid/high end stuff like deessing. Sounds sort of weird to me the higher up in the frequency range you go. But awesome on evening out an unruly bass or lower resonances in a vocal

author: BatMeckley
content:
So, got my car back from the shop today and they accidentally fucked up the stereo so that the amp that runs the low end and subs (and back speaker) wasn’t working, so I had to listen to music without basically anything under let’s say 300, and it got me thinking about our conversations about mixing.

I think a lot of the new (and even some of the experienced mixers here) would find out some neat stuff about mixes they like if they brought one into their daw, selected a hyper aggressive low pass (brick wall?) and then scooted it down to say 300 hz. What’s left in the song do you hear? Then down to 200. Down to 100. Down to 26. What exactly is in the low end information of the mixes you enjoy? I’d then flip it to a high pass and go the other way. How much of the bass is above 1k? The kick? I think it would be eye opening for some. 
Shawn Everett once showed me this great mix trick where he low pass something, say a vocal, and slides it all the way down until he can’t hear anything important anymore, and then just switches it from a low pass to a hi pass. (And vice versa). Pretty useful trick to make some space in your mixes.

author: kylem
content: I’ve used this trick to rebuild shitty top end in a vocal. Lofi as first plugin, pull down sample rate 1 click, adjust aliasing, then put top back using a pultec (or something similar). Also can do something similar across a whole mix / sub groups using standard clips built in filter. Can help get a more focused top. Also can completely ruin things! Fun to play with

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I find it helps sometimes to write client notes back to them in language that makes sense to you and will make them feel heard. 

Sometimes they’ll send an essay for each note, and you can write back with bullet points “Gtr up a little, make the vocal speak more, less snare.” And they’ll know that you read it, trust that you know what to do, and will likely end up picking up that kind of language in the future.

author: bobby k
content: a theme of 2025 i've been exploring is boosting on EQ more. In the past my thought process has been - this element buried in a dense mix is really poking out at xyz frequency, so i'm going to reduce that frequency to make it sound more "balanced". (take for example something like a screeching ambient guitar solo or vocal riff sitting in the background during ~big chorus 3~). Lately i've been challenging myself to actually push UP the frequencies that really make up the certain track's identity, then focusing on it's volume in the mix instead. so far this has felt like things in an arrangement each have a more tangible attitude, instead of where I was at in the past where everything was silky smooth and balanced, thus becoming a soft-midrange-soup. The instinct is as simple as something like make believes MBSI strip, with the midrange EQ knob that can boost or cut, where I would usually use it to cut a dense part of that element, i'll now *boost* it and just turn the track down. Been sounding so much cooler.

author: cian riordan

author: bobby k
content: Changed a mix in the 4th quarter to play more like an LCR mix (drums, vocals, bass all down the middle, BGVs perc and music hard panned L&R) and everybody loved it because suddenly all the elements were more defined without continuing to tweak EQs and levels. Wild how fluffy the mix will feel when everything is vaguely ~stereo~.

author: ALXCPH
content:
this is answer might not be the most exciting.

Actual Separation does not come from EQ, Compression and Saturation. These are just tool to help manipulate a sound into how you want it to sound. 

Separation comes from Arrangement. If you have a Piano and a Guitar playing full chords in the same octave, you'll never get good sounding separation, no matter how much you try and manipulate the sound.
Sounds are made from a fundamental and certain overtones/harmonics. If they overlap, then they overlap, even if you add a random eq boost on each sound some Freqs apart, because someone on youtube did that. (not that you can't do it, and it wont work)
But Instead of removing good sounding parts of a sound forcing them to fit together(whatever that even means at this point), arrange the parts so they naturally fit together with separation. This way you'll be able to act more, creatively and instinctively on how you want the sounds to sound while mixing, instead of fitting a triangle into a circle. As the good old saying says, it starts at the source, for the best results. 

Fx, in a typical jazz band, often a Bass will play roots on 1 & 3,  a piano will of then play the root and 5th an octave above that, and a guitar could play the 3rd and 7th, and together all the instruments make big full chords while also having their own space. this way there is now plenty of room for a singer or a Sax player to do its thing and not worry to much about cutting through a dense mix.

author: BatMeckley
content: Your way makes far more technical sense but I tend to tune and time first. To me it matters far more to keep the song moving, to make production choices, get doubles, have another vocal day etc. I do the forensic editing at the end once all the possible joy has been sucked out of the record.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Man it goes both ways- sometimes if you’ve got problem frequencies or too much bottom a compressor will react to the wrong things, and depending on what you’re using to compress there may be problem frequencies imparted. I wouldn’t be afraid to eq both before and after compression/saturation. 

There’s no limit on the amount of plugins you can put on a vocal chain, so often I approach it with a lot of things doing a little bit at a time, just adding or subtracting things I’m looking for.

But if more freedoms is stressing you out, try this approach. 
Add a comp in the second slot
See what jumps out at you, and then decide if you need to eq what’s going into the comp, or just what’s coming out of it.
Subtractive eq 
De essing 
More compression/saturation
More subtractive eq/de essing 
Additive eq 
Any final touches (limiting, saturation, de essing, etc)
Fx 

Use as many plugs as you think you need to. 

Then go back and disable everything, adding them back one at a time to make sure everything you’ve done is helpful on a fresh listen. 

If you love everything you’ve done but need a little more on the chain, commit and start as if that’s your recorded vocal and go from there.

author: Brodie Stewart
content:
I’ve found that as my monitoring environment has improved over the years, and the more familiar I become with it, I find myself using references less and less. I just mix music the way my ears want to hear it (which thankfully pairs to the speaker choice well!).

Every now and then, if I’ve lost perspective or there’s a translation issue I might pull in a reference for a reality check. Otherwise a reference is handy for broad stroke “concepts” (E.g distorted vocals, or tight dry drums etc.) and I’ve learned not to take them too literally - otherwise you end up going down the rabbit hole and inevitably chasing your tail to a worse mix 😞

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Actually just had a funny memory of the inception of this guide. I wrote it for myself when I was working under Mark Ralph after I cost myself a bunch of time once by doing prep steps in the wrong order, so from then on I'd pull up my own guidelines every time to make sure I did everything right. One of my early ballsings was not checking the ref against the delivered parts in enough detail, and we had an instance where the wrong vocal take for part of a verse wound up getting mixed (producer fucked up by sending the wrong one, but I fucked up by not catching it), and it wasn't caught til we sent Mix 1 back to the client. No biggie, and Mark was insanely patient with that kind of thing, but I felt it as a massive fuck up as the last pair of hands before things went down to the A rig. 

So I added the line to my notes in block fucking caps **MAKE SURE YOU CHECK THE REFERENCE FUCKING PROPERLY - VOCALS VOCALS VOCALS!!!!**

One day Jack from Clean Bandit was upstairs in the kitchen where the B rig was, saw the note on my laptop screen and thought it was an email from Mark 😂 Jack is so genuinely kind, he asked about it as if I might be trapped in an abusive relationship and he could get me out. I was, of course, but only with myself ❤️

author: peterlabberton
content:
I think Auto-Align 2 just totally saved my ass with an acoustic gtr/vocal recording/mix.

Was doing a little one-off tracking date with a big artist I'm trying to work with more and more, and I feel like I didn't do my best on the recording side. Could have and should have taken up a member here on a generous mic lending offer (you know who you are 🙏 ), but decided I could roll with my own gear. Acoustic gtr and vocal, tracked together—would have done the two figure 8 mics/use the nulls move with the borrowed mics, but I don't have two fig 8 mics right now. A drive across town would have gotten me the right tools for the job and made everything smooth and easy. Lesson learned: get the right shit no matter what!

Artist left in good spirits, job done, fine. But I was super bummed, I had wanted to blow them away. Had to step away for a few days, and then spent most of yesterday trying every trick in my book to get the phase of the vocal and gtr mic to be happy (it sounded fine so long as the artist wasn't singing loud—then it became phase city in a few loud passages as the gtr mic got more and more vocal). Time adjuster, playing with Little Labs IBP, EQ, whatever. Still mostly a huge bummer. But! Auto-Align 2 did some spectral phase shift magic that I don't think I would have been able to suss out on my own—holy shit, what a relief! Maybe I love our new AI overlords after all. (I think this plug-in claims AI magic... whatev, it's tight.)

author: Rob Domos
content:
Others here have the right idea with the light touch. 0.3 db changes usually sound like a slightly more excellent performance and capture. 3 db changes often sound like you ran shit through gullfoss in a bad way. 

But even that is context dependent. Changes made to the actual consonants and vowels need to be *very* light handed, while saliva drips and surrounding rustles can often (but definitely not always) be more or less nuked without consequence. There’s musical context to consider as well. I find that I want to leave in more lip smack on a rhythmic song where the vocal is competing with icepicky cumbia drums than I do on an exposed ballad.

author: Rollmottle

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This is a great question, and honestly I don’t think numbers correlate very well track to track, though @sethearnest’s answer *feels* close to me, and his work sorta shows he knows what he’s about. 

I feel like I’m currently starting to find a groove with allowing the top to *be* lower than it *feels*, and it has everything to do with relationships within a track. 

The key that unlocked this for me was starting from the brightest thing in the mix, in my case, it’s almost always vocals. Then I start marrying the other things I want to match that. Everything else gets tanked. Shakers & Tambos and acoustics are WAY darker than they used to be for me, it’s basically vocal & snare that share the top of the record. 

The elements that live on the sides, those can start to creep up there too, but that’s a taste/track thing that varies. 

So as long as the right elements are in properly relationship with your focal instrument, the top can live almost anywhere.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve moved away from housekeeping passes like that. I called it “eating my vegetables”, where I’d assist myself - tuning, de-clicking etc ideally with a gap before sitting down to mix proper. 

Now, unless it’s a real train wreck I usually prefer to jump straight into the mix and see what comes out in the wash. 

I sometimes found myself being a hammer and everything looking like a nail, maybe tuning too tightly and needing to relax it once the mix had been built up. Or like how mastering can reveal issues that weren’t spotted in the mix, when the vocal chain and mixbus high shelf are in, clicks would be revealed that I wouldn’t have heard before, so I l’d wind up having to do another pass anyway.

Maybe most importantly though, by the time I got to mixing I could wind up already too familiar with the song and it’s nice to come at it fresh like clean socks.

author: BatMeckley

author: BatMeckley
content:
Little Marshall MS-2, which id brought to the session because I’d just read that’s what they used on the bass for Song 2 by blur.  It was a great lesson in how to actually make records, because while I was sitting in the control room figuring out how to mic the thing as an effect, how to patch it in, etc, Jon just had grabbed the thing, plugged in a mic with a 1/4” jack and was holding it up in their vocal booth, and I was like “well shit, I guess that works”. 

Also, we had a 2 bar clapping sample off a popular radio song, and he just held up his iPhone to the mic to sample it. We (I) can really over think things sometimes.

They had the entirety of the song written and pretty much 90% of it recorded by 6pm dinner.

author: BatMeckley
content:
One of the things that irks me most about mixes the last 5-10 years or so is how often they sound like an instrumental with a totally sonically dissociated vocal placed on top. Really takes me out of the song emotionally and makes it feel like karaoke.

I was having a conversation with Cavallo the other day and he was telling me his mix process that he learned, and it was basically “I just go left to right. First I bring up the kick. Get that sounding good. Is it doing what I want? Then add in the snare, is it good with the kick together? Ok. Then add in the overheads… etc. Then the bass, is it gelling with the previous? Ok good. Then the guitars… all the way through the vocals.” Sometimes it helps to just approach it brick by brick, making sure the building is plum before adding another story.

author: JustinLeu
content:
I am using a lot of un-shared verb sends to make stem printing quick/clean.

I will use EQ on verbs quite a bit, but one thing I really like is to put soothe before the verb and focus it on all the resonant harsh stuff. (Mostly doing this for vocals)

Also throwing a transient designer before the verb can make them less obvious.

Or a slow attack gate for vocals 25+ms keyed to 500-ish (avoids esses and breaths nicely)

author: Tristan
content: Great compressor on the right thing, usually vocals, not much else IMO. author: oaklandmatt
content:
i don't know anyone who makes modern records who doesn't compress AT ALL. jon has sometimes said he doesn't compress but 98% of the stuff he mixes has TONS of compression before it gets to him. 

like @Zakhiggins said, i dance between clip gain and dynamic processing when i'm mixing, using both 100% of the time. i adjust them back and forth, back and forth. sometimes undoing one in favor of the other. 

using both tools in tandem makes for much better clarity without killing dynamics. even SUPER compressed modern pop vocals are better with lots of little clip gaining. 

sometimes i use clip gain to raise the level of a word and even things out, but sometimes i use clip gain to reduce level and undo the sound of super compression so it's adds dynamics.

author: chadwahlbrink
content: Also, as an aside, I have a theory, not a hard and fast rule:  The most transparent tuning results come when separating out “s” and other hard consonants with the little “separate” tool, and then leaving those bits mostly untuned. I find the harsh high frequency noise content of sibilance just doesn’t take tuning well to my ear. It sounds digital much quicker to me if I don’t make those slices as I work. Kind of the equivalent of phase cymbals and hi hats when stretching drums too much.

author: cian riordan
content: By this logic, you could argue that any tool in a mixers toolbox is a band aid to a problem created in recording. Compression a bandaid for something recorded too dynamically. HPF a bandaid for something that was incorrectly recorded with too much low end. A Pultec high boost a bandaid for something too dark. Sometimes you get a vocal that has a pokey resonance that happens at 3k and if you try cutting with EQ, it kills the aggressiveness… but if you do it dynamically, it only snags it when the frequency poked 15 dB above where it should.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I don’t think it’s that heavy. When you come in full Hero Status, Additional Production is a completely non-threatening ask. It honors both your work and theirs. No need to make it any kind of big deal or get preemptively defensive, (hence the thumbs down on Ryan’s comment.)

When you send your next bounce, include excitement for how the project is turning out and do the ask. 

In my mind, additional production credit can be when you’re doing more than replacing kicks & snares and editing/tuning vocals. If you’re adding parts or fundamentally shaping groove elements, etc. 

But I’ve added guitar parts and replayed bass on songs I’ve mixed and not asked for production credit when it really was about making the mix work. 

It’s a per project thing I think. I rambling, but it sounds like you’re taking pride in the work and everyone is on board. Seems like a no brainer.

author: chrissorem
content: @Sam Segarra The way I think about reverb is  closer/further, and adding length. Room verbs and short verbs without pre delay or a small amount of pre delay are good for pushing a vocal back into the mix. And longer verbs  like halls and plates are good for adding length and if you want length and the vocal to feel forward at the same time add more pre delay.  So nothing to worry about but rather think about what you are trying to achieve with the two verbs.

author: oaklandmatt
content: detune the doubles* not the main vocal. like, if it's a super pop song where i want the doubles to be super tight, I'll hand edit them for the timing, and then hard tune and drop the left double by a few hz and raised the right double by a few hz in their respective auto-tunes. auto tune has a pitch reference control where it's set to A440, so you can alter than and just manipulate the overall pitch of your tuned doubles

author: Deleted User
content: At a certain price point(up to 2-3k€) I probably would reach for a dynamic mic or ribbon, speaking very generally. A dynamic can be cool to minimize room engagement, which can be great if the singer is loud and the room isn’t great. David Bock’s paper on capsules is really enlightening. I would definitely try and avoid a chinese capsule a la Rode mics, but the mic amp is also very important. I’d avoid condensers that have intense artifacts at high SPL because of their mic amp circuits(Brauner Phantom and the Neumann TLM series come to mind). It can be quite hard to find a condenser that has that vintage-U47 style body under a certain level of investment, which is why I might reach for a large-diaphragm dynamic or a ribbon(and boost highs). I’d what that low-mid body to balance out the density in the high mids. But I’m mostly talking about belly tenors here, with Betty female singer I would probably be fine with something with less body(like a U67-style mic) It’s quite an in-depth topic I find, you can hit me in the dms if you have specific questions.

author: GaspardMurph
content:
Usually I’ll prep the session the day or so before, that way I can take care of routing / solo’ing for problems / fixing problems / checking phase / asking for new files before I start the mix process so that when I sit down to mix, my ears are fresh. Then I usually start in the morning and mix until I’m happy, usually in the late afternoon / early evening. Then I come back the next morning and listen, make adjustments and send it over. I feel like the mix really finishes itself once the artist / producer / creatives get involved so I like to send a mix out pretty quick. 
All of this will vary based on: how close to finished the rough felt to me, and the instrumentation. 50% of my time is usually spent on the instruments and 50% on the vocals.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
So for this song I was hired to produce and mix it. I got the stems from the demo and did the production in ableton. Then vocals were recut in London and I was sent a Pro Tools session. I always cut and edit in Pro Tools, so I used this session to comp and arrange the new vocals, but then I wanted to just bring it back into ableton and blend with the existing production. So I bounced the vocal from Pro Tools dry  (no verb or delay) but with tuning and some compression and EQ. Then I used some of the demo vocal and some of the new vocal in the final mix.

I'm pretty comfortable committing eq and compression on my vocals (the confidence of years of doing this... ps you should do it more, it's good for the workflow). But if I needed to go back for some reason I could go back to the Pro Tools session. I think I did go back once to remove tuning on an ad lib that was part singing, part talking. 

I'm getting much more comfortable mixing in ableton. The only thing that really sucks about it is that the sessions do tend to slow down when there's TONS of vocals with autotune inserts (the equivalent number of tracks and autotune instances in pro tools does not tax Pro Tools nearly in the same way). So thus far the only way that ableton really works for me to both produce and mix in is if I don't have raw vocals in there. Hence, bouncing from pro tools works best anyway.

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Surprise surprise ima jump in with some Brauer bullshit again- zooming out of the vocal for a second, cuz I think the choices you’re talking about making, when made in a vacuum, can lead you to very different places depending on what you’re already hearing when you start adding vox fx. 

The idea is to identify the 2 or 3 things that the brain can actually focus on at any given moment in a song as the leading roles. Song I was on the other day had horns, vocal, and occasionally gtr were leading and everything else was just supporting (either octaves of the same part, rhythmically the same, or pads on keys). So I got those 3 rocking together without worrying about every track, it was easy to identify the kind of space I needed. I wanted it in the same room as the brass, but really forward on the stage. If I’d had the pads up while trying to do this I was always either too wet or too dry and couldn’t find the happy place. The tl;dr is, if you’re struggling to find a satisfying construction of ideas, you may be trying to treat leading and supporting parts as equally important, and you’re challenging your ear to grab what’s really important at that moment. 

Also in Brauer’s template there are a folder of verbs that everything in the session shares including vocals. So you get a sense of cohesion from that, and the vocals have their own folder of delays that are unique to them. That helps create separation.

author: JustinLeu
content:
A few more thoughts/ideas that I really like to do.

If using verb as an insert on an instrument:
- on insert 1–put Mondomod (or any panning plugin that will change the track from mono to stereo)  then use this as the pan before the reverb. This lets you place the instrument in the stereo field of the reverb. Doing it with mondo mod allows you to keep it static but also automate movement (small or large) within the verb 🙂

Another idea:
Use Waves StudioVerse (or similar plugin that allows this routing)
-parallel split the dry/wet 
-wet gets what ever verb you want
-Leave the wet panned out-wide
-pan the dry in towards the middle 

Doing it with StudioVerse allows you to avoid making aux-sends and keep it all on the track level. (Very useful on bgvs)

Last idea:
Use a pan control plugin (S1, TrackControl, etc) after the verb so you can make it more mono if you want. 

I love verb/dly haha thanks for letting me talk  about it here…my wife is tired of hearing about it 🥲

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly, this is where the difference is between good and great gear. I find if you get the right mic/pre combination, the esss problem is a lot more manageable. I’ve used the pencil technique before and was surprised how effective it was at taming esses and plosives, but it was a scenario where I couldn’t reach for another mic. Also angling the capsule slightly can help, but you have to be careful not to get the singer outside the pickup pattern. Much like micing an acoustic, you can do some real Eqing just by angling up more towards the nose or down towards the chest. I tend to like a vocal mic a bit lower than most people seem to put it. 

Also, @NoahNeedleman  can attest, if I’m in the session I’m proactively fighting against S lyrics, especially if you’ve decided that that’s the sound you want to aliterate in a verse. Straight to songwriting jail. 

Also, like Noah said re: eq ing esses, you can usually see on pro q3 the shitty part of the ess and eq it out… because it also tends to be a combination of the singers resonance and the mic resonance, it’s almost always the same across all of the esses in any particular track. Make a quick preset and just go to work.

author: bryan cook
content:
check out an ever so slightly delayed distortion so you get that diction *and* the hair, just later hair. i like memory man to sansamp. the dark memory man fuzzes up well. I like to push the “punch” lower mid eq before the sansamp gain stage and then roll off bass and treble on the sansamp as well. sometimes lpf and hpf the memory man / sansamp after the fact. making this dirty slap midrangey really helps it not compete with the real or good sounding vocal and fulfill a different role.

delayed distortion can kind of be like predelayed verbs. keeping it forward and getting the vibe stuff. best of both worlds.

author: Deleted User
content: I like to think of it as these three terms. 1) EQ/Sauce - no predelay or barely any (sometimes I compress it to play with the shape of it too) 2) space - 50 to 80ms (or use mix of reverb with no predelay on a slap with slightly longer delay time) 3) bloom 90-200ms. I usually just put a time delay on it before reverb if I want musically timed reverb, but I personally tend not to go towards that direction very often. I’m also a big throws person so mostly my main reverb that are sent to aux tracks have medium to longer predelay and throws would have shorter predelay. Sometimes it’s the other way around too. I also like to make decisions based on how long I want the vocals to be closeup for before I hear the reverb kick in. Or I also print reverb sometimes and nudge it around in different parts and play with fades if I wanna get really sculpt-y with it. I do this with reverb throws (dups clips to audio tracks rather than sends) more often than send verbs.

author: ALXCPH
content: I’ve been getting more and more into not using static time based effects on hip hop vocals other than maybe a little slap if I want to put the person in a space. For verbs and delays I’ll just make thows when appropriate. If I do actually put a reverb or delay that’s static I’ll really over do it for effect kinda like the swae lee verb from unforgettable. Really opens up a mix not having all these random ass 1/4, 1/8 and different spaces hanging around all the time. (This is strictly for hiphop where you have less space between words btw other genres I think about this a little different)

author: cian riordan
content: @Zack Hames On second look, this comes off kind of jerk-ey and I didn't meant to just brush off your quest for saturation dominance! I guess what I meant to say is that through the dozens of interviews with Jon and Matt, it's clear that he's averse to using compressors and tends to use saturators more to do the job. While I fuckin' LOVE me some saturators, I honestly don't see the two as interchangeable... they're just two very different tools. One is leveling volume and the other is distorting a waveform to generate harmonics. I think saturators are a great next level tool for people who have wrapped their brains around compression.... but you really need some form of compression on an un-treated vocal. I feel in contemporary music, people are leaning too much on high-end saturation to get things to sound exciting and hyped. If I'm ever using saturators to distort things (which is often), I'm always trying to find some sort of un-distorted high end source to help the ears cling to clarity in the mix. Sometimes, things will distort in a way that will add this clarity -- or even manufacture it. But most of these multi-band saturators are just adding a layer of fuzz to the entire midrange up and the whole mix just ends up sounding hazy. IMO, a great example of modern hip-hop mixing is Mac Miller's Circles. The high end on that record sounds just as exciting as anything else, but it doesn't sound like everything got ran through a buzz saw (shoutout Greg Koller/Jon Brion). Just my 0.02.

author: junior.frigo
content: Hey all! Got a quick tip for a noise reduction technique. Occasionally, I'll get a lead vocal in with too much background noise. But applying noise reduction across the entire frequency spectrum can reduce clarity, which I really want to maintain in the lead. SO. If you grab the brush tool in RX you can hone in on the most audible parts of the noise and create "fade-ins+outs" of noise reduction, maintaining top end clarity in your vocal but masking noise at starts, stops, and ends of phrases. Can be a real life-saver, Cheers!

author: Eric Martin
content: I use soothe on my own recordings sometimes when I don’t want to cut hi mids and just want them tamed a little bit, and sometimes I need it just because the singer has an odd resonance that needs addressing and soothe is the best for that sometimes

author: BatMeckley
content: Again, @Zack Hames has a lot of good insight on this. As a general rule, pan hard left and right, compress the snot out of them, take out the low end, and i most of the time prefer them brighter so I can hear them. A side effect of the Melodyne generation is you can actually lock them in too much, and what happens is they start to collapse to mono if they’re too tightly tuned and timed. As with all things, there’s a sweet spot. A fan of throwing a touch of modulation on them too, particularly a LIGHT flange. Then I’ll verb for depth depending on how out front I want the lead to be.

author: samvalentine
content:
I like microshift for that kinda schmeared widening sound. I know a lotta folks here like the H3000 for stereo modulation.
Unless your doubles are hard tuned or super vocaligned I'm surprised they'd be very mono sounding. You could try is slightly different EQ curves for each side, compressing each side independently, even a subtle flanger on each side can be cool, or maybe different styles of saturation. The options are pretty endless. I believe @oaklandmatt has mentioned in an episode that he'll pitch one double up a few cents and the other down a few cents to give a wider image.

author: Will Melones
content:
I had a teacher who suggested listening to the “edges” of the reference track. How much bass extension, air, width…and not getting caught up in the detail of the snare sound or the exact balance. Although when I’ve spent too long getting microscopic with a lead vocal or something like that, l’ll switch to the ref to reset my perspective on that element. 

You know about my SoundFlow trick now, and that convenience has increased my likelihood of flipping to the ref significantly. It’s just a press of a button on my S3.

I know a lot of folks here have been anti-dynamic EQ in fabfilter, but I genuinely love it for VO and vocals in general. It allows me to balance the low end or low mids without it sounding scooped or too wooly. It balances from word to word, almost like "Soothe" claims, but without being as destructive. I can boost low end without it having a static low end wooliness.

I don't use it for much other than that, sometimes I'll do it for a low end boost on snare with a tight Q. but those have been game changing uses for me.

author: sethearnest
content:
I just wrapped mixing an album project where the intentions were not obvious from track to track. And within the same album/artist/producer combo, some of them were things like “why’d you tighten those vocals and clean the breaths up?” and other songs were “why didn’t you tighten up those vocals?” Or “those drums hit too hard—needs to feel lighter like the rough” vs the next tune “why didn’t you make the drums hit harder? The rough doesn’t feel right.” depending on the song. Uncommunicated mind reading. 

So we dig in and go for something. Sometimes we get it right and sometimes we gotta peel it back or take it further. It is hard, but as @LAPhill said recently, even in difficult-client situations, I’m still asking myself “ok for next time, what adjustments can I make to make my mind reading better?”

author: sethearnest
content:
The Way to Export All Tracks from Logic to Equal the Exact Mix that the Artist/Producer Left Off From™

1. Any busses you want printed need to be showing as "tracks" in the Arrange window. You can do this from your Mix Window by selecting all busses/auxes you want to print, right-click, choose "Create Track", and now those Busses/Auxes will show up in your Arrange Window. Do this for any and all effects, parallel busses, etc etc

2. ignore step 2

3. Turn on your Cycle range you want to export (yellow bar across the top like Marv said) and select all tracks you want to export

4. File --> Export --> All Tracks as Audio Files

5. If next dialog box doesn't have options showing, smash that Options Button and choose various options
  a. Range: Export Cycle Range Only
  b. Uncheck "Bypass Effects Plug-ins" if you want their processing
  b. Include Audio Tail and Include Volume/Pan Automation selected
  c. Normalize Off

6. I suggest making an AES-Standardly-named New Folder and exporting into that 

7. Export that bad boy

This will ensure you can import into your Industry Standard DAW exactly where they left off, minus the mix bus processing. 

If they're sharing effects (e.g. guitar and vocal both going to a verb), and you want them both wet but also separate, then they'll need bounce those separately or dup the verb send/return (in which case their Valhalla Vintage Verb will be 12dB too loud b/c they'll forget to turn off their 2bus processing when they bounce it separately)

author: Rob Domos
content:
Did an absolutely wild dialogue rescue with spectre this week. 

Got this podcast vocal that sounds like it was recorded through a laptop mic into a web browser recording system that had really strong AI noise suppression and had crazy amounts of packet loss in the transmission on top of all of that. Basically 2k for days and almost nothing else and everything sounded grainy. 

So I pull up spectre and lightly boost everything except for 2k by just a quarter of a dB and then set the dry/wet to around 90% (didn’t look at the number) so you’re almost exclusively hearing that new information. It ended up sounding pretty close to decently recorded vocal and no amount of EQ would have gotten us anywhere near that close.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Also, we say "there are no rules" a lot. But actually that's not nuanced enough for my taste (and perhaps, this place).

There are many great "rules." Yes, some are dumb and some are wrong, but many of them are worth learning so you know how to break them.

Things like "cut eq before you compress, boost after" is a really great rule. When you learn to do it and to hear it, you learn why it's so important (pulling low end plosives out of a vocal so it doesn't pin the compressor, for example). From there you learn how and when to break it (I like boosting the 200hz-ish body of a live snare drum into a parallel compressor/ saturator to solidify and have control of that frequency range, automate it for fills, etc.).

IMO this is a great "rule," which is great to learn and then break all the time.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
- The classic example of compression is to use a fast release with something like a parallel drum buss. As the release lets go and brings up the room gain you get this urgent and explosive energy. When the room is good, and the compression timing is set right it can really make things sound bigger than real life. Remember we're trying to tell a story here, we can't jam the *actual* real power and size of stadium rock drums into that mono speaker at Target but listen to Paradise City and it tells the story pretty well ... our brain does an amazing job of filling in the rest

- The last example is using something like a good tube compressor on vocals. With a nice soft knee and lots of gain reduction we get bring up a bunch of low level and emotional detail, breathy whispery stuff at the end of lines etc that can really help a lyric connect. Often with something like a good tube compressor we get a healthy amount of harmonic distortion too along for the ride which adds weight to the vocal and draws the listeners attention

author: chrissorem

I think many elements of creating can  benefit from a technique of a “once over”. Meaning do some work on a particular element whether it’s vocal eq or tuning or editing do a pass on it, leave it alone for a bit knowing there is work to be done and jump to something else. It forces your brain to focus on something else and often something with jump out and you can do an another move.  For me it’s similar to when you can remember a word or a name of something and the more your try to remember that harder it’s gets and if forget about it and then think of something else all
Of the sudden it pops in your brain. I’m always trying to figure ways of getting out to my own way

author: peterlabberton
content: Not sure how helpful this is, but: as I’ve mixed more and more, I think consciously about this less. I tend to try and find 2-3 instruments/vocals that will occupy the main focus of a given song or section, and just put those faders up and try and get them to sound amazing. Then everything else just gets gradually turned up and processed to fit in with or accentuate those primary parts. I’ll often briefly solo them to high pass and usually subtly low pass, then sneak the fader up and not touch any solos again. Getting a track a little too quiet, and then hunting around with Spectre, an API style EQ, or Sie-Q for a pleasing frequency to accentuate works well for finding a spot in the frequency range. Also I will often aggressively scoop out low mids on sampled/software instruments as I find these almost always have way more weight there than needed in even a minimally dense mix. FX may be added at any point along the line: if I know it’ll be integral to the part I’ll pop ‘em on a bit while soloing at first, if not I’ll sneak the effect in gradually with everything else playing. I definitely need to be fairly aggressive with filtering as things get more dense, particularly in the low end.

author: peterlabberton
content: I’ve recently tweaked my mix template and put a Delay III plugin (is that what it’s called??) on the first slot of all my verb auxes. Then I leave the second slot blank in order to be able to EQ/de-ess/transient design/whatever before the verb—this way I can do most of what @bryan cook was outlining without extra tracks/routing. This all makes it easy to sync any predelay to the tempo of the song. I’ll often aim for something in the 60-120ms range as a starting point, whether that’s a 16th or a 32nd or whatever… OR I’ll just tweak by ear until it’s working. 🙂

author: Deleted User
content:
From my experience, mic positioning is the key with getting the clean brightness in vocals. A lot of times I’d put the mic slightly above or below the mouth to have the full spectrum of vocals without accentuation of high mids. The idea is that the voice projects through the mic not to the mic. This allows me to boost natural top end without having to make weird or any cuts on the high mids. Key thing is to keep the pop filter at the same height as the mouth so they don’t start looking up or down to match the height of the mic. That can be detrimental to vocal performance as it strains their neck. 

Sometimes people record too close to the mic. From my experience, it doesn’t take the EQ too well unless you’re intentionally going for the proximity effect to have a little more woomph. If you’re going for that, dynamic mic may be a better choice. 

I would spend some time working with the artists to go over mic positions on zoom before recording. For the vocals that are already recorded, I can’t really say much about what to do because there’s no context, but I’d say try not to over process because that would get things sounding dull very easily.

author: Rollmottle
content: Soothe can be a miracle worker! I've used it to tame resonances in the low mids from bass and synths, annoying ass honk on vocals, and gnarly sibilances. I find it's best used subtly, especially in my use case for correction on a master. I pull it out most often for taming build up and gnarliness in the mid range, especially as it relates to vocals.

author: cian riordan
content: Well from experience, there are certain instruments that take better to additive high-mid saturation -- bass guitars, vocals, etc. Some others -- like certain brass instruments, violins, etc -- can get really harsh if you push those too far. I would start by going heavy handed on the most innocuous of the pile-up and see where that takes you. Saturation is a great way of doing this without making things pokey... but might be good to audition with an EQ first to see what zones you should focus in on. Once you have an idea of where you're going, then you can fire up Saturn 2 or Spectre or Neutron and go to work.

author: Maxim
content:
I’d say when all efforts have been exhausted to try and get stems you’ve only got a few options depending on how “badly” the beat is mixed. But generally my approach might look something like this: First pull down the volume by a bunch. Then usually you’ll want to add in some transients back again. I like Spiff for this to taste. Then sometimes Master Rebalance by Ozone can be a life saver. Especially if say the balance of some instruments are clashing with the vocal or the 808/bass is too loud in relation to everything else. Essentially I’m “unlimiting the beat”. 

Then together with the vocal in the mix I’ll try to shape the beat around the vocal with some subtle (usually reductive) eq moves. Something like dynamically sidechaining a bell on the hihat frequencies to the vocal can help a lot. Or I might also play with Spectral Shape. Some people get good results with sidechaining the vocal as a whole with trackspacer or soothe. Then if I’m missing some super lows or excitement I might throw a Pultec/Bax-type EQ or Spectre on it. 

So ultimately I’m creating as much space as possible and give myself enough headroom to still do some typical mixbus moves.

To me this removes the need to do anything different on the mixbus. Even though it’s likely I won’t be able to push as hard.

author: austenballard
content:
I have a perspective on this that I've specifically been seeing in independent hip hop, and it relates to something y'all talked about on Conversations, which is 'what does a band look like'? 

I think that there's a new configuration of a 'band' (if you'd call it that) coalescing where instead of a group of people all playing different instruments, you have a group of people and one is the vocalist, one is the producer/composer, one is the engineer, but the lines are blurred somewhat because they all came up doing a little bit of each others' job and can communicate with each other about making recordings in a way that used to be the way musicians would communicate their ideas to each other.

So that's where art vs. engineering might be an outdated dichotomy at this point; I see the two becoming increasingly integrated

author: JustinLeu
content: I think something to think about is that  as others have said it is a useful tool in many situations, including creative uses (controlling lowend, side-chain specific frequencies etc.) For modern *LOUD* productions, there is no way to get around having complete control over each source. MB comp/Dyn EQ/De-essers are not band-aids, they are tools to control audio for a more controlled end result. On vocals...you could spend a lot of time automating resonances out (which sometimes is 100% the way to go) or you can put a Dyn-eq on a few freqs and keep working. These tools are incredibly useful for mix engineers that do not get a say in what gets sent to them.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I’m sure some of the big dogs here can share some munch more nuanced versions with their knowledge, experiences and perspectives. 

When I’ve experienced situations like this, I just try to not attach myself too much to the situation and just concentrate on moving forward, to the next project, and not letting the situation keep me down. If you continue to do good work, a few outliers won’t define you. 

Since music is collaborative we rarely can control many aspects of the process but our own. So i think it’s best to just do our own best work and try to be satisfied with that and move on to the next thing. 

The further you get in your career, the more opportunities you’ll have to decline work that does not align with what you want to work on/who you wanna work with. And cases like these will happen more rarely. But it is just part of it. 
You can always voice your opinion through a recommendation. But that’s about as far as you can go. 

Mentally, try not to let other people’s choices have power over your self worth. Stand back up and do more good work. 

I also have shit I’m embarrassed to have my name on(I think everyone does) but it’s all part of the journey. When I look at them now it just reminds me of a different time and point in my career, it doesn’t bring me down.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Also, if you’ve already mixed the track, I’d be thinking to make sped up versions of both the source material (played back through your existing chains) AND committed versions of your original BPM tracks. Not to mention your return FX - verb times and predelay might need to be tweaked, possibly delay feedbacks etc. Everything’s going to change, and keeping convincing/good feeling stereo image in things like verbs is one of the challenges.

It’s hard to predict what’s going to happen in any case, so for me it’s about doing the science with your science hat on, taking a break, then fucking around with options until the voodoo clicks. 

It’s not the same mix or even really the same production at the new tempo - groove will change, relationship between rhythmic parts (the satisfying low end you fought for in the kick is suddenly slowing everything down) and consequently vocal parts and their associated time based effects all shifts.

And with all that said: sometimes just blasting your printed mix with soundshifter sync mode beats everything I just described 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Ross Fortune
content:
