Alexis made some last minute lyric changes, recorded new lead vocals on his iPhone and I had to slot them into a verse. Wildest Pro-Q curves you ever seen, split across a bunch of tracks with different EQ and compressors for each word in some cases. I was pretty happy with the results in the end though, pretty imperceptible after everything went through the vocal mix chain.Took ages but it was a good ear training lesson. 

@jantrit ‘s recipe above is a good methodology

*Went back and dug it out, it was second verse of this track - 1:58 "a lot to learn, a lot to earn" was recorded on iPhone https://open.spotify.com/track/2yhKDrTVMCLBWYd0aIfOfy?si=1a2914797e6843d8

It's got a low double and the FX are such a part of the character; it's a context that allows this tomfoolery.


Incidentally, just remembering some other stuff around that record. It was produced by Philippe Zdar (that particular edit was made less than two weeks before his tragic death), and I remember the stems coming in with all of their character baked in. Wouldn't say it's the band's best album, but some of the parts were awesome.

A bass guitar came in with the hihat baked in to it, so I dutifully went back on emails asking for them separated, but that was how he'd printed it - they were sharing some piece of gear, and for whatever reason that's how they had to go down. Mark Ralph was mixing it, and at the time I might've had a bit of a "huh, Zdar's supposed to be a professional, why is the hi hat on the bass channel" sort of bullshit attitude, but that particular instance cleared that right out. Mark's response to anything like that was always pure acceptance and understanding that people work how they work and it's his job to do what he can with whatever he receives.

author: peterlabberton
content: Trying to match stuff by ear is a great learning opportunity (not trashing EQ match). Recently was trying to punch in vocals on half a bridge on a song recorded a year earlier in a different studio with a different engineer on a different mic. Just AB'ing back and forth and going, "ah, yep, it's a little brighter in the old recording..." and then poking around and trying to find out the right spot to boost... going back, "okay, now it feels a little boxy..." etc. etc.. When you get down to it, things are usually simpler than you think. It's bright, it's dark, whatever. You address it, and learn/train your ear in the process. And if you're a little lucky and kinda know what you're doing, often you can get pretty close pretty quick. 🙂

author: GaspardMurph
content:
I’ve been doing the same thing with my PCM70, cycling through the patches. Sometimes I feel that what I like is that those patches are a little bit over the top but I never bother to edit them because it’s a PITA to do. Maybe with plugins we have too many opportunities to tweak em to “blend” in the mix when the opposite might be better.

Here are a few things I like to do with vocal FX:
- Chorus / Doubler that I then distort and will boost some high mid frequency (spectre is great for that)
- mono slap back is underrated, can be very appropriate in modern mixes
- Mentioned many times but compressing / distorting / EQing reverb returns (side chaining the compressor in the return with the dry vocal as key can really make vocal reverb bloom)
- Also, I don’t always tempo sync my delays, sometimes 300ms just works 
-

author: LAPhill
content: Lastly, unless they were clever with the multitracking, you're likely going to run into phasing. The same instrument played the same way in the same position is not going to replicate 4 different players, on different instruments, in different positions. You might have better luck ditching some of the doubles. Or doing unspeakable things like pitching the down and using alterboy to pitch them back up, or slightly messing with formants. (Leave at least one natural if you do this)

author: chrissorem
content: Lots of good  ideas on the mix bus talk!  I think it can be easy to get in the weeds with the “Mix Buss”  I’ve found for myself that I will try these different techniques over the years for example,no mix buss treatment and only a limiter.  Then I tried the music/vocal buss thing. Then I tried only processing the groups and lighter on then mix buss processing.  What I learned is there is no right or wrong way to do anything  and it’s good to try different approaches out but if you feel you are fighting something it’s a good idea to check the processing and see if it’s tying your hands. The only way I know how to do this is gain match your inserts and turn them on and off.   I’ve mixed with the inflator and had good results,  and it’s also been horrible. I’ve mixed with Vulfcomp on the master (generally a horrible idea  but in certain cases it rules!) I even mixed with altiverb on the mix buss recently.  Good technique is  very important but sometimes I like mixing into something wildly colorful and it can take you to very interesting places sometimes you have to work harder for it but the end result can very unique

*A* way but not the only way: I'll try to pick only one or two things to really carry the 'weight' of the warmth and clean up other things in that range. Helps overall keep the perception of warmth without the mud. 

And never afraid to move/automate/dup-and-change-settings depending on the section of the song. As an ex.: if a verse is ac gtr and vocal only, the ac gtr can carry a lot of weight. When the band kicks in, you can thin out the ac gtr and let bass or something else carry some of it.

author: cian riordan
content:
Couple of random thoughts:
1. If the synth is extremely subby, consider pushing in some midrange via EQ or saturation to help definite it in the mix. Sometimes these synth basses are swimming in sub and the more you turn them up, the more it eats up headroom while still not really being able to hear it.
2. Are you competing against other low end sources outside of the kick? If so, you’ll have to divide and conquer the frequency ranges and let each one live in a specific zone. For example, if you have a bass guitar, make sure that its voiced in the fundamental 200-400hz area and leave the sub handle things below the kick.
3. Utilizing the analyzer in Pro-Q3 can be helpful for finding conflicting frequencies. You can throw Pro-Q3 on say the synth bass and the kick track, then on the synth bass instance, pull up the kick as a secondary histogram in Pro-Q3 and you’ll have a nice visual representation of where the kick is trying to punch through. You can then use some creative cutting to carve room for the kick. Or vice-versa.
4. Sometimes when nothing is working with synth bass and I need to do something drastic, I’ll delay one side of it 30mz to widen it out and get it out of the center. This can fall apart in certain mono-situations, but will often clear way for more bass instruments and the kick drum if done right.

As always, all of this is dependent on everything. YMMV.

author: jerikcenteno
content:
Heyo! I work in podcasting as a freelancer and at a podcast/media company. 

Echoing what others have said — get Hush. Get the one that goes in PT and not the standalone app. It’s expensive and can take a very long time to render if you don’t have a lot of RAM, but it is the best thing ever. Some RX stuff for de-reverbing is too artifact-y. 

Either than that, I just approach it like a regular mix! Go to the part where it looks the loudest and busies, and just make sure all the VO’s are about the same level — just “ear-balling” and clip gaining accordingly. The only diff is I use vocal ride from Waves. 

Also, the company I freelance at asks for final files to be -16 LUFS. Not sure if that’s standard everywhere, but just get a limiter where you can read the final LUFS after committing. 

Another tip is I make sure my clip gaining is set to 3.0dB in preferences. If somebody laughs over somebody, I’ll clip gain it down anywhere from 3-6dB.

author: Felix Byrne
Jonathan Jetter
content:
Certain group processing is easy, e.g. an EQ on a group is mathematically identical to the same EQ on each individual track.

Certain processing (e.g. Autotune) has to be monophonic in order to work right

Certain processing (dynamics, distortion) is very situation-dependent. And the more complex the chain, the more situation-dependent it becomes. And the linear processing (e.g. the EQ, but also most reverbs) then becomes different depending on whether it's before or after the nonlinear stuff.

author: chrissorem
content: @Slow Hand I almost always eq all fx and almost always make a a new verb or delay for  every new instance.  I can’t really think of a reason why I’d share fx unless I want something to melt together.  The fx end  up routing to their prospective group, for example vocal verb would go to vocal group ect and can be processed together if needed. I would almost never insert a verb on an individual track unless I want to push track back more into the mix. Or if I want a verb throw that simultaneously  turns the track down as I turn the verb up.  This is also the primary reason I don’t like inserting fx on a individual track. If you turn the fx up you are also Turing the dry down and in most cases I’m not trying do that. Also tend to process my fx, sometimes compression or saturation and also sometimes send fx to other fx. Example a delay feeding a verb

author: Eric Martin
content:
I think, again, it’s knowing the reason you’re using the tool, it’s mostly used when you want to accomplish something on the sides or in the mono signal when you can’t get to the track that needs the help, if your mixing, you should go to the track that needs the work first, not a M/S tool, M/S tools are designed for working on stereo tracks and shaping things because you CANT shape the original thing you want.

Example, the vocal is a little quiet in the mix, using a M/S tool to help bring the 1-2k of the vocal out in the mid without bringing out too much 1-2k of the cymbals and guitars on the sides because that balance was already where you wanted it. In this situation you can’t get to the vocal because you don’t have the track, BUT if you’re mixing, you can reach for the vocal and boost a narrow Q at 1500hz to accomplish the same task but in a cleaner way.

This is the type of reason I might reach for M/S, I don’t reach for M/S if guitars need to be brighter on the sides, I find the guitars on the sides in my mix, and make them brighter.

This is also the same reason to argue against multiple bus processing, because if the ability to use such a processor is there, we will use it, take away a bus and we have to work harder to get the mix done, but the end result can be much more effective, impactful, dynamic, and inspiring, but it takes longer and requires a lot more finesse.

author: alecdibell2

author: bryan cook
content:
My go to is a 16th note. It may sound like too much when the verb return is loud but when you sink the verb down it usually is really effective for me.

I like to use a mono aux with a delay plug-in for predelays, with a bus as the input and a bus to the verb as the output. No predelay on the verb itself, you make it before hand on this aux. Reason for this being you have a lot of control on your send signal that only the verb hears. A midrangey verb and a full range dry vocal make for depth and texture that can peacefully co exist. You can de ess the send harder than the real LV. With this pre delay aux you can make the send signal darker or brighter. If the song calls for it, make a second aux and have multiple predelays feeding the same verb. For example, a 16th with no feedback that is 80% wet, and a second input bus to same output bus that is dark 1/4 note 100% wet and with feedback where you can automate the send to that long feedback predelay and leave the short no feedback 1/16 static. You can get a lot of mileage out of the same verb with these multiple pre delays and provide some cohesive varied space.

author: BillyC
content: It's mostly about keeping phase in mind and not working against the bleed. If there's vocal bleed in the guitar mic then the guitar mic is part of your vocal sound and vice versa. Before doing anything, it's usually worth zooming in and sliding the regions around a bit to see if you can improve their phase relationship at all. Then you can try to use EQ in a way that best preserves that relationship with the least harm done to the overall vocal sound. I've had good results with keeping any HP/LP filtering on the sum and using only bell filters on the individual stems.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’ve got the right idea - The more different the left and right, the more wide it will feel. So you can change timing, pitch, and timbre/tone when double tracking to make it wide but also balanced. For example, double tracking guitars, keep the same guitar cab and guitar but different amp head. Or different pickups from the same entire rig. Etc. 

There have been a lot of good tips for layering vocals, to have the harmonies be different mics and preamps or simply stepping away from the mic to get more distance. 

As far as plugins and stereoizing, even a simple pitch shift plugin can do a lot. Delay 15-30ms each side, pitch +/- 5-10 cents, can get a cool effect if used subtly

author: Deleted User
content: The best tip I can give is moving back at least a foot(!) from the mic on the belted notes. Compression can get weird if the singer has vibrato in their voice(ESPECIALLY parallel compression), of not it’s less of an issue, but can still make certain voices sound like a duck if not done well. I also personally would only do broad-stroke clip gain/clean up and then use automation instead, I’ve had much more success making the dynamics sound natural that way.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
i started doing this at the beginning of the year and was probably the biggest improvement for the consistency of my mixes:

1) use _one to two_ reference track that i think the tonal balance is perfect (for me 7 rings by ariana grande lol)
2) have it in Adapter Metric AB looped at the chorus of that song and assign the A/B switch to a key command
3) hit the key command while your track is playing and reference a short 3 second burst than go back to your track

The only thing im listening for is stuff that is _completely_ out of whack that jumps out immediately. Like "WHOA there is _way_ too much 1k in my vocal" Anything more subtle is going to throw me down a rabbit hole of trying to match 2 completely different songs.

Like @Eric Martin said, it’s not a hard & fast rule, but the philosophy is this:
Think about what goes in the middle, and think about what goes on the sides; pan accordingly. 

I tend to think the only things that truly occupy the middle should be kick snare bass and lead vocal. but of course every rule is meant to be broken. Hence the word “primarily” in my note to self.

author: cian riordan
content: Make it sound huge in mono, it'll sound huge in stereo. Make it sound huge in stereo, will probably sound small in mono. There's no rules anymore, but with arrangements this simple, if you cant get vocal and acoustic to work down the middle, there are likely arrangement & recording issues.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
I saw a reddit thread yesterday where a guy was essentially asking, "I mix for a living, but only compress vocals. Am I doing something wrong?"

author: spectrummasters
content:
“This held true over into the recording world for me as well. When I was trying to capture something in my head I was a slave to it, but when I’m trying to capture something in someone else’s head, I’m merely curious and experimental. And *that’s* when I learned the craft. Mixing, recording, producing, etc. “
This resonates with me so much right now. I’ve found the biggest challenge most recently has been , being able to learn to mix (particularly vocals ) to someone else’s taste/aesthetic that isn’t my own. I came into mixing from mixing my own productions where it was always just making the sound I want. Currently here in London a lot of young rappers like this huge ambient reverb sound for their vocal  that to my ear just leaves a long washyness over the instrumental and I find very hard to accept as appropriate for the groove/tempo and on a rhythmic .delivery ... I think it sounds better dry ...learning how to successfully achieve an aesthetic I disagree with  , to someone else’s satisfaction has been a really rewarding journey of self as well as skill. However , If I’m mixing gabba records in 5 years I’ll have taken this too far

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I find that telling someone they’re wrong or that you know better is NEVER the right move. Even if you’re right and they admit it. Trust gets built through curiosity. 

When I have clients ask for specific fixes, I tend to try to get them to focus instead on what the perceived problem is, or the desired outcome. 

Also, starting by just doing what the client asks, understanding the intent, and then achieving that *plus* the other things you know it needs not only builds trust, but it shows them you respect their vision. 

Also don’t shit on CLA Vocals. 
Repeat clients tend to have fewer and fewer requests like this, and start to sound more like “do your thing.”

author: spectrummasters
content: FAO : Logic Gang. I may well be v late to this but have recently been getting into Logic’s Selection-Based Processing function and have found it to be excellent for Vocal Clean-Ups. The selection based processing allows you to create a new take every time that appears in the timeline with the original unprocessed region as a takes folder just like when you loop record. What’s handy I’ve found is if you wanna quickly soothe, or de-ess / gullfoss your vocal but not apply it to the whole vocal take.....simply use selection based processing on the whole vocal and create a new take for each process (one soothed , one gullfossed , de Esser etc)....then go back into the timeline and simply comp the soothed/guullfossed take for the  problem areas...into the original take ...it takes seconds with the highlighter and then you can flatten the takes and its all done! So you’ve Only got the processing exactly where you want it and nowhere else. I guess pro tools clip fx does the same ? But this is a lovely one for logic.....super quick and clean

author: Deleted User
content:
Depending on the tools at your disposal and the exact situation I have a few suggestions:

Look for some low end in the performers vocals. Boosting with SPECTRE is nice but any eq can help add weight to a vocal if you’re boosting correctly. I would suggest having the dynamics tamed to your liking before boosting low end in a vocal because it can easily get out of hand

You could try duplicating the take, use RX de-reverb or whatever you can to remove as much ambience as possible, compress it heavily and blend it in. Obviously compression will bring out ambience so as to not let that become an issue try removing it beforehand. 

AVOX duo is a neat trick I use sometimes to help give a vocal some dimension. I use it on a send.

author: aidanthillmann
content:
If you set up your Pro Tools template in a certain way, you can bounce stems super fast. I set up auxes and route stuff to them that will be a stem, so it’s part of the prep process (i.e. route Lead Vocal to Lead Vocal Aux, Keys 1 to Keys 1 Aux and so forth), so choose what you will for the song and split up however much you need to. Then I use sends (or you can multi-output) to respective audio tracks and name them (you can also include Instrumental, TV Mix and A Cappella as their own audio tracks). Record-enable all the audio tracks, record them down. Then use Soundflow to copy the mix buss plugins you need (Copy Track Data macro), copy them to all the audio tracks, then use Track Bounce to offline bounce all of the stems in one go, and it will include the plugins. Takes about 10-15min.

The only caveat with this is that you have to route any effects to the same aux, like Lead Vocal Verb has to go to Lead Vocal Aux and nowhere else, so you can’t share effects. But if you just create verbs for each thing as you go (or set up in your template) it’s no problem.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Majors, indies, everyone’s having a laugh 😂

I made the list @Adam Thein posted above over 2 years mix assisting on largely major label chart pop, both UK and international. The points listed are all there because they were the things that came up over and over again, at every level.

There was all sorts of hi-jinx going on constantly - as you say, I’m sure Manny’s assistants do a ton of prep to get the sessions in proper shape before they get to him.

One of the first checks I’d do was to make sure the lead vocal takes *and lyrics* matched the ref. It happened relatively frequently that there’d been rewrites along the way (especially verse 2, for whatever reasons), or they’d reverted to the original demo vocal and lyric at the last minute but we’d been sent all LV by the vocal engineer/producer and communications hadn’t gone up the line.

There’s a mega talented and successful writer/producer we worked with frequently who had to send me their logic sessions on more than one occasion to track down missing takes when they couldn’t find them. Zero shade on that writer, they just weren’t engineer minded and would commit stuff, chop it up, swap verse 1 with verse 2, process it etc along the writing journey. Their focus was rightly on making a banger, not providing some nerd (me) with flawless multitracks for a song that might never get cut. 

It sucks, but it’s just part of it

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Rules for giving notes. 
1) start with what you like, but be brief.
2) “kick up” 👍🏻 “I feel like the kick is too thin” or “boost 50hz” 👎🏻 
3) mixers expect notes, so approach every communication collaboratively. 
4) if something is wrong but you’re not sure what it is, call and discuss. 

Basically not everything needs an explanation, not everything needs to be handled gently. “Kick up, drier verse vocal, longer snare tail, brighter vocal.”

author: masteredbyjack
content:
You know, I've been thinking more about something like this. Almost always I would much rather refer people to a proper mixer...someone like @cian riordan  or @Adam Thein provides insane value IMO (also @Joshua Riley ). But I have, for whatever reason, recently been hit up more often about having me mix...and sometimes there isn't the budget to hire a proper mixer (I advocate for that up front whenever possible, even going so far as telling most people they should hire a mixer rather than me if they have to choose one).

Normally I just do the stereo master in those situations after saying my piece about the value of a mixer, but when people don't want to hire a mixer I have been considering just asking for the session (was chatting this with @Joshua Riley actually the other day). 

Often when I hear the "mix", I know if I just had the session I could improve it by way more than just having the stereo file...say just raise this here a half db put some color only on the vocal, tweak the mixbus, but for a lot of reasons I haven't asked for that yet. Maybe I will try this and see about the results!

Corollary is I find that stem "mastering" is honestly the worst of all the worlds, for me it would be either the standard stereo file master or give me the session. Which I would approach with a mastering mindset, accepting things for what they are and listening big picture.

Also I've come from producer/mixer land and being new to mastering in late 2022/2023 really...I am sorta less attached to what mastering "is" in the philosophical sense.

I often think of mastering as just making the song better (to my taste and ear) within the almost arbitrary restriction of just having the stereo file. Of course this ignores the mindset of approaching a full project! Which is a huge part of mastering. 

But as you stated, with how technology is evolving and the ease with which we can send stuff, may change. Excited to see where it goes!

author: Ingmar Carlson
content: On the subject of over-flattening vocals, I think we're definitely dealing with a cultural feedback loop of sorts here, not dissimilar perhaps to what's happened over the past few decades with autotune. More and more people are accustomed to vocals feeling this way, and not just dynamic flattening with overcompression, but emotional flattening as well. People are referencing vocals that feel like this. And by the time things get to us, they're often sufficiently dehumanized to the point where trying to inject more "natural" dynamics etc is already a fools errand

author: Rob Domos
content:
There are a lot of things that you’d usually want to fix regardless of any considerations in the track. Ie. Crazy plosives, mouth smacks, jacket rustling, mic stand bumping, noise fades, etc. I’ll typically get these janitorial fixes done without much thought of the context, (with the exception that I know to leave in a little more lip smack if it’s an aggressive rhythmic track than I do if it’s a ballad).  Beyond that my main thought is that I don’t want to hear the microphone. ie. mechanical sounding capsule buzz is something I tend to attenuate. 

All of this happens without me being able to hear the instrumental context (though I wish I could. RX integration into a daw context would be a game changer for me). 

Ruairi will rebalance the harmonics in a vowel, and while I also do that some in a vocal prep context, it’s harder because the undulation of resonances in a full musical context sometimes feels exciting while in solo it sounds off-putting. Ruairi gets to have the whole song in his RX window where I’m often only hearing the vocal, so I have to be a little more careful to imagine context and hedge my bets Hippocratic oath style, lest it looses some life.

author: chrissorem
content: It depends but two things come to mind. One would be that I want to vocal to feel upfront but I want length  I tend to darken with a shelf anywhere from 2-5k. Reduce to taste. I prefer to do this before the reverb usually.  The other thing that comes to mind is verbs can take up quite a bit of space, so  one way to listen for it is to turn the send up to taste and then mute it.  try and listen for what tonal changes are happening when it’s unmuted. And take away masking frequencies.  Some instances I boost frequencies  on the fx  return, this allows it to poke out where it can be heard and I can turn it the return down a bit.  Does that make sense ?

author: Tristan
content: While I now own well over 2000 plugins freezing is ideal in most circumstances because there just isn't a consensus on the way all plugin manufacturers authorize their products and that bites you in the ass. An example might be Goodhertz, which you may have installed once before as a trial or part of a bigger pack, but not authorized yet or the trial ran out. All DAWs will load the session with presumably no problems, but it's not until you manually open the insert itself that you realize the plugin has been operating in bypass the entire time. Waves even does a version of this now too, but it's active with 15-30sec intervals of silence. Multiply this with basically every plugin manufacturer and it becomes a very complex matrix. Furthermore, some plugins aren't as backwards compatible as they should be or different computer architectures impact settings carrying over. AutoTune (the bane of my existence) for a long time would flip settings if you went from a silicon Mac to an Intel Mac, but not vice-versa. Too many gremlins to account for to be fully reliant on their session as-is, but of course it happens. nature of the beast.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
This is not exactly the same, but a story regarding something similar -- did a song where a feature was added to a song I mastered (team very legit behind the scenes). I look at the new file, most everything is cut off above 15k or so. But it was a wav, and the new vocal added had full spectrum audio. So my spidey sense goes up, I make the ask and sure enough the vocal engineer who cut the feature got the file off a text thread which had converted it to m4a, that was used to track the vocal over, then sent back to me, etc. We were on really tight deadline but luckily we could make the switch and get it done.

This issue happens almost daily where people send files on iMessage, it can say it is a wav on their end but on receiving end it gets converted lossy. Just something to know and keep track of as things move really fast these days, another point for QC being important.

author: peterlabberton
content:
I’ll add (again, I feel like I say this a lot!) that, in addition to everything @Tristan said: using a consistent monitoring level is amazing. That’s been a big step up to me in terms of consistency and speed. It took a while to wrap my head around it at first—I was used to yanking the monitoring level around all day—but has majorly paid off.

I’d do what you can to find a level that feels good for you (low 80s db on an iPhone SPL meter for me), and get your DAW and Spotify/whatever to all sit there on finished tracks. Then* you have a sense baseline for what banging drums sound like, for instance, or where the vocal should sit in a chorus or a quiet bridge or whatever.

*after you’ve listened to tons of music in your space like this!

author: spectrummasters
content:
@Nomograph Mastering  Thank you ruairi . I appreciate it . Starting with the vocal is actually a very pertinent point for me . 
For this body of work I’m going  through currently the vocals are all tracked to a 2track instrumental but  with most of the songs  I’m importing all the instrumental multitracks  into a new alternative of the mix and ditching the stereo instrumental , much for the reason you’ve pointed to there . 
The balance of the instrumental sounds excellent to itself but once you start mixing the vocals , they really need a re balance of the instrumental mix elements to allow space . So this has had me listening to the vocal alone first at length and then bringing back the instrumental elements very much around it. I was thinking yesterday how remarkably different a balance was needed to give the vocal its place.  It feels like trying to matchmake two friends who are going to be great together if you can just find the right setup , 
Main weapons (of love ) have been faders , panning and gentle eq . All of which I learnt how to harness their true power here . I’m back at it again this morning and feel great about the challenge again and do love these songs . The artists are telling true stories and speaking their truth in them and that’s what drives me to excel with a project 


There’s also an addictive joy and fear dynamic here atm as I continue my ever deepening realisation that there is no perfect mix to find and attach myself to ! 

I have to remain open for the “feeling “ right ? Ha ha . This is Some mystical stuff we engage ourselves in I swear 

Thanks Ruari , best wishes

Thinking about this lead me to a new question:

How are you all striking a balance between the idea of “turn up what sounds good / turn down what sounds bad.” and the idea of placing density based on what the song wants. 

As an example, let’s say 4k in a vocal recording sounds like trash texturally, but the writing/arrangement is begging for a 4k forward vocal.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Reverb can eat up a lot of space in a mix, try muting most/all instruments and just listening to drums/bass/vocal+fx. How does it sound? Still muddy? Roll off the low end on the reverb and/or shorten it. Now start bringing instruments in and rebalancing, when do you start to lose reverb intelligibilty? Try to work out what’s masking it and treat accordingly. Also +100 what Cian and Noah said.

author: noahc

author: Maxim
content:
I think that might be a limiting factor on top of the artists' abilities (Pop Smoke already sounded dope before his setup got professional https://youtu.be/317TP4JOSSE). I've recorded not-so-great rappers through nice chains and mixing wasn't the answer to save a (lacking) source. It never gave you *that* feeling. But even if you are recording great rappers cheaper mics tend to lack body and rarely have "boostable" or pleasant top end as you said. So it's a bit complicated before you even get to "mixing". Felt that was important to mention so you're not too hard on yourself.

But assuming that the limiting factor really is just mixing there's a bunch of options. First things first: is your monitoring and listening environment decent? Or are you on headphones? This could make placing vocals even harder for you. 

Then do you have a process that starts with vocal cleanup to get rid of or reduce unappealing harshness or performance issues? Despite being simple, people tend to skip basic tools like clip-gain to even out a performance. This should usually also give you some leeway for strategic boosts. Maybe instead of EQ look at harmonics. Fresh Air by Slate is free. Gem Dopamine is nice. Spectre is great. All of these should give you that "sizzle" you might be missing.

Then to get the presence and even out the performance you could try some parallel compression with something like an 1176. Also, try out Multiband Compression with the Mcdsp 404 or C6 or whatever you have to control the performance throughout the song once you've got a vocal sound you like.

I also find mixing the 808 & drums together with the vocal the most useful when it comes to gain staging and getting the song to feel right.

Obviously, there's more that could be said but I find processes more helpful than tools. It's art at the end of the day. Attached what Serban's assistant sees as their/his "mixing process". Mix more and experiment with what you have. Get feedback from the artists.

author: itaylerner
content: If you can get it to a place where you like the top end but feel like the body is missing try giving Wavesfactory Spectre a try, it’s great for adding some tasty 200-600hz to a vocal

author: Adam Thein
content:
A huge majority of the work I do is tracked at home by indie artists and I'm often wearing a lot of hats with a "mix" that can vary from a track that hits my inbox completely edited (timed, tuned, audio cleaned) and I can sit down and mix a track in one sitting (2-3 hours) before I feel good about sending it off.  That situation for me almost always involves programmed drums or drums printed by the artist with a committed sound.  However, that being the ideal I can also be completely transforming and recovering tracks that arrive with tons of noise, resonances, artifacts, clicks, multitracked drums not phase or time aligned, sloppy super dynamic playing etc, vocal timing and tuning.  On that side it can take days and days, weeks and weeks, or even months off an on depending on the artist and track count.

My advice on projects like that #1 is make sure you are negotiating your rate based on the extra work expected of you and #2 try and compartmentalize so that you are doing all the dull tedious work separate from the creative mixing.  Take a lot of breaks, and make sure you are communicating with the artist to manage expectations on why things are taking more time.

author: Maxim
content:
It depends on the song but a lot of times you don’t actually want to “hear” the reverb. It should be woven into the performance in a smart way and that’s where choosing the right verb and EQ is essential. 

So I’m not sure if there’s really any “secret” other than developing your ears to hear what’s right and knowing how to get there. 

If a client is asking for “more reverb” I wouldn’t take that literally. Maybe they want to hear more reverb between phrases (automate or use ducking), maybe they want a verb that has more high-end information (plates tend to sound a bit dull unless EQed), maybe use multiple reverbs at different lengths with various characters to compliment each other, etc. etc.

There’s really too many options to give a general response.

But as far as getting the vocal upfront use pre-delay and slap delays to get that width. Dial in the MS amount by ear.

author: Zack Hames
content:
- EQ them differently is a great place to start in mixing.

During recording, you can use a different mic, have the singer back off of the mic more than the lead, etc. I’ve found using a different mic is an AWESOME technique, it’s a must. I started hearing phasing in my doubles and harmonies, especially when you start tuning, different microphones fixed that problem immediately. 

It doesn’t even need to be the best mic - if you’ve only got one “proper” vocal mic, a sm57 might be just fine for the certain things.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
the main thing for phase issues is not hard tuning double/ triples. if you tune things aggressively, they will be pulled so accurately in pitch that they will phase in the frequency range of the note being sung (the fundamental plus some harmonics). 

depending on the type of song, i will either tune doubles less aggressively, or sometimes detune the whole vocal a couple cents within auto tune. you have to LISTEN (of course) and play with the options to see how wide/ chorusy/ flangey you want it to be.

author: sethearnest
content:
For sync most of the time they want actual sub-mixed stems per inst group, not multitracks, so a drum mix, bass, guitars, etc, as separate stems all adding up to the stereo mix. So whatever’s a part of the busses /subgroups adding up to the stereo mix should be left on. 

The reason why: Most of the time they’ll use the stereo mix in my experience, but if something like a shaker or lead synth is wailing away under a dialog moment, or something like a boomer is messing up a sound effect, they’ll bust into the stems to mute those conflicting elements, but they’ll want the song/mix to generally sound the same. 

So for sync stems, they may have deliverable specs already, so doesn’t hurt to ask, but if not, I always try to put myself in the mind of an editor and approach stem splits with the idea of “if it could be distracting, it gets its own stem.” Generally, aside from basic inst groups, I’ll split out high perc stuff, boomer/swooshers/lifters, any leads/solos, and of course vocals always get split lead and BGVs as separate stems.

author: Will Melones
content: I’d second the opinion that you should use different guitars. The small variation in intonation will give you more width than amp tone. Same with background vocals—I like to leave them a little less tuned than the leads (but not distractingly out), unless they’re sung by different people.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I almost never use multiband comp tbh. I use multiband saturation all the time with Saturn.

The general reason i use it is to brighten something without simply adding a high shelf, or to create a broader wider transient on a drum track. The distortion with splay out the sharp transient. So I’ll saturate high end on vocals or bass to get more openness without harsh high end boosts, I’ll use the same sort of settings on close mics on acoustic drums to get more attack and punch. 

This is an Oversimplification but Nothing is bad in excess if it sounds good.  There are no rules.

author: Will Melones
content:
I have two thoughts on this. One is to use balance (often fader automation) to bring attention to a particular track moment by moment. Maybe multiple midrange elements will be competing, but the ear can only focus on one at a time (in addition to the drums, bass, and maybe vocal) so YOU choose and shift the focus!

My second approach is to take two or more of the competing tracks, say kick and bass, and play them together. No point in soloing one. EQ one while listening through it to the other. You may notice that you can subtract quite a bit from the bass without losing its character, but the kick’s punch is improved by the space you’re carving out. I do this a lot with vocals, too—focusing on the vocal inside a dense mix while subtracting from all the other stuff that’s stepping on it. When the lead just finds its home in its own uncongested space, you know you’ve got all the surrounding noise right.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Having a balanced top end is part of the dark magic of a good mix. I’ve def had trouble with that before. 2 things have helped me a lot. 1) choosing what lives in top super carefully. (Usually vocal & top of the snare are the brightest things in the mix.) 2) using a pultec on the 2buss to give some uniformity to the top end.

author: GaspardMurph
content: Hey Chad, thanks for the video! I use the same technique as well. In my experience and after much testing, I have found that buffer size makes NO DIFFERENCE in h/w insert latency (at least with my Apollo interfaces, could be different with others but not sure why). Also, I had my HW latency dialed perfectly for each sample rate I use but since the second to last PT update (the one before integrated Melodyne), I have found that pro tools now calculates automatically and if I leave all HW latency at 0.0 in my playback engine, I get perfect null). Also! I have found that one thing that totally affects the number of delay is the settings of my interface, there are a bunch of settings within the Apollo’s (dsp load lock, UAD engine delay comp…) that will affect the latency. Hope this information might help!

author: Maxim
content:
For some activities flow is essential for me (prototyping/design/production) whereas with something like mixing I don’t want to get lost in flow too often. But I couldn’t follow a timer consistently so I try to take breaks whenever I finish a section of work.

So for instance I’ll get the session setup, organized, listen and take a look at some things that are really poking out at me. Then I’ll make a conscious effort to get up and make a coffee or tea. (Short break 10 min tops)

Then I’ll come back and do some editing if needed and start getting the important things to feel/sound right (usually low-end & vocals). Then once I feel like I’ve got then in a good spot I also step away again. This is the hardest break to take for me because it’s just before I could go off into the deep end. But I’ve usually spent an hour listening and tend to lose perspective if I were to go much further. Sometimes I’ll also close the session and work on another project if I’m not in a rush.

But approaching it from a more conscious perspective and removing myself once I’ve hit certain check points is the only thing that’s working for me.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’m only dealing with digital clicks very rarely. Usually on loop edges, so you can deal with them and make a new loop (you might have to copy-paste a kick transient or guitar attack from elsewhere).

Vast majority of cases are mouth noises, often on in-breaths or ends of words (but everywhere in between too - squelchy mouth closes and opens, all sorts really).

Totally depends on the singer. Some are fiends for it, some less so. Especially if they need a drink - a sip of water can save work down the line.

They’ll usually be more apparent in quieter phrases, closer to the mic etc. where the “signal to noise” (ie vocal to clicks) ratio is lower.

I work largely in pop, so layers of compression and generally a brighter vocal balance exaggerate them, plus the lead vocal tends to be forward in mixes, in arrangements that lend themselves to vocal clarity in the upper mids and above.

author: Zack Hames
content:

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Sometimes Avid Lo-Fi’s saturation can help voice cymbals a little lower (by dulling/darkening).

Whatever approach you take, listen with all the drum mics in (don’t solo), as any processing will affect how the mics on a multimic’d kit interact with each other. 

Lo-Fi Saturation adds gain, and for some wild reason there’s no Output Trim on Lo-Fi, so you’ll have to compensate (or not) for that too.

My two gotos are

author: cy (sigh)
content:
the main thing for me is finding a couole of elements i can really dig into. i might mute everything but that and get tjose sitting where i personally like them - may not be right for the song. this is rrally to get me excited abiut things. ive found that so long as im excited it doesn't matter if i actually kbow what my next step is I'll move by instinct or intuition. 

i do smoke weed but in my case it isnt directly related to my creative ideas - ive spent months withiut smoking and that changed nothing aside from me being anxious af af every session 😂

but i really recommend building a list of homiew to bounce ideas off of. over the pandemic i became friends w a slew of producers and a few engineers and we send thongs back anf forth all the time. between taste and what we work on it varies a lot so we manage to get some solid perspectives. i do think the kind of question bwing asked or how its framed can give more ideas then the simple feedback. had someone ask me whatbi liked, didn't, like and would straight uo trash in a song then asled me if i would use the "bad" sounds in something else. that made me think about the sounds ina v diff way and startwd approaching it that way. 

switching up your approach might also work. if you usually start w drums, start w the bgvs or synths. 


laat thing is, just do it. even if you dont likw it, finishing will let you gwt a diff perspective once you know one of the many options. you ca take notes and start again baswd on that and sometimes you'll likely keep some of what you already did -obv there's a time issue w this one

author: wald
content: Relate with this a lot. I always have a mix like this in the que. Sometimes even good songs , but bad execution as far as rate of information is concerned. Ex a perc part to lift a section, that flams with vocal consonants and unpredictably combines with snare midrange. Millions of examples. The way out for me at least, is to zap the anomalies and unpredictables one by one. Solo mode, out of context, because clearly you can’t mix yet. One by one knock them over. Vocal resonances, consonants, timing, buildups, stacks’ phasing, instrument sections against vocal, etc etc. Make a list even. Might be 3 hours of work, but can save days down the line. The focus will eventually come. Serban’s secret weapon is John Hanes 😂

author: BatMeckley

The one thing I really do believe in is compressing on the way in. Singers will sing totally differently in response to the squish. 

<deep breath> 
That’s what’s great about the Apollo universe, if you can’t afford a good comp on the way in, being able to have a good (great) compressor emulation on the way in with virtually no latency is an even bigger win than the AutoTune to me.

Had a lot of success with Noah with that last week when the outboard VariMu wasn’t working for me

author: Zack Hames
content:
I fuck with dynamic EQ. If I’m doing a large but tight Q boost on say a snare drum, like 15-18dB boost at 150hz or so, it’s nice to only have it actually boost when the snare drum is being hit instead of just a bunch of low end statically swimming.

I also like it for wide Q boosting low end on vocals. Again to balance the low end from phrase to phrase or word to word.

author: Adam Thein
content: One other idea to try - if you layer in a pretty quiet dark reverb that is short (maybe 200-500ms) you can reinforce/lengthen the low end content already in the vocal.  If you have Seventh Heaven Pro there are some "Interiors" that I've used for this before, or you can dial in really any smooth room/chamber type verb really short with a lo pass set to taste.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok if it’s intimate- I’d say maybe lean away from doublers, and go more for verbs for size. Something filtered for low mid focus, compressed/saturated. 

But for making a vocal sound intimate, compression is your friend more than anything else. Choose one that brings low resonances out- like a fairchild instead of an 1176.

author: Adam Thein
content:
DAMN nice!  This did exactly what I hoped - appreciate the suggestion!  There's a preset under the Spectral De-noise called "Hiss control" and just a smidge of this (1.5db) was enough to tilt that balance where I wanted. Quick edit - definitely wouldn't recommend slapping this across a whole vocal, but it helped on a couple words with "ah" vowels on this vocal that were extra breathy.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So when I’m thinking about glue, I’m mostly thinking about frequency cohesion. Like where is the top of the vocal? How do I get the top of the snare to live there too? Are my perc tracks or BGVs adding density to the sides? Or just motion? Do my bass and kik muddle each other or enhance? It’s almost always an eq question for me…
Of course I never stopped using compression so we may be on different paths. And of course Cian is 100% right. Now that you’ve learned the “why,” it should be very easy to hear what the comps are doing and how to use them to benefit your tracks.

author: Joshua Riley
content:
I’ve been using HitSend and honestly so many more pros need to hear about it! It’s got file management, mix notes, mix versions, invoicing and payment all built into one platform. I setup a project with the name and everything, setup the invoice and can choice whether I want a deposit or not, then create a playlist and add the mixes to that, Artist can add notes etc, you can go through multiple versions and then once it’s done, you add the files to the deliverables folder, they can click approve which will take them to a payment gateway to settle the invoice and straight after that, they download the deliverables package
There’s a few deeper tools as well such as password locking, who has access to what, if you’re just sharing a link you can choose which link has the ability to comment and approve, you can bring on project members as well so that they can manage the project and files and a few automation integrations as well as email notifications for everything. Also has google drive and Dropbox Integration

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Full band compressors with a filtered side-chain can be transparent in some use cases and awful in others. Split band de-essers (almost always linear phase) can work better sometimes but not always. FFT based processors like DSM and Soothe are the most powerful but also often have the most potential to damage your source

author: Calvin Lauber
content: My favorite Shawn Everett trick is the “rainbow mixing” thing where he mixes each frequency area of a multiband on the master/print track. Maybe im just not smart enough to pick out some problems with all 20khtz happening at the same time but it really helps me make decisions about balancing frequencies in a more intential way (kick and bass, what does the midrange actually sound like and what’s speaking, how are the top end of the vocal and hats/acoustics interacting) etc

author: BatMeckley
content:
I just had this issue on a live Matt Maeson record. The bleed… not ideal. We were in tiny rooms. It can be jarring to the whole mix if you’re gating the vocal, because the whole band jumps in level when the vocals start.

Every situation like this is different, and requires different solutions. In my case there was a lot of multing out vocals. Treating and eq’ing different parts of the songs differently. Had a lot of luck using a very narrowly focused Soothe on the vocals sidechained to the overheads, but it takes a bit of work to figure where, how wide, and how much. When it works, it’s awesome, when it doesn’t, it’s really not.

author: WillCrann
content: Not a veteran but have mixed a lot of live band vocals in my big empty room. I’ve found that clip gaining the bleed in between each vocal phrase down like 5db can help a lot (actual number dependant on how much bleed there is of course). It’s enough tighten up the sound of the band when there’s no vocal happening, but not enough to be jarring when the vocal comes back in. And then leaning into the sound of the bleed beyond that/a lil RX de-bleed if that works, etc.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve had this once or twice. I work better one song at a time. I Get it sounding good and go listen at the gym. I like to pick a song a loop it, see what feels missing or not quite right, and make notes. Some issues go away as I listen and some present themselves. 

Mostly, I find they real sauce is in transitions and ambience choices. Like, I’ll gate a drum fill, slap a prechorus vocal, varifi a delay tail… little shit to make moments. 

If the record feels cohesive, then I find these little splashes of color can go a long way.

author: chrissorem
content: I do analog summing when I mix so  I have daw  groups that feed final daw  output groups that feed my console. Generally I try to not share fx between groups and designated fx that feed the groups. Example: vocal verb or delays outputs go to vocal group. This give an option to eq compress or saturate and melt together if intended. If I don’t want that I send the fx to their final outputs. Example: vocal verb output doesn’t go to vocal Group but to vocal output to console. This is a good workflow for making stems ect as well.

author: Rob Domos

author: ehutton21
content:
To follow up on yesterday, he removed the multiband chain. It wasn’t the OTT setting, but we confirmed that his multiband setting was boosting the high mids a fair bit, which wasn’t playing nice with the natural response of the microphone. 

I found a good solution between serious clip FX therapy, a really narrow de-esser, and some spectral shaper on the 3.5-4.5k range.

author: ehutton21
content:
Honestly I would just fuck around with it and read the manual, it’s kind of intuitive but it’s also not a process I’ve seen well defined or explained by other resources. Celemony’s site has some walk through videos but YMMV with those. 

My adhd brain enjoys the game like process melodyne brings to the  “how can I get this vocal to sound the way I want” most effectively & efficiently, which is part of why I just enjoyed diving in without too much concern. The art of knowing when to split a note, snap it, leave it, etc is something that’s just gonna take time.

I’d say that the formant tool was something I neglected for a while but it’s been a feature I’ve found subtle but defined utility for. You can help out a vocal with some formant shaping on some nasally or sharp vowels.

Oh and the “make loud notes quieter” macro is a nice lil way to augment and enhance your clip gain process.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: I seem to have got in the habit of mixing vocals quite loud and upfront. I don’t dislike this but have been listening to all sorts of records over the holidays with vocals set back a bit more and have been really enjoying it.  I really like PJ Harvey’s “Written on the forehead” as an example. It’s a vibey mix by Flood which wouldn’t really work being more upfront. I’m wondering your thoughts on this? The obvious candidates are less level, more effects but there’s a real art to that to still get the voice to cut through.  Rather than talk just of effects it would be interesting to see your philosophical takes on this. For me the louder vocal doesn’t always mean a deeper connection to the song, in fact it pushes against the song when not done well and you have two parallel plains of sound hitting you. (The band and a disconnected vocal)

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I might reframe this a little bit. I know what you're getting at re: U67/Neve/fancy room, but there's also the reality that I've mixed a bunch of vocals from those kinds of setups where the source sound *wasn't* great, sometimes not even good. I'm not sure I have all the answers here but I tend to look at the rough-sounding home studio vocals the same way I look at the fancy stuff, just at a different point on the same sliding scale.

i.e. Which aspects of the sound do I like, which do I not like, how much to change, how much to retain, which tools am I reaching for to make it work, how far can I push those tools w/o causing other harm to the source sound or the vibe of the music. And then it's kind of the same mindset for all of it, just a question of size/scope of my input, and I've found that to be a helpful way to tackle it.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content:
I would probably dip hard in that 100-130 area, and then selectively automate it back up when the vocal's down low and those low notes feel thin.

Would also play w/ polarity + phase to see if I can cancel out any of the bass bleed.

I'm not often working in situations where people want me to add new FX (e.g. the chorus/microshift stuff), but that is a cool idea.

author: chrissorem
content: I had some tasty results last night on a mix I was working on that was all recorded in the same room with quite a bit of bleed in a  pretty ambient room. I side changed trackspacer in the offending instruments to the lead vocal. In my case it was 1-3k range that was dominant from the vocal bleed. You might try doing that to the bass and using the low end 100-200hz bleed in the vocal as part of the bass sound and duck it in the bass when it’s feeling dominant

author: Marc
content:
For reference tracks — I was curious to compare two songs I love Bowie’s “Young Americans” and Springsteen “10th Avenue Freeze Out”. Similar instrumentation but the lesson for me was size and prominence of the different instruments. Bowie’s bass is way more prominent than Bruce. Bruce has the piano and guitar up front. Bowie’s has more delay and reverb. 

I think it reminds me I have to make more choices, and I also —(have to write better songs lol) — have to keep in mind when I use a reference track, that my tonal balance may be different or the vocal will sit differently if, say, my snare is way fatter/thinner than the reference track or my lead vocal is in a different octave register, which means the guitars are competing etc.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: @itaylerner i’ve had good results with Supertone Clear (used to be known as Goyo) plugin to deaden bleed on a vocal, and for more demanding cases RIPx (good because you can preview/tweak) and UVR - good separation but lacking in realtime interaction. My usual routine is printing different passes with different levels of reduction and then putting these processed takes in playlists synced to the original, this then allows me to comp between ‘reduction’ takes. I find it’s good to do this work separately to the actual mixing, or at least have a break before you mix as it can lead you down some dark alleys of bleed reduction. The passive listening Ruairi mentioned yesterday is key. It’s about controlling the bleed a bit better so that your vocal can be presented better.

author: spectrummasters
content: Re “how are folks using gullfoss “ ….im defo in cians camp 🏕️ for the main part . I agree , in some ways it seems counter intuitive to use whole spectrum dynamic eq type plug ins imho . Because , they will have a fluctuating phase relationship with the other sounds in the mix that I’m just leaving up to the plug in . This seems a bit reckless after all the cautious phase choices we would make for a mix ? However , I listened recently to a bob horn talk where he described his vocal approach is to do his vocal clean up work , in order to get out clicks , pops , harshness etc and to get out any over heavy lows or low mids  before they go to his first compressor …..but before the compressor first thing on the inserts is gullfoss in tame , no more than 10% and in this position it’s virtually imperceptible and yet does defo do a nice little thing . I tried it and have found it v subtle

author: JakeTB
content:
Here’s the long-winded human version. We’re still on this learning journey so happy for any pushback or insight

For the most part, our group felt the tradeoffs of very subtle multiband often outweigh the benefits, since just putting those crossovers in the signal makes a bigger difference than, say, a dB of control.

We felt more liberal use of multiband can add an aggression and excitement that is very familiar and unique, and prefer treating it as a sweetener or energizer over the whole mix more than trying to control problem areas that could be addressed on tracks.

In the signal chain, its position can drastically effect how other tools behave. Up front, it can help a bus compressor or saturation device behave more predictably, but may mush things too much. Near the end, it allows those devices to play a more colorful role but may cause weird behavior when using fast, “transparent” limiters afterward. I like it first right now, most of our group like it near the end.

The hallmark signs of overuse for us were mixes that sound overly strident or when a vocal becomes inconsistent tonally from section to section as density changes.

Tools-wise, the group unanimously preferred minimum phase tools over linear phase or dynamic phase. OTT is a starting point, ear training to recognize that color. Once you hear it at 15-20%, you won’t be able to unhear it on many pop records. After ingraining that color, ML4000 and C4 both have their own flavors that can do a thing while offering tweakability when needed.

author: elvis
content:
So, I’m a long-time follower of this thread, but have been to scared to post any questions as I’m afraid to look like a total dumb ass…

I’m a singer/songwriter/guitarist who has been teaching myself how to record/mix over the past few years. I don’t totally suck, but I have a long way to go.

I’m working on a mix for a client—yes that’s new for me—and I want to kill myself 🙂

Basically, it’s a big, dumb rock song (I.e. Foo Fighters), and I can’t for the life of me reign in the drums—in other words, there’s freaking cymbal bleed in EVERY mic. So, I have this situation where I tame the shitty cymbals—then get something that sounds like kick and snare samples playing along to a vacuum cleaner. Mostly because I’ve put every stinking plug-in like Soothe, multi-band compression and dynamic EQ on the overheads and rooms. Yeah! My cymbals don’t poke your ears out—but, they also sound like a Rumba.

And gating did not work as the drummer is hitting his shitty cymbals on every freaking beat! I ended up sampling a god forgive—clean snare hit and using that as a sample. It’s okay, but without being able to raise the level of the rooms and overheads, I’m kind of fucked.

I found myself referencing this Joel Hamilton production/mix of a Highly Suspect song as it’s kind of similar to what I’m working on. It’s on Puremix. He’s pretty amazing. And while the music isn’t my thing—it sounds awesome. His mix sounds big and organic—while mine sounds like an electric ham sandwich.

Without hearing the song, I don’t know how much advice I can expect. I just mostly want to vent…

I sometimes wonder if I’m the one that sucks, or is it the source material? When do you know you’ve done the best you can with what you’ve been given? You can’t polish a turd. 

And as a newbie dipshit, I’m trying so hard to make whatever I do be super awesome, badass—whatever that means. But, maybe I just need to make the rough mix sound 20% better. I don’t know.

Wow! That was long. Thanks for any advice…

author: kieronmenzies
content: It depends on what you're using it for but I use Melodyne for pitch correcting (and often timing correcting) a vocal performance so I consider it to be part of the vocal performance and thus it's the first thing to happen before anything else so that I'm just editing the raw performance. Also, I usually do the Melo thing until the performance is completely satisfactory and then commit the track before moving any further with the mix. This is because when you Melo as an insert, it lifts the audio from the source audio track and then what you see in the edit window no longer represents what's playing.

author: itaylerner
content: I HIGHLY recommend sifting through the 600+ messages. It took me maybe a couple hours? And I got as good at Melodyne in a day as I thought would take me several months.

author: Colin Althaus
content: One thing that's been super helpful for me is to assign key commands to the main tools I use in Melodyne. I have it set up so the 1 key is pitch center, 2 is pitch modulation, 3 is pitch drift, 4 is time tool, and I forget what 5 is off the top of my head haha. I always found the right-click-to-change-tool workflow super cumbersome. Having key assignments makes it a breeze. My left hand is on the keyboard changing tools and right hand is operating the mouse at all times. Not sure if something similar has been mentioned already but wanted to share as it sped up my Melodyning drastically!

author: Iwan Morgan
content: @sinaigimenez You can go very scientific with this, but first thing I would do is find a handful of your favourite tracks and play them back at a level where you feel comfortable in your room - not too loud that it hurts, but feels relatively balanced.  Then use a quick SPL Meter in C weighted mode (loads available for iphone) and see where the SPL lands when playing back these tracks.  In my room it's around 75-80 db and I'm comfortable there.  I know that when I leave my monitor controller at my predetermined setting playing back mastered -9>Lufs tracks roughly how it should sound.  if something sounds dark/bright it's usually because it is.  Like wise if a vocal is too quiet, I'm not reaching for the main volume pot to turn the overall mix up, I'm turning the vocal up until it feels right.  And also, if my mix isn’t feeling loud enough or present enough at the preset monitoring level I know I need to work harder to get it to sit in the same world as the refs.  Once you get your head around it, it’s very freeing.  I use Metric Halo Monitor controller directly connected to my speakers and control via a Stremdeck (thanks @Bryan DiMaio !) and this has 5db volume steps where I know I can mix without my limiter at +10 and when the limiter is engaged I need to be back at 0. I imagine the Hilo has something similar?

author: cian riordan
content: In an ideal world, you'd have no chain. But lets say the vocal sounds dark to your ears, then you'd add an EQ to brighten it up. Let's say the performance is wildly dynamic and has big swings in volume, then you'd be looking to solve that with some form of compression and/or volume automation. Keep solving problems until they're arent any.

author: Deleted User
content:
Jeff Ellis made a great point in his course about the difference. He says, it’s about “poignancy”. A compressor doesn’t differentiate between a word or phrase that should stand out from the others. That’s why he uses clip gain to level out stuff beforehand. 

Ofcourse you can make the point of leveling out with a compressor and then automating up poignant words or phrases. But most modern vocal recordings have to be edited anyway so why not go in and do it all there?

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: In the past I’ve used different reverbs/spaces for the different energy levels, but those productions also introduced stereo elements for the vocal (doubles, harms, gang vox) so the consistent vocal energy actually became the anchor and other things built around it. So going forward even if those things don’t exist I tend to ask myself “is this vocal energy being the same throughout actually a problem, or is it a strength that I can highlight by turning my attention to other parts of the mix instead”. The answer obviously isn’t always the same and in this case what you did sounds like a great solution.

author: cian riordan
content: Vocals it’s all about midrange grit. If it needs to be aggressive, dial in some high mids. If it needs to sound thicker and lusher, more low mids. Sometimes it’s audible as EQ, sometimes it’s noticeably distorted sometimes only when they go for it vocally…. So many options and often just surprises that I stumble across that stay in the mix.

author: chrissorem
content: I’m not sure I understand the 1st question entirely. I mix in cubase so  I almost never receive sessions in cubase format. But i usually ask for wet and dry of everything and the protools session. So in theory it should sound similar to where they left off. And I can grab dry files as I feel needed. In my case I almost always use dry  lead vocals to start.  If people are very particular. I tend to bounce blends, such as a BGV stack or string or horn stack. In particular if there is arrangement automation. I’m not trying to re do what they already like. But if it’s not working for me I’ll re do it. I have a template that has my busses routed and then I get organize and color code. Small sessions take about 15 mins to  prep and bigger sessions about 30 mins max.  If I can I prefer to prep before I plan to mix incase there are any issues with files ect. Sometimes I have an assistant doing it for me. Then I go to town

author: onanisland
content:
yeah ive had it since it came out, same with soothe1 and all similar tools, @Joel "Roomie" Berghult was right. I tend to buy plugins to save time when projects come in. 

In the order I'd range these kind of tools mentioned here:

1. soothe
2. speccraft
3. reso and all others

If you have soothe, you're good imo. 

I liked this one (speccraft) because it gave me more control when I needed to chase a more targeted frequency without affecting the rest (i.e vocals, bass gtr, etc), stuff like that, but I use these kind of tools sparingly. cymbals, egtrs cabs, things like that, almost never on the mixbus because IMHO (don't shoot me), soothe-like tools, affect too much of the signal - suppressing resonances/frequencies "killing the depth" because of the pushing down of reverbs, delays, etc. That is not to say I never use it, there are times for everything, and every tool has its place but yeah. There are people who use it that way and still get GREAT results.
As much as I want to simplify my workflow, 90% of the job is audio janitorial, I go back to simple eq, compression, fader...

I saw another comment asking about Spiff > I don't know if anybody wanted my input on that but nevertheless - I like it sometimes on drums after tape-sims where it kills too much of the transients if I need to drive it more for *reasons* but the sound is lovely (i.e country), bit of spiff after and get best of borth worlds.

author: Chris Lyon
content:
Try OTT on your instrument bus then “sidechain” after it. And by sidechain I mean shaperbox, kickstart lfotool, not traditional sidechaining. You basically create a wall of sound then add dynamics back in but fully under your control. Use the shape of the sidechain to add groove. 

Sidechain all your verbs too and even try subtle sidechaining on the vocals especially in the “drop”

author: peterlabberton
content: I currently have both a music buss and a vocal buss feeding into the main mix buss. Music has a Kush AR-1 which adds some tubey flavor, vocals get a Fairchild 670, and both only compress a couple dB at most in the loudest moments. Both also have a Kazrog True Iron before compression on the (I think?) “clean master” preset. The mix buss has a Pultec and Slate VTM, then goes to the limiter (Pro-L2). Collectively pretty much every piece of the puzzle adds a touch of saturation and I’ve been liking the collective effect—I did some actual measurement and analysis recently but I don’t think I took any screenshots. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Rob Domos
content: A lot of self exploration tbh. That and over a dozen voice teachers, a half a dozen singing courses, etc. I picked up random pieces from all over and synthesized that accumulated knowledge together as a 15 year process. TBH never once have I encountered a single system that I think does an adequate job of giving someone a complete, useful, and accurate understanding of the mechanics of the voice. Have you ever seen one book that would tell you everything needed to be a good engineer? It’s the same thing. They all fall short pretty hard, and FWIW the people who study them the most very often don’t sound that good to me.

author: Deleted User
content: I was pretty lucky, I feel that I totally hit the jackpot with my second singing teacher, who’s philosophy was based on Marifioti and a few opera teachers before him. Really it’s quite an anti-system, the philosophy being that „technique“ and analysis causes more harm than good and the basis of a healthy, happy voice is relaxing the vocal muscles as much as possible. He had learned and developed a number of exercises which facilitated that, one of which was actually a particular form of meditation where you focus on releasing tension in the vocal muscles. But I do agree, he taught me a lot, but I learned so much which was vital from other sources and am still very much learning. There doesn’t seem to be the perfect teacher or system, everybody has to discover their own path! It’s fun, though

author: Rollmottle
content:
The loudness war is by no means over and never will be lol. Fucking myth. To get mega-loudness, you definitely need to stack limiters. Couple strategies to get you there:
- Make sure your De-essing is dialed in. That should soften some of the peaks that will end up gnarly once munched through multiple limiter stages.
- I've found I can get there much easier by driving a lot of density in the analog stage.
- Parallel processing can give you extra density and perceived loudness
- De-ess again if you have to
- One chain I've found great success in is: StandardClip after the analog stage into the Weiss Maximizer then into the ProL2. That has gotten me very clean and very fucking loud masters, but that is post an analog stage that is built for high headroom to drive serious level in the analog domain.

author: Deleted User
content: In my experience, double tracking the exact same instrument - like the same guitar - will usually just end up sounding phasey, not thick and wide. You really really want it to be 2 different guitars, using a different amp or EQ just doesn’t really cut it, I find. And preferably also different amps and maybe even mics on the speakers. The more you’re actually close to something that could literally be an acoustic event(meaning it could play out that way if you were recording both parts live simultaneously), the less phasey it will be. If vocal doubles are too close to the lead sonically, for example, they can end up sounding like a phasey reverb instead of adding punch. So definitely use a different mic. Like, even Freddie Mercury‘s background vocals can sometimes sound a bit one-dimensional because of this, though of course Queen‘s performances were utterly amazing(it usually was just one u67 they tracked with)

author: Deleted User
content: Michael Jackson would step back further from the mic  on each background layer + they would usually recording the backgrounds in Blumlein while using a different mic from the lead vocal. All that made them sound pretty wide.

author: Deleted User
content: On top of everything else was said here, I think stereo width also comes from arrangement too. Thinking about which instrument will be on which side and how far, and if it something that would feel weird to pan on sides- you could utilize voice spreading to achieve width (panning each voices in the voice differently- played by slightly different instruments, you could also utilize variations of autopan and modulation effect on one note to add dimensions to things like synth pad or B3 style organ.

author: jantrit
content: A lot of the time I will mess with hard panning diff mono sources in a mix to create the sense of width whilst maintaining balance. Also if it is double tracks like others have said I like to sit them in diff places tonally or treat them differently (diff verbs or pushing diff eq points) it’s the differences in the hard panned sources that create width. When tonally different information reaches each ear at the same time your brain tells you it’s wide! When it’s only subtlety different like in the case of doubles it can end up sounding mono again. A lot of the time I like to pick two elements that are holding it down throughout the track (maybe guitar and Rhodes) and then hard pan those in opposite directions. This maintains the balance left to right.  So I guess try hard panning a mono element and then balancing it out with a totally different mono element the other side.

author: Maxim
content: Guess this depends on your philosophy. Some mixers prefer compression to EQ and that’s where it can come in handy to control a sound. I believe Serban still uses the ML4000 on his mixbus. Would be surprised if it’s doing much though. JJ same story — he really goes in with Multiband on Vocals too. Other people might just use it to tame a specific frequency range instead of EQing it. But since dynamic eqs are a thing that’s gotten less popular I guess.

author: Maxim
content: I wouldn’t use more than 2 bands on vocals anyways to avoid unnecessary crossover points. One band to control everything under say 1k and one band to control above could already give you interesting results. I would also keep the settings pretty much identical and only use a low ratio (2.1 or below). The idea is to let the compression trigger based of how the vocal performance might change in the lower and higher registers throughout the song. Of course this is pretty useful with problematic performances. But maybe not something to slap on by default.

author: Maxim
content: Yeah it’s interesting. I really wasn’t into multiband on vocals before trying it. I prefer it with the high band (B4) disabled though. So maybe there is something other than compression going on.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yeah I had a 2track, which was dense and fantastic, but made it hard to get the LV sit without killing the impact ya know? I could’ve done a some dynamic dips sidechained to the vocal in the intelligibility range to create some space. 
You can generally do that with static eq on individual instruments, but the dynamic thing helps when working with a 2track. 
Remember I FORGOT to do this cause I’m an idiot. 
Also thinking of things in m/s can help getting vocals sitting well without making them overly bright to compensate. 
Manny talks to Andrew Scheps about letting the vocal be the thing that mandates where everything else lives re: eq. IE: Instead of getting the vocals to sit in the track, get the track to work around the vocals…. All tools I have and forget to use, cause I’m an idiot.

author: ehutton21
content:
Much like what @Adam Thein said you gotta (1) lower track count (2) lower the amount of decisions that aren’t committed and (3) force yourself to check on headphones, your alt monitors, and with visualizers constantly. Treat yourself like a producer who sent you a track to mix—it doesn’t matter how messy it is, you gotta freeze everything and simplify your life. I’m working on a pop record for one of my favorites clients and before I went into mix it, we were at about 100 tracks and it nearly ate me alive until I started removing the excess that was driving me insane. For instance, all the backing vocals can probably become one track by now rather than one group, your leads can become one if they’re close enough, etc.

Make copies of previous saves, but honestly commit to your production choices, take time away from the track, and be honest with your client about the fact that you’ll need a little more time than normal due to the irregularity of mixing your own production.
