author: Slow Hand
content:
Convolution is a strange technique to describe in a way that is intuitive to understand. But here goes:

In convolution you have two audio signals, your *input signal* and your *impulse response*. The simplest description of what convolution does is that it multiplies the *input* signal by the *impulse* signal and what it spits out is a new audio signal that includes only the frequencies and amplitude values that both signals have in common.

Practically speaking, what this means is that when you convolve an *input* (let's say, a full frequency drum kit recording) with your *impulse* (let's say a 5 ms burst of white noise that was hi-passed at 500 Hz). What you end up with is a drum recording that sounds like it was hi-passed at 500 Hz.

Think of it like how a vocoder works (which isn't that different). Your vocoder might combine a full-frequency synthesizer patch (input) with the frequency contours and time content of your voice (impulse/carrier). But if your voice doesn't have 100 Hz in it then we never hear the 100 Hz from the synth patch because the input and carrier/"impulse" don't share that frequency. What you hear is what both signals have in common. If your voice has a huge peak at 1.5k, then the synth patch is going to be accentuated in that same way.

So. What I'm saying is that if I have a complex EQ curve (ala Sonarworks corrective EQ) that I use as my *impulse response* and convolve it with, say, the output of my stereo buss, will it impart that frequency curve onto my mix *without* the phase shift that you'd get from a traditional FIR or IIR filter (aka traditional EQs)?

In short, I don't know because it's hard to search for the answer online. But I'm throwing a hail mary in case we've got any DSP nerds in the forum.

author: Will Melones
content:
I usually find that if I take some time away from the mix and listen to it from beginning to end, maybe somewhat passively as @Slow Hand suggested, the level inconsistencies tend to jump out and demand attention. Works even better with a bounce and PT closed, taking notes with a pencil and paper.

Flipping between sections doesn’t do it for me, and it’s not how any listener is going to experience the flow of the song. It makes sense that Tony and Jon are so dedicated to mixing the song from the top every time.

If I’m really doubting my perspective, I’ll turn the monitors down so low I can hardly hear the song and see that I can still understand every lyric. Usually pretty easy to tell at low volumes that the vocal is getting buried in the chorus.

author: ALXCPH
content:
That is true, but I think a good mix still sounds bad in target 😅 and I’ve been in enough bars and restaurants that have playback systems that sound worse than my iPhone in a bathroom only playing out the left speaker. 

And people will still say, “omg I love this song” and start bouncing their head.

 I believe that great songs translate every and anywhere. But fidelity cannot IMO be appreciated in these specific places. 

Ofc there are exceptions. But try eating at a restaurant on a beach promenade in south Spain and the restaurant next to you has a speaker 20 inches from your head blasting a different song. And tell me you think the vocal is warm or the drums are punchy. I think, sadly for general non music fans what they find in music, is less quiteness it’s not even about the song. 

Whereas I think the people who enjoy music, will appreciate that extra punchy drum sound or warm vocal and deep bass. And I believe those people use headphones 80% of the time. They might have a great speaker system at home. But how much time do we really have at home listening to said speakers? Headphones are with us on the go all the time. Everyone I know under 30. Listens primarily on headphones. Or their iPhone speaker. Sometimes a JBL at the beach or park, and every now and then a party speaker at a party while drunk. The ones who really really love music, either have an old vintage speaker set from their parents or a Sonnos/smart speaker type thing. 

I still believe mixing for speakers is important, and @Nomograph Mastering has a great point in speakers translating to headphones easier than vice versa. But I always make sure shit sounds amazing on my AirPods. I’d rather sacrifice something in the speaker than the AirPods. But then again. I don’t have the accolades you do. So I might be shooting myself in the foot. But that is my general philosophy.

author: Will Melones
content:
Likewise, mostly de-clicking mouth sounds. You know what you’re getting 2 inches from a hot NT1000/TLM103. Actually a lot of my declicking pass is more de-plosive.

But I’ve been getting more vocal comps where it seems like an edit was made in the middle of a sustained vowel. Often it’s crossfaded and there’s no click, but I can hear the interruption in the cycle lower in the frequency range. The only solution I know of is to slice at the crossfade and line the waveforms back up with a one-crest overlap.

author: Ross Fortune
content: My philosophy here (logically and sonically, for my mixing sanity) is Waves DeEsser before any compression. So the best thing that bussing like this did for me was draw my attention to gain staging. I used to “sum” 
Basses
Guitars 
Drums
Perc
FX
Keys
BGVs
LVs

As if I was using a summing mixer, and on each bus (except drums) I used Gem Dopamine as a slight betterizer.

author: BatMeckley
content:
It’s always been: if something is crucial to the vibe of the song, say a certain echo, or dotted stereo delay guitar part, that shit gets printed and sent as an option. But the mixer also gets the rough in case they got a better way to do it. 

That’s why a mixer gets a rough bounce. So they know what to reference. 

CLA used to have a 12 page mix submission requirement thing where you had to consolidate all files, take off all fx entirely, and send him all the tracks bounced from 1 clearly labeled.

Again, it’s CRAZY to me watching a mixer pushback against having to actually mix the song. It’s like someone hiring me to vocal produce and I’m like “cool, but you have to pre record the vocals, compress them right, get the takes, comp em, mix them, and then I’ll… tickle them a little. Where’s my 5k and a point?”

author: Josh Bowman
content:
I just read through this whole thing, and keep trying to write a reply but it ends up being way tooo long.  Including this reply. Sorry for the novel.

I totally agree with you that the mixer should be able to recreate/beat the rough by rebuilding chains in a better way and not sticking to exactly what you did. . I do that routinely too especially on lead vocals, mix buss, and other important elements, drums etc. Whatever I hear could be rebuilt better, I will if I have the option/access to the unprocessed files and it needs it.

I guess I was more referring to when people take stuff off that is part of the vibe of the sound then say “do your thing, you can be creative!” and then when it isn’t identical to what they had, end up wanting me to use their thing because they heard it that way for 6 months.. ie really complex effect chains, a sound with 5 plugins stacked on it that, when removed totally changes the character of the sound, like @kylem  was saying which happens a lot with younger producers.

When you send serban sessions, even if he zero's out the EQs and redoes the dynamics, I think starting off where the producer ended still has an advantage for everyone to see how the sausage was made, then he can decide to re create the elements he wants to using a better recipe. John Hanes even wrote a post on GS about how they want the actual sessions that match the production, and if they dont get them, he will go bar by bar on an important project to match it by ear to the rough before doing the actual mix...

author: Josh Bowman
content: Ya I used to use it on mix buss at just 1-4 percent… for a little “clarity”, doesn’t happen very often anymore.. now sometimes I’ll use it on a group master if I’m stuck and wanna try something broad stroke subtly to open up a group… often with the top end range limiter pulled down a bit. Seems to help sometimes! One time it really help with fixing a boxy vocal with the range limiters pulled way in to effect a specific limited range, in a way that normal eq or doing my own dynamic eq didn’t quite do as well. Only ever worked once in that situation, but that day for whatever reason it solved the issue quickly. I think it’s like any other tool…. Some people love it some hate it. I don’t see it being any worse or better than something like soothe in principle… it’s not exactly automatic if you consciously choose the settings and frequency ranges your effecting is it? If someone is slapping it on everything at an arbitrary percentage cause they saw someone else do it, that’s another story…

author: Jodonny
content: I'm not sure if this will be helpful to anyone else, but I feel pretttttty dumb after realizing that Dessers do not compress the frequencies you're setting in the plugin. Those are just the frequencies that the trigger the sidechain, like any other compressor. At least in Pro-DS and Desser. I've heard/seen multiple big mix engineers use these plugins to "just deess the high mids" (3-5k), and never really thought about it.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
First advice is to lean into it. Sound distorted? Distort it more. Overly compressed? Compress it more. That sorta thing helps me a lot.

Second is to detune a little left to right. Hard tuned vocals on the sides tend to get phasey and lean toward the middle. A little detuning will help widen them again. 

Without hearing it none of us can actually diagnose tho right?

author: JustinLeu
content: In my experience you can open up RX-Mouth de-click, RX-de-click (I have my default to multiband mode), and an instance of pro-q3 audio-suite with a HP filter around 200hz on “A” and then flip to “B” and set it to the HP filter and a low-shelf around 800-1K subtracting -8 with the output knob set to -10. I listen to the vocal without fx, but with comp/eq somewhere around what it might be in the mix. Make a new playlist then edit clicks/pops with the RX-tools and plosives with “A” setting on pro-q. The “B” setting I described will be used to clean up breaths that have annoying frequency build up or “s” sounds that maybe not be recorded the best…I’ll change those settings to make it fit what ever I need to. This does not take long to do and sometimes I will use mouth-de click on the whole audio file with a gentle setting to start.

author: Edward Rivera
content: I'm the worst with fx. So it's pretty standard. Always have mono and stereo reverbs set up, along with mono and stereo  1/4 and 1/8 delays. And Microshift for when that's needed. Also a slap back delay and infinite reverbs but that's pretty rare. Maybe a mono spring or chamber if it's a vintage thing. And a short room if I want reverb that you don't "hear". All my delays also have sends to my vocal reverbs so they aren't so sharp sounding.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Yeah so x/y isn’t great for info on the sides for a solo performance. It’s more about capturing more of the guitar, the string chime and the body. It’s a little wider than a mono mic so it works well as a single instrument with a vocal, but it’s not gonna do a “stereo” thing. 

My best advice out the gate is keep it about 6-8” off the 10th feet and move around until the balance feels right. If you’re missing brilliance, try raising the guitar or leaning left or right a little… it’s really about your instrument and your room and which mics you’ve got. 

Honestly x/y should be an easy way of getting the full guitar captured.

author: Rob Domos
content: Voices in room do not sound like they are hitting a microphone. Think about the physics of sound for a second. High frequencies move in a laser beam shape and low frequencies move in a spherical shape. Nobody is ever turning with their ear facing 1 foot from a mouth that is laserbeaming high end into their ears. This is why you almost never hear saliva drips and lip smacking when in conversation and hear it constantly in recordings. This is also a big reason why the high end of most captures sounds so rough and edgy compared to real life. A lot of what I’m doing is going in and massaging that high end to take it from “this sounds like a mic capsule” to “this sounds like the person is in the room”

author: Adam Thein
content:
I've been here before a few times where the producer had a Soundshifter tuning up everything a weird amount (like 28 cents or something not even a semitone).  Generally I prefer the sound of shifting things separately - and at least on my system Soundshifter almost always has unpredictable and inconsistent stereo imaging artifacts so I usually prefer using other tools for as many tracks as I can do.  Most of the time since I'm working in Ableton I'll use the pitch shifting modes there (Beat warp on drums for example, tones or complex on individual harmonic instruments).

Play around with different shifting algorithms to get the results you want.  Be warned though that Soundshifter definitely has its own character/tone so if the producer/artist are really used to that sound they may wonder what happened if it goes away.  At the very least I'd try and warp your drums and vocals separately from the main instrumental if it were me!

author: Zach Hughes
content: I recently revisited a mix I initially did in 2021 for an as of yet unreleased project. A folk / rock / americana track. My OG mix had this really aggressive edge to it that I kinda liked but it also felt way too scooped in the low mids. I checked out my old session and turns out I had cranked a ton of 8khz on the mixbus (a move I haven't felt compelled to do since 2021). Related I've been really enjoying thick / dense / full bodied mixes that still have excitement / edge up top especially for vocals and I had previously struggled to achieve a similar 'heft' in my own mixes compared to what I was hearing. I think in the past I was too quick to zap low mid resonances in my vocals / guitars. So I've been experimenting cutting less down around 200hz-600hz and emphasizing more. But then I felt I was losing some of that edge / excitement by see-sawing too much with the low mids relative to up top. I've found cutting some 170hz clears much of that up for me (like oh hey there's my snare or more room for kick / bass), I achieve the thickness above in that 200-600hz range and balance that with the excitement around ~8khz. Pushing and pulling.

So my revelation has been to pay better attention to the space that the vocal needs and make sure I’m making the music fit in with the vocal. Also, for me, multiband compression (in tasteful amounts) on the mix buss has been helping both with mid range control and overall better energy.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
**The Lin/Log Thing with FFT**

So …. FFT and iFFT are a powerful thing. I’m gonna play fast and loose with technical accuracy here in an effort to make this understandable and actionable for a real record maker

At its simplest an FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) is a mathematical process that splits a signal into a bunch of slices/bands/bins (technically it’s component sine waves) which can be then acted upon or processed separately. This is *not* the same as a crossover or even a linear phase crossover, for various complicated reasons. The iFFT (Inverse Fast Fourier Transform) simply reverses this process and reconstitutes a single signal out of the many bands/slices/bins

Ok, off to a good start. It should be fairly obvious that the FFT bands in something like iZotope RX denote the number of bands a signal is split into

Now, the whole point of splitting is so that we can do interesting and useful things to the various parts of the audio spectrum. Something like Oeksound Soothe allows us to do very trick control of a signal in somewhat more powerful ways than a typical multiband. There can be downsides (time domain blurring - more later) but oftentimes they are worth the price of entry

Now, to the point of the post. The Linear/Logarithmic issue. Music/Audio is Logarithmic. What does that mean in practice? - let’s take A440, the next octave up is A880 but the next octave doubles that to 1760 Hz (not 1320 as might be expected in a linear system). There are lots of videos about the deeper differences in Lin and log, SPL is another log domain which is why we use dB (a 3dB increase is double the power in an audio signal)

author: cian riordan
content: Limiting, clipping, any sort of containment is useful at this stage. That way a big downbeat on the drums won't pull down the vocals, and vice versa. Also helps you tailor any sort of 'sweetening' type things for the program material -- ie, all of the electric guitars could use a little low mid boost and a little air up top.... but if you do that on the master, you fuck everything up. Just sort of a different way of thinking about staging your elements into the final mix bus. I find that with this method, the actual mix bus does less work and you get alot of the impact & loudness without many of the downsides.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I think it helps to redefine width as "The difference betweeen L and R." So if it's the main guitar doubled, probably keeping the spread doubles yes. But if there are two supporting synth sounds, or two electric guitar overdubs, and they're both in stereo (or both centered mono), maybe they don't need to be. And maybe cutting them down to mono, panning them opposite each other, and turning the levels up to compensate, will feel a good bit wider.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
When I first started mixing I would get lost in ultra detailed referencing. I’d get laser focused on some tracks kick sound or how a vocal was sitting and tie myself in knots.

Lately I’ll flip over to discord and read or scroll elsewhere and listen to references with more of an outer ring of awareness / not try to hone in on anything specific. Then flip back to my mix and my ears will just know better what to do. Also often what I need is less referencing and more ear breaks.

author: bobby k
content: landed there after doing a live session with this artist i absolutely love (Nolan Taylor) in a big warehouse. his vocal was incredibly dynamic, i did my thing to the close mic in mix to level out the performance, but the verb in that room was so killer that i threw up room mics and ended up not using any kind of digital verb on the mix. then been chasing that verb ever since and this is my digital solution to recreating it, when possible

author: Zach Hughes
content: All the other suggestions are dope / could be the ticket. I dig gang vocals with different distances from source. If all the tracks are an sm7 equal distance from the mic could place some of them further back with short ambience verbs. The depth slider on valhalla room is pretty handy for this. I've had good results w/o individual track compression and just handling it at the bus level. Similar to what Rob said the greater the variation in timing and pitch the more width you can get. Tradeoffs there. Could also play around with formant shifting some with melodyne or alterboy. Could also experiment with high passing some of the layers up a decent bit to create more height / contrast

author: matthewrederburg
content: Shave off the leading edge of the sound. Two tools to accomplish this are fast attack compression and transient designers. You can roll off high frequencies too. Abuse de-essers for a laugh. All of these combined with some of the additive ambience tips should get you there!

author: Adam Thein
content:
Pop in a search for re-ess to see what’s been offered on the server before but summary

1) isolate sibilants and manually edit using either special editing or clip effects
2) comping in sibilants from an unprocessed version of the vocal
3) comping in sibilants from other spots in the track that sound right
4) overdubbing your own sibilants or pulling from another track

author: masteredbyjack
content:
Honestly Matt, you should. I know you have no faults — so there’s nothing to improve — BUT after using it thousands of times it really can solve things I’ve yet to see anything else do

Now — if I was a mixer would I be blanket doing it on everything? No. But at this point I could definitely fly through a vocal and adjust a few spots very surgically (if they needed it), in a basically transparent way with almost no downside.

A few times mixers who have asked about a vocal issue have sent me a stem, I tidied up a specific word or issue, mind blown. Think “this specific word is shouty” type stuff, soothe or whatever isn’t getting it done. Tuck some upper mids  with spectral repair — maybe just at the beginning of the word — all the sudden the body comes to the fore a bit. It’s a beast in hands with taste and vision

author: masteredbyjack
content:
In your hands it would be really good I think

Listen to vocal —> “oh I don’t like that thing, maybe we redistribute the energy there” —> draw a box around the region in the spectral view and attenuate

Or “oh there’s a click” and de-click

Its honestly that simple

From my experience, the “magic” is in knowing what and where to smooth vs what to leave alone (or actually gain up or increase)

Dead simple in practice (though not easy to do effectively, easy to be a hammer looking for a nail)

author: Tristan
content: The part about the magic and knowing when to leave it alone is so key @masteredbyjack . I’m heavy duty RX user, and it can sterilize the sound when not used appropriately - my learning curve was not hearing the trade offs until about a year down the road. My favorite use is deessing drenched wet vocal stems and super gnarly clicks and hi pitched resonances in a voice. These days I’m more in the land of expecting less from it and using it in conjunction with more traditional processes. De noise is good too, that one is the hardest one to nail and very time consuming to do it musically

author: JustinLeu
content: Most of the time I will adjust mix/depth/decay time to tie two sections together. (Almost like a throw) but it can also be useful from vs to chorus. Maybe a banjo verb amount is more in the verse where it is a less dense arrangement…then at the chorus  it is slightly less wet to make it less of a mess. Also I’m a big fan of ambiance/small verbs on bgvs that need to be almost dry but punished back. I get that you are asking just about automation though. Skys the limit, be creative!

author: thegreatcarsoni
content: Brauer told a story about mixing a track that had full arrangement in right from the beginning but the song really felt like it needed to start with just acoustic and vocals to tell the story better. He went ahead and did that, pretty significant changes. But he sits down with the artist and producer on face time and says “so I changed some stuff. Here’s why, and I need you to listen to it 4 times and really consider it”. And that’s what they did, and the artist ended up going with it. But that really only worked the one time, the handful of other times he made his case the artist or producer would say (and rightfully) “I hear what you’re going for……..no”. But I love that he has the conversation about it and really insists on the idea getting its fair consideration

author: nachomaquieira
content: Besides what the guys mentioned earlier and mastering the tools so you can work 'without thinking' about them, there's also the whole thing of the 'musicality' when it comes to tuning. It’s not about getting everything to 0 cents for perfect tuning, but rather seeing what happens with the music, the chords, and what it’s interacting with. A few years ago, I realized that the most intimate, soft songs often had a slight tuning drop, while the more energetic songs, where the voice pushed forward, tended to be a bit sharper in pitch. It’s pretty crazy how just a few cents lower or higher can completely change the vibe. Lower tuning gives it a warmer, more muted color, while a few cents higher brings a different vibe, almost like it has more brightness or energy.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Definitely overcooked.
Don’t be afraid to kill all the plugins and start fresh with the knowledge now of what you don’t want to happen. The ozone exciter is often the culprit when I start to wince. 

Also, in a section like this where you’re going to really push up against the glass of the master bus, instead of pushing the brightness of the gtr have you considered temporarily dimming other elements? Sometimes I’ll put a c6 side chain on a few busses, and have it duck the them based on the feature element. Ie, often across the let’s bus or guitar bus I’ll have the vocals ducking specific harsh (or bloating) frequencies, just in certain sections of the song. Might be worth taking a look at.

author: spookydrums
content:
If you’re in the soundflow world there’s a script I found in the forums there written by Chris Shaw where I highlight a section and hit my keyboard shortcut (shift+cmd+t for me) and it will separate the region, create crossfades and highlight it, and then I just clip gain up and down with shift+ctrl and the up and down arrows. Such a quick workflow. I also love gainstaging into compression a lot of the time rather than doing it post compression. 

And then there is this other soundflow version of back and play that I hit (ctrl+space bar) where it backs up two seconds and play from there. Amazing for automating vocals.

author: spectrummasters
content:
I fully agree with Josh about perhaps it’s not meant to sound how you had hoped . 

Hang tough man ! You’ll get there . 
I’m sure others will chime in with greater tips but fwiw 

I had a moment like this with a band project a while back . I thought what I’d been given wasn’t good enough to get what I wanted . The turning point for me was realising I had started mixing the songs before I knew the parts , the nuance and strengths and weakness of the performances of those parts and the arrangements of them intimately . I didn’t know all the vocalists lyrics or know the parts of their vocal range that distorted and those that sat perfectly . I realised I was effectively driving a car with my eyes shut . 
My best offer would be : make sure you know everything inside out , and then mix again from scratch …and with old school good balances and fader rides I bet you can bring it to life . 

In knowing every aspect of the performances I was able to anticipate the parts and really bring the interplay of the band to life in the mix properly . Kinda felt that was the key that unlocked the potential that I’d not found before 

Good luck 👍

author: Aric.Edward
content: Hey guys! thought I might ask this here. I am mixing a rock track right now. I was looking into what Michael Brauer does with sending the vocals to multiple different parallel compressors and blending the character of each different compressor into the vocal... do any of you guys do anything like this? and do any of you all have some cool suggestions as far as which compressors might work for this and what kind of character they add to a vocal in parallel?

author: JustinLeu
content:
Keep it as simple as you can = )

Try doing the para processing from 1 send off of the main vocal and then blending the "dry" signal (original) with the wet signal at a vocal bus...

Para sends to try:
1. CLA76 or VU-comp or similar 1176 slamming away 
2. Distortion....so many options but you can try **Decapitator **(there are some great presets for gritty vocals....then just run them 100% wet since it is a send)  or the protools sans-amp

So routing will be:

Original vocal (dialed to roughly fit the track) with a SEND TO:
Para 1 (heavy comp)
Para 2 (disortion)
Bus all those tracks to:
Vocal bus...and on this treat the group as you need (comp,eq,limit,de-ess etc)

author: Aric.Edward

author: cian riordan
content: I tend to be more of a compressor in sequence guy rather than a in-parallel guy, but there’s really no right answer. My chain usually consists of a character compressor (something doing the heavy lifting tonally), then a utility compressor to level things out a bit more (rvox or an ssl channel) then I’ll bus that and all the lead vocal specific effects into a glue compressor to bind them all together — often unfairchild or SSL bus style. I know the formula well so I can gain stage things quickly and audition a few different things in each position to get the lead right where I want it.

author: bobby k
content:
It’s not gonna be for every voice, but the two cases I’ve found it great in the past week are these:
-pushy dynamic male rock vocal (think kings of Leon) that’s needing a heavy dose of saturation
-soft bright female pop vocal on an SM7b that just has way too much dynamic and information in that articulation range. 

I like Rob’s comment about time domain a lot. I also want density in that region, which my other option becomes controlled compression + spectre or Saturn2. KCLIP just does a thing that seems to work.

author: BatMeckley
content: I mean just years and years of getting sent two tracks to cut vocals to, using tab to transient, and then it makes the track just ever so slightly early (because people’s programmed drums are rarely with the detectable transient on the grid, usually due to the way samples are put together). So, everything you now cut in this new session, when you send it back to them is a little bit early. (The hip hop kids had a word for it) It just loses the pocket. Once I started doing the square wave trick that all just went away.

author: Maxim
content:
I mean without music in context there's not a ton to say. And even if you managed to get the room out of the vocal (which with plugins like RX 8/9, C-VOX, SPL De-Verb, etc. is still not great) I doubt you'd be left with much that's "nice" to work with. 

But nevertheless, after doing some processing with the usual tools (best mentioned above - look into the new Dialog Isolate from RX 9) my intuition would be to eq the lower mids/lows first in the context of the music to get rid of the room "mud". 

Then maybe (lightly) slap some Soothe or Gullfoss on there to see what that does. Then once you've possibly got something to work with, go through the usual steps you might process a vocal with  (more additive/tone-shaping tools to get a sound).

Thing is, if you don't have all these plugins already it would be much cheaper to just record a better vocal. (I think you can demo them all though?) Maybe even consider renting a studio for a day (if the artist has the budget).

author: cian riordan
content: Haha honestly acoustic piano (grand pianos especially) are just a midrange nightmare and are so dynamic that there's no broad stroke rules I can give off the top of my head. If it's a dense composition, I love using something like Trackspacer to send a vocal signal to the piano, and have it dynamically tame that particular area. Then the piano sounds big and full when noone is singing.

author: rse
content:
This is really valuable! Thanks a lot. To go into some of your questions; I'm using Adam a7's (not the newer a7x's, although I tested them and they're wasn't as much of a difference as I had expected in my room). My room has been treated with diy panels, 14cm thick Rockwool and it sounds decent for a home recording studio. the dimensions aren't great and low lend monitoring isn't top of the charts but it's workable. Any peaks and valleys i did have have been sorted out further as much as possible with sonarworks which has really outdone my expectations. I also use Beyerdynamics dt770 pro's. 
Usually a lot of time does actually go into clip gaining, cleaning up and taking harshness out of vocals. I often take as much time just manually leveling a vocal, taking out esses etc as I do mixing. Fresh air and dopamine have indeed been big helpers and have been big steps towards that sizzle. Also the waves exciter in parallel has been working okay.
I never seem to be able to get a multiband compressor to work well. Either I'm overdoing some of the setting or something because often i feel like it attenuates too much and other times to little in the places I want it to. I've noticed that a little boost in the low mids on pro-q3 that then also attenuates dynamically can work. 
Could you go into a bit more detail on what you mean with phase bringing a vocal more forward?
I've also noticed that a lot of the sound I'm looking for comes from a certain sort of rolling kind of sound that might be coming from the rappers throat? I'm not sure at all about this but it seems like it's almost vocal fry but in a very natural way that is inherent to the singers/rappers voice. Idk if this is a rapping technique thing or if this is more accentuated in the mixing process, but it sounds really nice.
Definitely a big thankyou for all the tips!

author: Slow Hand
content: It sounds like your 808 is hitting your limiter too hard. Because the limiter has to turn down the entire mix each time that it hits the threshold, all of the music and vocals are being reduced in volume, or "ducked", while the 808 is playing.

author: itaylerner
content: I feel all of this as well, super eager to hear what other people’s thoughts are! What I’ve landed on is creating an aux with the verb / space that I want the mix to exist in, and then I carefully dial in what’s getting sent there. So each individual group aux (drums, music, vocals, low end) will each have a send to their own aux where they get some eq, mostly just filtering, and then they get sent from there to the “global verb.” Hope that makes sense haha. That’s been the most effective way for me to get those natural sounding reflections that make it feel alive without adding the business I get from just slapping a verb on the master.

author: spectrummasters
spectrummasters
content:
i hear ya , re: 808 through a neve pre-amp, spot on agree with you. thats exactly what i do ....defo the sauce  ! lol. I sum OTB and send my drums , vox , fx and music buses through my ssl sixes (no transformers, no phase shifting , lovely SSL punch and transient response) and then bass through the 73 and into the SSL on an insert return bypassing their pre....I came by that one from an old Jaycen Joshua tip ! 

I also find i use the neves transformers if ive got a phase issue between two parrallels, if i send one through the neve it can often shift the phase in one a bit and they blend better when they sum back after. This realisation led me into learning about phase rotation and all pass filters this year......im still deep diving phase since christmas lol 

I’d defo recommend SSl X-phase plug in to anyone ITB 

What you say about tape is interesting to me because.....

i wonder if the "to tape sound" will soon be a thing of the past even as an  aesthetic.....the artists in my genre, here in london and i know its the same in the states......their new forward looking aesthetic is this ruined/ultra smashed/clipped 808 , hi-passed percussion , serum synths and a  filtered vocal sound....ts like distorted nintendo on acid .....lol i actually like doing tracks like that for the madness of it....but magnetic flux and tape hysterisis are a v distant memory at that point me thinks......

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There’s no wrong way to eat a Reese’s. It all depends on what you’re trying to accomplish! But think of using PP auxes like a Mix Knob. 

As far as vocals, there’s all kinds of ways to do this. I often take a tuned vocal, set the output to a bus that feeds 2 separate auxes with dif types of compression, and then bus both of those back into a single Aux which I treat as if it were the originally recorded vocal track. 

I use spitty 1176 type comp on one and a smoother VariMu type comp on the other, then eq any unwanted resonances and de ess before sending them to the final Aux.

author: Zack Hames
content:
My day job is post production.  Usually post studios have WAY less mic preamps, microphones, etc. Smaller spaces. More seating, TV screens for clients to watch, ISDN / Source Connect patching capabilities for Voice Over Recording.  Way way less outboard.  Another big thing is Soundminer, an application used for SFX file implementation/organization. Very handy. 

a large TV screen, Soundminer, certain plugins (Nugen VisLim), 5.1 mixing capabilities, Source Connect connection, are probably the *biggest* things that a recording studio might not have. It's more that they're just way stripped down in comparison to music studios. 

As far as design, they're just usually really simple, clean, it's more meant for corporate clients and less for "vibing out" with musicians. It's a very different feeling world. I have no idea if this answers your question, but a recording studio should be able to do almost anything you'd need for post production, it's more about convenience when clients/creatives are in the room.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I love this topic. Great question @chloe corley! 
All the ideas here are things that have worked for me, esp on the tracking side.
But I do you wideners too. Ozone Imager works really well for me on sources that are already stereo. 
Also, something that really helps me, is using fx to widen. Taking a stereo delay and using it in Multi-Mono (this also works with eq,) and plugs like Primal Tap and Crystalizer. 
Last year I went deep into the stereo field, and the biggest thing i learned is that the only things in the middle should be kik snr bass & vocals, then everything else on the sides!

author: rse
content:
From my experience; 1. re-record 2. try to get it out with whatever you have, Rx, spl de-verb, waves ns1 and clarity vx, whatever tools you can think of. 3. Since it's REALLLLLY verby, just run with it. If it's impossible to rerecord or to polish it up with any tools you have, it's best to just go with that sound imo. It won't be amazing, but sometimes it just be like that. 4. Talk to the artist. Tell them straight up what's going on and give them the decision between rerecording and a mediocre vocal sound

Edit: use as little compression as possible, you don't want to be bringing out all that nasty verb even more

author: Brodie Stewart
content:
I’ve been dealing with this today, but the vocalist has extremely bright/sibilant/harsh strident capsule resonances popping up in different places like 5k, 7k, 10k etc. Sometimes the tightest q cuts worked at the pin-like resonances piercing through, other times a literal notch provided the smoothest results. I was trying Soothe for anything above 5kHz and sometimes it worked and sometimes it didn’t.

Different sections and phrases had different capsule resonances, like the tube in the mic was fluctuating based on temperature/humidity causing all sorts of nasties. I ended up using Audiosuite on the odd phrase here or there and manually cutting the resonances with a tight Q or notch (in addition to what was on the channel).

author: ehutton21
content:
To @ALXCPH’s point, I think it’s important to understand that hyper pop is all over the map and the kids making it usually started in their bedrooms and because they grew up in such a widespread era in the early 2000s & 2010s, hyper pop can really sound like *anything*. It can be beautiful guitar ballads with lots of stacks, or it can be insane berzerk bass with crazy vocal effects. Brevin Kim is a duo that embody that balance very well. 

In the way it’s create, hyperpop borrows from and feels reminiscent of the punk days because of how connected it is to modern cultural movements (hyper pop is deeply tied to LGBTQ+ culture), so many of these kids don’t care about things like if the master redlines or there’s masking—if that’s what gets their energy across, they’ll want that in the mix.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
Totally agree. Its why hyperpop is one of the most fun genres to be part of nowadays.

 I've listened to enough records now where distortion is cool and hahaha i have to always stop myself from clipping the master MORE than the demo. But its things in the rough, like vocals with a TON of reverb, uncompressed vocals, masking, and especially this one, weak-ish drums,  that I have a hard time leaning into.

author: ehutton21
content: Heavier room reverb with less of a traditional pop feel (ie shorter and more ambient, and generally less tail and predelay) are good for vocals. For drums, gain stage louder than you think you will. Snare and kick on big productions  will be louder than your vocals most of the time, and with hyper pop that’s true as hell too. I personally clip to get “faux”loudness in hyper pop, I try and clip if the distortion is pleasing.

author: ehutton21
content: De esser on hi hats with top end pump is a crucial tip for making hi hats sound crazier while also removing the vibe of them. Keeps them out of vocals too. Hi hats are a place where i side chain on hyper pop cause of how much clients want saturation of top end these days

author: BillyC
content: I just import some VCAs, FX returns, mix bus, and print track. All other routing is only done as needed, because routing decisions are really about processing. And those decisions are hard to make until I’ve heard the song and can see what stems I have to work from. I’ve just gotten too many sessions from people where there is so much bussing and subgrouping going on that by the time the vocal gets to the mix bus, it is passed through 3 instances off gullfoss and 4 different compressors and there is zero life in it. It quickly gets out of control. I actually find minimal bussing to be a quicker workflow because I don’t have to follow a whole series of subgroups to know the entire processing chain on a given audio source when I’m trying to make a tweak, nor will that tweak affect any other element that is sitting just fine. That’s just my brain though.

author: Will Melones
content:
I’m starting to believe I’m not as good at treating vocals as I thought I was. Usually the stuff I get to mix is recorded in a bedroom or worse on a cheap condenser mic, and I’ll do what I can to polish the turd, but at some point it’s as good as it can get.

But then I listen to some of the previous releases some of these artists have, and I wonder if the folks who mixed those songs had to work with the same quality raw material. The stuff sounds pro in the end (sometimes).

It seems like this is more and more the way things will be for good. It’s rare that someone is singing into a decent mic and pre in a treated room (studio!?) or that they bother with mic technique.

Does anyone have tips or resources related to *really* digging into the repair of things like wonky room resonances, harsh-ass mics, inconsistent distance, and sometimes no talent? It seems like the folks working in that next level up can wave a magic wand and turn an NT1A into a 251 without harshness or dullness.

I always thought vocal recording was pretty clear cut. I guess I spoiled myself because all of the stuff I mixed early on I had recorded myself, and my only real ‘vocal’ mic was an RE20.

author: Will Melones
content:
Sorry, the real question: 
In 2022 are bad vocal recordings doomed to sound bad forever?

author: ehutton21
content:
Ahhh I see you’ve met my people—the bedroom artist! 

Jokes aside, I got into engineering because me and my friend could not afford to have someone decent mix our stuff, so I know the NT1A to 251 struggle well—he records exclusively on an NT1A. 

The biggest thing about working with bedroom-y vocals is they’re going to have their shortcomings, and maybe more so than most other mixes, you can process them quite a bit and you should. Do whatever RX work you need to do, and do that first. I don’t usually worry about playing the vocals with the track at this point, im just hunting for any pops, clicks, clips or room artifacts. 

Next for me is reamping—this may be odd to some people and their may not be a general consensus on how much it helps, but it gives me a sense of tonal consistency when I can set how I want the vocal to drive. If you have something that feels like how you would have tried to record it, it helps the psychological aspect IMO.

author: ehutton21
content: With poor mic technique from singers, I like to process each take on a consistency basis. I’m usually grouping lines based on consistency—if one take sounds wildly off from a group of others, I’ll put it on its own track and bring out the best of its world (and I’ll try to make that a moment where there’s a deliberate event with effects) so that way I’m not having to agonize over handling events like a change in proximity to the mic when they went to punch in. That’s going to save you some automation headaches, even if it means you have to do maybe more freezing down the line

author: ehutton21
content: I have my vintech patched in to my I/O as like insert 3. Set a vocal preamp like it’s going to line, right, and you’re pretty much getting what you have ITB and running it through your transformers like you would if you had been there with the preamp. I’ve tried to read into this and the most I got was a GS thread about whether or not it degrades audio quality, and whatever I lose by running it through my preamp and distressor, I make up for in comfort and tonal familiarity. It won’t be a silver bullet but it’ll give you a blanket of “oh yeah ok I have this sound, that’s my transformer, I can work with that” and it isn’t necessarily a radical move like distortion

author: Jeremy Klein
content: what are the pros/cons of high passing a vocal (90hz ish) before a compressor? I've always done it without ever considering if there are any merits _not_ to do it.

author: Jeremy Klein
content: dope, thanks for that! i constantly want more low end thickness in my vocals without them being woofy, and started to wonder if that was causing them to be thinner than i wanted.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
High passing the vocals right below the fundamental shouldn’t kill any low end thickness- if anything it’ll give you a little hump there. 

There are a lot of compressors that add low end resonance, some more musical than others. UAD 175-B and Fairchild do really well with that for my taste. 

Bottom without woof and top without sibilance are what make your vocals sound pro, and there’s no one way to skin that cat properly.

author: Jeremy Klein

What sources are you all reaching for an 1176 when mixing specifically with the higher ratios?

author: hank01564
content: I’ve had to deal with similar situations- not sure if it’s some terrible Waves YouTuber vocal chain preset going around but I’ve gotten good results using RX9 De-Click and Mouth DeClick. Sometimes if those transients are crazy enough, RX will register them as clicks and smooth them with one render

author: NoahNeedleman
content: Settings change per source for me- but I generally reach for it when I’m looking for a real snappy electric or spitty vocal. I’m pretty partial to the UAD 1176 over CLA or BF, but I love the UAD 176 and 175-b when I’m looking for extra sauce… the more you drive those the better they sound, and it’s hard to make it too pumpy, whereas the 1176 it’s hard to make it *not* pumpy. That’s just me though. I’ve been accused of not going hard enough more than I have of going too hard, so keep that in mind.

author: BatMeckley
content: Also, because what else am I doing right now, I’ll tell you a real fun tip about 1176’s: they tend to have a real magic sweet spot, much like the way a good guitarist sets their amp for just the edge of breakup. The track comes alive with harmonics without being “woah that’s distorted”, and I’ve always viewed them more for that effect rather than just a “gain controller”If you have your own 1176 that you can really spend time with, you can figure out just where in the needle that magic happens. THEN you can use something ultra transparent and awesome like a Dave Hills titan to control dynamic on the way in and really increase your chances of keeping the vocal right in the magic spot without risking overs. 🪄 You can do it with a studio’s 1176, you just have to figure out the sweet spot before the artist gets there and be willing to adjust on the fly

author: BatMeckley
content: Both! The ratios all sound pretty different to me. Often times I’ll hit the 8 or 12 cause they sound leaner and you. Do. Not. Need. As. Much. Low. End. In. Your. Vocal. As. You. Think.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
whats the deal with reverb on vocals? Like if you are trying to get a modern upfront vocal, 99% of the time to me, it seems to make it worse and a delay sounds better. 

But vocals i get from producers who know what they are doing all have reverb. Am i just missing something?

author: sukhuno
content: It’s for a bunch of reasons: easy to cover up a unconfident mediocre vocal with reverb, bad monitoring so can’t hear reverb at low levels/short decays, it hides mistakes, being super wet is trendy nowadays, etc.

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
That makes total sense. Like producers are just putting reverb on every vocalist to make them feel more confident in the room.

 And yeah im not talking about like tame impala effect reverb. Im just talking about 10% wet valhalla reverb as a default on a pop vocal.

author: sukhuno
content: It’s used as a handicap nowadays honestly, if the vocal is shite - the easier thing to do is put more verb on it rather than cutting it again or becoming a better singer

author: Jeremy Klein
content:
as a mixer id way rather have a guitar washed in delay than reverb. 

But on instruments i dont even mind reverb _as much_. its really just vocals that make it, (to me), so difficult to get the upfrontness i want when the lead vocal has reverb on it.

author: itaylerner
content: Any Melodyne wizards have good tips for smoothing out the glide between notes? This one spot in this vocal is killing me, there’s a little gloddle blip instead of a smooth slide up into a note and pitch drift / modulation is not doin it for me

author: Deleted User
content:
pitch drift is fixes the overall picture of pitch deviation and stabilizes it if there’s a spot where the singer didn’t take enough breath and the note kind of wanders around in pitch. modulation just changes the amount of pitch deviation. 

the problem you described usually occurs to me when I have to fix the notes quite a bit, and the pitch between the connecting notes have to spread apart a fair bit. That’s when dividing it up and moving the blobs to draw in smooth transition between the notes help. Attack time is what I use if I need further smoothing between those divided blobs

author: Adam Thein
content:
I’ve always had issues with this feature ever since it launched with 5.0 - I’m still manually turning off sibilant detection everytime I load anything in Melodyne because if you do any sort of timing around sibilants there’s a small chance it becomes phasey with the crossfade of the sibilant in an unpredictable way.  I emailed Celemony the day 5.0 came out noting the issue and never had anything come out about what the diagnosis was for the issue and they haven’t ever followed up as far as I know (been reading the release notes since then to see if they’ve addressed it).  I really really wish they’d add a way to turn sibilant detection off for the melodic detection algorithm though!

Maybe it’s just me but it’s happened to me on both mac and PC in both stand-alone and plugin versions.

content: damn. that is a lot of work but also not, considering the fact that the sibilance need to be clip gained. It may actually be a faster workaround hmm 🤔

author: spectrummasters
content: I can relate to this . I think first impression notes are a great tool and I’m challenging myself to “do less “ not more to roughs:demos . Often times when I’m tracking vocals it is to a two track (rnb/hip-hop) and I’ve learnt that just about any “vocal sound “ I want to go for I better get it whilst we are tracking because the artists always want a rough vocal mix to go away with at end of session . Invariably , whatever that rough sounds like I can’t stray away from (for good or bad ) once they’ve heard it . And then when it comes to a final mix , it gets even more complicated getting the actual stems for the two track and mixing it all down with the vocal tracks as it often (imo) sounds better but doesn’t feel the same as that on the day rough vocal mix to the two track . I realised there’s no way I can get an artist to unhear that first  rough mix and I’m wasting hours mixing it all over again with the stems , like I’m re inventing a wheel no one wants . I’ve noticed @Bainz_  telling @oaklandmatt he had the same issues with thugs punk album and also have heard Jason Goldberg and Stuart white embracing the idea that you’re possibly mixing the final mix/pre master as you track . It’s a very raw and quick approach and it does keep you miles away from overmixing something . I embraced it as a workflow only recently and it’s less stressful than working your ass off on a “perfect” mix only to get back they prefer the vibe of the first day mix .   top tips not to overmix I am meditating on currently are : don’t lose your dynamics , watch your phase relationships don’t change , leave some mistakes in , automate more than compress and be quick

author: peterlabberton
content: I think it’s really important to be reactive and intuitive—the flow state you’re referring to, @JakeTB—as a default. I feel like when I’m at my best, I’m not analytical until I can step away. Then maybe after an hour or two or even a day, I’ll listen and perhaps write some notes, then go and address them efficiently, and print. Usually then I’m done. I will say I disagree with @Nomograph Mastering on references. I think it’s SO easy to become acclimated to the thing you’ve been listening to for 4-8 hours that a quick perusal of some familiar music is a great reset. Should you be trying to match the kick sound or vocal tone? Fuck no. But it’s a great re-frame IMO.

author: Ross Fortune
content: Just discovered the pinned messages and saw this - one alt step I use (in Pro Tools, using AutoTune Pro but same should apply) instead is to arm the instances to scan, but instead of freeze or commit, I right click the relevant channels and use the Bounce option and generate mp3s at a location on my HD (I clean it out every now and then). This way you don't have a 50MB WAV added to the session each time you need to scan. Come to think of it, I don't know how DAWs handle freeze files once unfrozen, but this way I know exactly what's happening and where.

author: Adam Thein
content: Gonna throw my data point in here - I'm definitely still learning a ton and trying to get faster but I'm typically working with small indie artists of a wide variety of skill levels and that can make my work vary pretty wildly between being able to knock out a mix in a few hours (probably 3-4 on the short end) and many days of editing, vocal work, additional production, and mixing.  On average I'm probably around the 8-12 hours actively mixing mark and editing can sometimes be an additional day or two per track especially if it's a heavily layered track.  It really depends on what comes in.  I've only been at it full time for about 3 years so I'm hoping I can get a little more confident in my moves over time as my monitoring improves and my ears get more refined but there's still a lot of work for me that goes into getting things to feel right.

author: Tyler Graham
content: Question: What are specific mix decisions that will alter the perceived timing of a vocal? My PDC is fine - i think - on pro tools but after finishing a mix it seems the pocket has been altered (vocals slightly late). Maybe the rough was just muddier and the pocket was kind of obscured?

author: samvalentine
content: My first guess would be the mix has a different verb size (maybe predelay) or delay speed than the rough. Even subtle changes to time-based effects can alter the pocket of a vocal. Compression attack time could also be a culprit. Definitely not unusual to impart subtle pocket changes if you’re doing some heavily lifting in the mix. Don’t be afraid to nudge the whole vocal a bit to solidify the pocket.

author: Tyler Graham
content: All of my vocals are routed identically (give or take a couple effects plugins here and there on individual takes). But upon dragging the printed Acapella bus up to the original vocal takes, and re-aligning the first couple transients on the hook, they're in sync for the first couple bars, and gradually fall out of line. This is what's blowing my mind - even visually comparing the printed ACA bus and the original vocal takes - the shifting is both rushing and lagging in different areas.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Are the vocals running through Melodyne or other tuning plugins?

You can get into some squirrely situations with tuning, especially if you place Melodyne in the chain later than insert 1.

I have experienced Melodyne slightly shifting timing over time. At least when using the plug-in version. It’s usually not a massive shift, but it could mess with the “pocket.”

author: chadwahlbrink
content: Also, I haven't really tested how ARA Melodyne stacks up

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
Yes! This is true. The weirder thing is that the prints wouldn’t phase cancel if you started the commit at bar 20 instead of bar 1 in the session 🙃. They started to drift over time.

According to Melodyne support, that was an “expected” discrepancy (that first question in those screenshots).

But yes, even with ARA, get the audio printed to static WAV files before moving on.

author: chadwahlbrink
content: Although, I’ll admit, I mainly use ARA melodyne these days. I should do another nitty gritty test on accuracy for that mode of work, but it also has felt good to my ear so far, so I haven’t bothered.

author: chadwahlbrink
content: But using the melodyne plugin anywhere but insert 1 can really f you up… I got into trouble when I tried putting a natural phase fabfilter hpf before melodyne on a project once… the delay comp got screwy. Bad news.

author: ALXCPH
content: You also do your timing in melodyne? I’ve always been curious about that, would love get your perspective on it. I always time it, then bounce a timed version, then pitch in melodyne

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Nice. I’ve done a similar thing with an AT graphic followed by EFX3, with the graphic just serving that purpose when EFX doesn’t know which note to push to.

Functionally, the emphasising consonants etc gets done in clip gain (AT graphic doesn’t actually capture the audio like melodyne and allows you to edit clip gain - you can even get away with small timing adjustments to the clips and sometimes swapping in different takes). Whenever I have significant timing stuff to do, AT graphic pitch and time mode does a very good job with that. Excellent time stretching, at least on vocals where I’ve tried it.

Hearing all of this though, I’m v keen to try Melodyne now with the new implementation

author: Adam Thein

I was gonna say the least transparent tool for me usually is de-plosive - and like @Nomograph Mastering just mentioned the spectral repair tool (or even making a selection and using gain) can get you there quicker.

I tend not to do anything in RX across the entire file, usually only jumping in when I hear an issue within the context of the mix, note the time stamp, make the edit, save as an "RX" version of the file and splice in the section I repaired

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So I got into this when tryn figured out how to get depth in a mix. (This was after gainstaging, top and bottom, wideness, but before loudness and also im still learning all of it.) 
From a purely EQ perspective, our ears perceive brighter things as closer and darker things as farther away. See what happens when you darken the vocal a little, chances are it’ll move back in your mix real fast. 

Also, DVerb ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

author: Slow Hand
content:
I tried out the demo and was kind of put off by how severe the EQ sculpting is. It’s voiced very very bright. Maybe that’s the sauce in pop mixes, but it felt extreme to me. I found myself having to turn up the low shelf a lot to account for how bright it is.

The level rider seemed pretty good. And the compressor gets pumpy quick, but it was alright in small doses.

The doubler felt great and the two verb options sounded excellent, but I could see them being limited because they only have a dry/wet control.

Overall I like that it can act as an instant-vibe plugin for when you want to move quickly through a session. It’s got zero latency, which is great and seemed very light on CPU. But it’s not a fit for every style. Seemingly just for big pop stuff.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Many hands make light work! 
That tracks with my experience anyway. 

I usually find myself eq’ing multiple times in a chain- after each comp or saturator adds desired things, I often have a ProQ3 to de emphasize some of the unwanted things- adding in a couple db of dynamic dipping around the sibilance each time is really helpful! 

If at the end the esses are still an issue that’s when I break out audiosuite, but sounds like I need to dig into RX more. I loved it for killing mouth noise, but after I upgraded my OS & Protools Izotope plugs started crashing me, so I’ve moved away for long enough that it feels foreign again. 

As Jon Kaplan always says to me “work harder, dummy.”

author: Deleted User
content:
I’m ruling out the performance since you said it is smooth- but great bass guitar performance often don’t need much clip gain because good players know how to adjust their touch to the acoustic properties of the instrument.

Sometimes it’s arrangement, when instruments are playing notes that aren’t really meaningful to the arrangement then it won’t cut through the mix. Or if the other instruments are doing things that aren’t meaningful to the arrangement, it can get contribute to bass notes getting lost as well. 
Try muting other stuff one at a time until you can hear the bass well, and evaluate why the bass isn’t cutting through. 

Sometimes, you just gotta zoom out and mute the bass and mix the song without the bass and put it in. Before you do this, save as and solo vocals (if there is any) bass and drums (sometimes one other most important/prominent element in the arrangement on top of that) and make that work first. You can get it to a point of making the mix work this way if there is one element that just doesn’t sit well in the mix.

author: ALXCPH
content: i think the point of the chain is that if everybody focuses solely on their craft, and let the next person worry about their job, that way you get less artistic compromises through out the process. You wouldn't ever want a singer to want to only sing in one specific octave because it gives the song a higher LUFS measurement. Lets the mixer and and ME worry about loudness, and let the singer be creative and sing what they feel, how they feel they can create the biggest connection. I Think its the same with a mix engineer, let them mix it to their best ability and creativness, and let the ME worry about the last QC, before sending it out to the people.

author: XLII
content:
I’m of the same opinion. I myself also make a lot of dance music whilst also doing a lot of production work as my main job and it’s a completely different process.
I think for dance music / electronic music, many people have omitted the concept of mastering altogether. I think the bulk of the process is already done in production and they have the sound dialled in exactly as they like and are only looking for gain / desired LUFS. I also often do that for my dance music stuff.
Whereas production for vocalists, there’s the pre-pro, pro, recording, mixing and mastering all as separate processes.
I find it really interesting personally. So many ways and methods.

P.S. I often wondered why some tracks would just clip like crazy in my dj sets. Now I know. Haha

When you send a clip to RX from PT via RX Connect, it sends the raw audio file of the clip. So I want to monitor what RX is doing through my entire vocal chain and mix bus, as this will absolutely determine how much I should be doing.

So RX Monitor is the very first plugin in the chain.

author: ehutton21
content: I push into the VU comp on an aux with a post comp high end boost. Rev F, Mix 100%, w/ aux gain to taste. It’ll do that nice parallel 1176 thing but with some shimmer that makes the top end feel natural and adds grit in a very smooth way, for me. That + I’ll use it as the main ITB compressor on my signal chain if I want a pop vocal to feel really tight without killing all of the transients

Accentuating lows brings up the muddy breath noises from proximity effect
Saturation and compression both lower the dynamic range between harmonic to breath further

author: Deleted User
content:
I find that delays can take some aggresive EQs depending on the style. Give a wild boost on area where I want the delay to cut through and turn the overall delay down - and then compress it a little bit to duck it. 

At least for reverb- I find it’s not always necessarily to have a dry signal keying the compressor to duck the reverb.  Sometimes just a compressor directly on the channel will do something similar and less dramatic than ducking if that’s what is needed for the song, 

Also I find faders very helpful in automating effects. Because I don’t always want them to duck in the same shape or ducking is something I’d do to change the nature of the tail and will still need some additional shaping to give specialness to different moments.

For vocals I like copying the audio track and make separate fx tracks because I only want it on certain words. Even for overall effect, I use a separate track so I can take out certain words from reverb or clip gain them. Or even fade in words when I don’t want the early part of reverb poking out too much in certain parts.

author: joaomartins
content: 100%!! we’re not here to serve our egos but to serve the song and sometimes what we think is better for the track it’s not what it’s asking for. If the track doesn’t need a certain “signature” I’m not gonna do it just to justify having my name as credit for mixing. One might like big drums, bright vocals, big low end, etc. but if the song doesn’t ask for it why do it just for the sake of it? I find I connect wayyy better emotionally to mixes that are serving the song and the characteristics of it rather than the perfectly balanced and polished mix in theory. Sometimes we have to do a lot of heavy lifting and that’s cool too, but if the record just asks for the last 5% so be it. If I got a track from Jack Antonoff or Blake Slatkin I imagine they’re not looking to have their shit reimagined

author: Zack Hames
content:
Bass - None (black)
Drums - Green
Guitars - Red, Orange, Yellow (if multiple guitarist / parts)
Keys/synths - blues
Vocals - pink

author: stefanmacc
content:
Master 
Bus to master 
Vca for bus master parallels below
6 or so mstr bus aux parallels
Vca for 3 main grp busses below 
Vox main bus aux 
Music main bus aux 
Parallels main bus aux
40 - 60 various aux busses for parallel 

Then

Vocals pink 
Bax light purple 
Drums dark green
Perc light green
Bass or subs blue or dark blue
Gtrs red 
Acoustic yellow 
Horns orange 
Piano or Strings or synths dark purple

author: Deleted User
content: For me bass is part of drums so they’re together and then vocals. Sometimes vocals first

author: jantrit
content:
Drums - dark red 
Bass - blue
Sub bass - dark blue
Piano - blue
Keys like rhodes - light blue
Synths and organ - turquoise 
Guitars  - green
Strings - green for violins/ violas and then blue as you get to cello and basses
Vocals - yellow
Doubles - darker yellow
Bvs - various shades of orange and brown
Rooms and reverbs- purple
Perc, samples and sound effecty stuff - pink
Horns - depends sometimes green sometimes yellow

Auxs are the standard protools colour, master same thing. Print track is tape brown 😆

Always start with drums, overs than kick/ snare then rooms. Bass comes next, then through rest of the rhythm  section to any other instrumentation. Then vocals and finally bvs

Auxiliaries all somewhere in the middle usually after bass or keys/ guitar. Then print track and master.

author: cuba1956
content:
Hey guys, I'm mixing an album with vocals ranging from very quiet and intimate to quite engaged and passionate in the same bar. I was wondering if you have good tips for (maybe even specific) compressors / saturators to help me out leveling them up without losing the feel. Maybe get me through some good bit of work before I finish balancing with automation. Anything you've used before with good results? So far I've used a usual suspects — pair of COMP-2A and 1176, I've tried my variable gain compressor (which I don't usually use for vocals) and both worked okay-ish, but I was looking for maybe a good plugin so I can streamline my process a little bit rather than bouncing the vocal tracks through hardware all the time.
Appreciate your input.

author: chrissorem
content: @cuba1956  sometimes in this occasion I’d do an automation pass with the ole fader, and try and get the vocal to sit with just volume rides at first and then I’d go section by section line by line and try to even out the phrases as needed. I know what I like, I know when something is working or not but what I don’t know is what you like.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I’ve had so many red flag moments with clients over the last month that I myself am in a funk. Like I know what I’m delivering is the best sounding thing they’ve ever done and yet the notes keep coming. “What if we do the intro with fewer ghost notes on the solo acoustic guitar?” “I just love the iPhone demo you sent of you playing it though for the first time. Can you play it just like that?” “I want this song to feel like a 90s music video… I think the electric guitar is making it sound too 90s.” 
Then I have another friend who I’ve done a whole records worth of material for come by and sing an absolute garbage scratch vocal and it brings me to tears because she’s just real, and doesn’t sweat things that don’t matter. 
Sometimes it’s a joy, but sometimes a slog. 😑

author: stefandurandt
content: I use an Analog VU meter on the output of my monitor controller built by the inhouse tech who also worked at Neve (he designed and built the 8816 summing box) - he recommended the Sifam ones because their ballistics are really good - which I think is the main argument for analog vs digital. I started using them itb after Leon Zervos who masters at 301 where I work but used to work at Sterling (where he mastered classics like mambo nr 5, the macarena, Avril Lavigne, Maroon 5 etc.) recommended them & spoke about the same “dancing” thing that @spectrummasters spoke about. After that I also got another 2  lessons by 301 mastering engineers (one who’s won like 19 aria - australian grammies & been nominated for like 90) - once where I gave a floortom too much bottom end $ & that really triggered a mastering compressor limiting him in some way & he showed me how the left side jumped on the vu - I didn’t hear it at all in the mixing room but could hear it clearly in the mastering room. The other engineer showed me the same thing this time with a powerful lead vocal. This was kinda back when the loudness wars were still a bit more relevant & when I delivered quiter mixes & left them more space to do their thing & these energy bursts limited the final loudness potential. Then I saw that same Jacquire King thing & together all this made me think of how useful the VU is if you’re working in less than ideal bass monitoring environment - it really shows the bass energy in a pretty unique way. I like listening to references (check the bass VU on for instance Jon Castelli’s Khalid Talk vs Sza Low - one very kick focused & one super sub focussed - both a fuckton of low end vs Serban Blinding Lights try -7 as the reference - BL hovers around 0 & is louder lufs wise & then try Fleetwood Mac Dreams (I think the 2012 remaster) - softer, nice transients, beautiful bass - being driven by Kick,snare & bass) - all of those “dance” with the groove.

author: rse
content:
hi guys, haven't been here in a while. I have a specific question regarding asymmetrical waveforms. I've heard that very often brass instruments like trumpets and also male vocals can produce these sort of waveforms.
I'm working on a male vocal pop ballad and the vocal is quite asymmetrical, i'm concerned this will mess with compression and limiting and the overall loudness I will be able to get. I have "corrected" the asymmetrical waveform using phase rotation in rx. Is it common practice to use phase rotators/all-pass filters to make these waveforms more symmetrical? or do these things do more harm than good? what are your approaches to this? Thanks a lot
videos on the subject: https://youtu.be/dAzjq6vldkc
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nSV5ocyfKLA

author: rse
content:
from my own tests on different material I've noticed that phase rotation actually changes the transients and can introduce something that looks very similar to preringing to me, so I'm very hesitant to use it on something like drums, but i'm not sure if this is a concern on vocals.
I mostly just want to know if this is something that is done in professional mixes (to make sure the vocal has a little bit more room before it hits a compressor threshold) or not

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: To your specific case it’s unlikely that the voice will be the thing hitting the limiter hardest, not impossible but unlikely

author: rse
content: it doesn't hit the limiter hard no, but was concerned about how the compressors on the vocal track itself would react to this kind of waveform, as I've never dealt with these before and I'm not extremely confident in my own listening skills

Anyone good with NI Battery? I've made what could be a very useful patch, but it's not triggering reliably.

author: Edward Rivera
content: It should be a fairly linear approach, and if it's not working in the end, you gotta look down the pipeline and find the worse offenders. A good drum recording should slam without mixing. And if you have a slamming rhythm section going on that's now obfuscated by bringing up the rest of the mix, find out who's the culprit. Or rather than try to make everything slam all the time, figure out what the heartbeat of the song is, and make that slam. If it's the vocal, do that. If it's a keyboard hook, do that

author: Ross Fortune
content:
[Apologies for long message, I’m thinking out loud but also detail is probably useful] Gearing up to mix a live album with a heap of songs (tbc but potentially 23 in one show).

The last time I did something like this, it was low channel count -   a couple of acoustics, one or two vocals, maybe a keyboard per song. I mixed the whole thing in one Pro Tools session, with a separate set of channels for each song which I’d then make inactive and move onto the next song. When printing the continuous mix at the end, I’d make active two songs at a time for any overlap, and constructed the long printed mix like that.

In this case though, there are multimiced drums, bass, electric guitars, keyboards, vocals. The recordings are good (from the stereo board mixes I’ve heard) and the scale is such that I want to have the fidelity I’d approach a studio record with, and the room to shape an identity for each song (while still sounding like they all happened on the same stage on the same night) so I’m thinking to use my usual elaborate drum mix routing with parallels etc, all the bells and whistles.

This complexity would put me off mixing 23 songs in one session, but I’m thinking of the inevitable crunch at the end of the project and the potential frustration of jumping between sessions.

Am I thinking too deeply about this? Should I just get a drum sound and leave it there for 23 tracks, with a few rides here and there?

Not much experience with this stuff so any thoughts would be very welcome please!

author: GaspardMurph
content:
In my experience they are quite used ! Many TV shows in France and Europe require TV tracks or PBOs (play back orchestra) as we call them here. A lot of newer developing artists don’t have budget for MDs that can prep a TV track, and aren’t very good with DAW to make it out of stems. Obviously this is very genre specific to variety / pop / hip hop. Most rock, indie, folk people don’t need these as these TV shows aren’t really part of their promo circuit. 

I have been called many times to deliver a new TV track with a specific timing edit if a specific program has a maximum length of day for example 2:20m.

I usually make the TV track this way:
- instrumental
- background vocals
- lead vocal throws 
- maybe lead vocal in on choruses minus 5/6 dbs

I have been advised by sound folks in TV / Radio not to master TV tracks. Something about loudness requirements, TV broadcast compressors and being able to mix the live vocals more easily with a less compressed and more dynamic TV track.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A producer buddy of mine asked me yesterday how often I listen in mono while mixing. I said “When I find myself using too many stereo imagers to make things fit, sometimes I’ll check to see what kind of fuckery I’m causing. But honestly who listens in mono anymore?”

He reminded me a lot of small Bluetooth speakers are in mono, so I decided this morning to take a fresh look at a tune I’m producing/mixing, starting in mono. 

The leveling choices totally broke down when I switched to stereo, but I think the mix is much better and it happened faster cause I was forced to look at the eq in relation to the center elements, so even when I spread them back out there was more room for the vocal kik snare bass to speak. 

Y’all ever start a mix in mono? Or work with mono as a tool for extended periods?

author: Rollmottle
content: "Apple placed four microphones in its top-of-the-line AirPods Pro wireless earbuds. Two are used in the same way as those in the standard AirPods, for listening to the wearer's voice commands, allowing interaction with Siri, and for answering phone calls. The other two microphones are actually situated in the portion of the earbuds that fit inside the ear. Apple isn't trying to listen in on your internal conversation with this placement. Instead, these microphones hear the sound as it is formed by your ears and picks up on any leak-through from a less than ideal fit. This means the AirPods Pro don't adjust the sound to some theoretical model, but rather tune it specifically for each individual, and even to each ear."
