author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok I’ve got a complicated one. 

In a dynamic song, like piano vocal and slow build to distorto jam in the bridge, what are your go to tools/philosophies for balancing loudness on quiet parts and impact on the loud parts?

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Fader moves. I’ll massage the overall master fader to balance out the dynamics of a track. Simple things like boosting the quiet intro a little then dipping back down before the vocal comes in.  Doing all this at a fixed monitoring level helps.

author: Josh Bowman
content: If it’s a modern/pop/“competitive” (ugh I hate that word but you know what I mean) genre how I deal with this in recent years is to make sure the arrangement is doing the heavy lifting instead of actual volume to get the feeling of dynamics, instead of making the song too dynamic (ie quiet parts too quiet). I always do a quiet listen or a headphone city walk to see if I loose important elements in the quiet bits to make sure I don’t overshoot the dynamics. Also don’t get stuck in a loop of just one section for too long. Also sometimes I start the intro a little louder and slowly let the volume settle to where I actually want it in the verse if I want it to actually be a bit more dynamic… just a subtle bump of the intro guitar/piano etc then let it settle under the vocal can help it appear loud enough in a playlist off the top and still let you have some contrast from verse to chorus. I know I said two conflicting things- depends on the arrangement

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So think of mid vs side in terms of panning left right & center, and think of EQ as volume. 

If you’ve got a lot of low end information on the sides, and say it’s fighting with a mono bass track that’s supposed to be holding down the majority of the low end, you can eq the lows out of those panned tracks, or you can blanket turn all the lows down on the sides with a m/s eq on a buss, so that the L and R info is quieter. It’s basically a group volume ride for frequencies instead of tracks. You can also do this on individual stereo tracks if just panning isn’t granular enough. 

The why & when is mostly about taste. I tend to mix into a proQ3 setting that has the sides hi passed around 100 for the same reason I have a pultec boosting highs & lows on the master- it just ends up doing a lot of work for me.

It can become problematic if I’ve got big toms in a song and, after I’ve got a mix starting to cook I’ll toggle it on & off to see if I’m doing more harm than good. For the kind of music I mostly do, it works more often than not, but the one song I sent to Cian for mixing he basically blasted me for doing that. (In his own kind and gentle way.)

But m/s eq isn’t just for the master buss. You can think about it for any stereo track. Sometimes, I have an acoustic that’s carrying the whole song, but the fundamentals are fighting with the vocal, so I’ll turn the mid down at that frequency (or side chain that to the vocal if it feels anemic when the vocal is out.) that leaves the sides as big as you like cause it’s not fighting with my mono vocal.

author: river
content:
As I like to mix loud, I take inspiration from a method I found called "clip to zero" when it comes to returns/buses/groups (I'll name them buses.)
And also Skrillex and his crazy groups. He showed his screen for a music video a while ago so it's prolly changed but still gave me inspiration.

It'll look something like
Drum bus + drum room bus, grouped together = drum sum bus.
Synth bus  + synth FX bus = synth sum bus
Vocal bus + vocal fx bus = vocal sum.

If it calls for it and I'm feeling spicy, have another group which contains just my bass elements as their own sum group.

Depending on the track, and how important I think any single element is over the other, I might do something like further group/bus together my drums and synths. Leaving me with 2 buses to balance against each other.

author: cian riordan
content:
Guitar:
* Reduce the main guitar volume slightly throughout the song and better blend it: The guitar is just going through a phase – it wants to be heard, but not too much, and it's looking for a blending partner.
* Make the guitar solo sit more on top of the mix: The guitar solo wants to be the star of the show, like a diva in the spotlight. Lights, camera, action!
* Experiment with sound design and cool effects for a more theatrical guitar solo: Why play a guitar solo when you can have a one-man rock opera in the middle of the song?
* A bit too much overdrive, consider reducing: Less overdrive? But the guitar likes to live life on the edge, where "clean" is just a four-letter word.
* Decrease the volume of the single-note guitar walk-down at 2:39 and blend them into the background: Because sometimes, even guitars need to take a step back and chill with the background singers.

author: f.ern___
content:
Here's what I did. 
Made session with a bunch of group channels. Namely these:
Kicks, Snares/Claps, High End Perc, All Drums, All Bass, All Music, LDV and BGV. 

Kicks, snares, percs was routed to the ALL Drums as well. Any transition FX was also routed to All Drums. 

On each of these groups I had an izotope insight 2 channel. 

I then loaded a bunch of stems and routed them to the proper channels. Some came with only a drum bus channel so I could check the kick and snare on their own. 

I set the levels so all mixes peaked at -4dB. 

Here's the songs I looked at:
100 Gecs - Stupid Horse
Ariana Grande - No Tears left to cry
The Weeknd - Blinding Lights
Charli XCX - Forever
Ava Max - Turn Off The Lights
Dua Lipa - New Rules
The 1975 - Give yourself a try

Here's what I found

author: f.ern___
content:
The All Drums group was pretty much consistent over all these tracks hitting peaks at -7dB and and RMS at -15 or 16. Ava max had peaks at -5. 

Most kicks had peaks at -9.5 to -10dB. Ava Maxs which is was more dance heavy peaked at -6. RMS on all stayed within the -14 to -16 range. 

Snares peaks was about 1dB louder than the kick on all tracks and ranged between 8.5 and 11. Rms sat between -22 and -24 on all. Ava Max is exluded cause there was a kick on the snare stem. 

High end percs had peaks around -20 to -25 and rms around -35-40. 

on the All BASS channel the peaks varied a bit more ranging between -8.5 and -12dB. Most sat between 8.5 and 10 though. For rms they were all around 15-16 apart from 1975 again hitting -18. 

The All Music Group all had an RMS of -18 to -20 but the peaks varied -6dB to -11dB

the LDV group (which sometimes also had the BGVs in the stem) varied more than I thought and had peaks between -7 and -14.5. Most sat around -10 to -12. Ava had the lowest ldv, possibly in favor for the stronger drums. On most tracks the RMS sat at -20.

BGV. The bgvs include to many different types of elements to draw any conclusion but they all had overall RMS between -21 and -25.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Seeing a few people tagging me asking for more deets. I’m on holiday with fam now so a little write up will need to suffice. 

Jack’s video covered a good chunk of what I’m doing. Attenuating a few frequency hotspots and clicks is more than half of it. Unlike Jack, I use mouth declick far more than spectral repair or declick. 

There’s other things I’m doing as well but they vary from song to song. I’ll manually smooth out plosives, mic stand bumps, clothing rustles etc. I’ve even gone through and reduced the aliasing in a processed vocal (which takes fucking forever to lasso tool). 

One thing I’ve never seen anyone mention before is fades in RX. It’s a little hard to explain so I’d have to make a video for this, but I do frequency dependent fading. If you think about it, almost all sounds decay with the high end decaying faster than the low end, so when I’m fading noise floor I do the same and the result is more natural and invisible.

author: ehutton21
content: Mildly inspired said discussion: tried rx de-plosive & a combo of spectral repair + a band of spectral shaper to de-ess/control sibilance on a really fickle vocal, loved the result I was able to get. Hadn’t thought to use spectral shaper for non-vowel issues but it didn’t disappoint.

author: ehutton21
content:
Re clip gain, i really agree with a lot of this, esp as someone who went way too far down the clip gain rabbit hole. 

I forgot who said the melodyne “automated clip gain” macro tool was a massive part of their workflow, but I’ve noticed that if I’m going too far beyond that level of adjustment i just get into a messy territory. A good process that I’ve found helpful is clip gain, tune + macro volume adjust with melodyne, clip gain again if it’s still needed.

The multi band thing is intriguing. I admittedly use it on the midrange of the vocals pretty sparingly. I think it’s all case dependent but I definitely love using MB on a dense production.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I love this perspective and I agree with it very much. Of course your experience on the vocal side is very deep. 

RX in my world is incredibly useful in small spot cases because I'm often the last person to touch a record and it can zap things that others have missed due to their zoomed in perspective that almost objectively distract from a record (odd clicks or noises and such that aren't intentional) -- but many of the most interesting things I hear on a day to day basis are the ones that have some unbalanced life to them, something interesting that was left because it WASN'T flat and perfect, I think @cian riordan is one of the masters of this balance

author: peterlabberton
content: First thing is getting all the audio in there, then all those tracks get assigned to a "vALL MIX AUDIO" group so I can trim and control with the VCA below the final mix buss. Then I organize everything by groups/stems by dragging below the associated "x_BUSS" track. Then I assign to the correct buss ("B", for instance). Then—and this is why I start with this layout—I name the "x_PRINT" track as needed ("GTR_LD"). This way I don't have to have pre-named busses that may or may not make any sense for the mix; I can just quickly go through and name based on what's below the print track. THEN I split eveything out so it doesn't look like an insane cluster; the print tracks go in the "STEMS" folder, the buss tracks go in the "BUSSES" folder, and all the audio tracks go in either the "MUSIC" or "VOCALS" folder. I am increasingly rarely using aux sends on a global level, so the "FX" stuff at the bottom is just there to quickly pull in and assign to a buss as needed. Otherwise I'm dup-ing tracks and putting FX there, or just putting FX inline on the track—*gasp!* The first three tracks are just there so I can flip to them quickly on my S1 and listen to the ref, the mix, or the stems (barely used).

author: Zack Hames
content:
This has been a recent revelation for me as well!

For me, gently cutting midrange areas of build up on each instrument, like guitars, drum overheads/cymbals/keys, around 1-2k, leaves a nice little slot for the snare and vocals to sit.

My thought is all of those midrange elements are cumulative. It may sound too smooth in the midrange solo-ed, but when you have 3 elements each with a -2dB cut around 2k, you’re making a sort of “-6dB” hole for the vocal. In other words, you’ve got a giant 6dB mid spike if they all add up

author: Deleted User
content:
This is kind of average of my eq decisions pertaining to high mids/top end

punch 800-2.6k
presence & energy 1.9-4.5k
teeth 5-7k
vocal top end 7-10k
brightness 9-12k
round top 12-15k
sizzle 15-19k

most of these go together with filtering. It doesn’t feel the same without filtering so I would usually touch the filter first

author: Will Melones

author: BoozleBAM
content: I followed up until: 1 - The masking frequencies part. Are you saying that the reverb can have frequencies that mask the original vocal track? If so, I do think I've observed this phenomenon before. And 2: I don't even freaking know what an effects return is. lol. I'm so remedial with all this.

author: chrissorem
content: No worries.  Yes frequency masking or congestion is like two people talking at once at the same volume. Your Brain interrupts this as blurry and confusing. That’s fine if you want it to sound unison. But if the goal is clarity and separation then you need to find a place where one isn’t in the way of the other. I like to think of this as guiding the ear. Example: I’d like to hear the vocal close but I want to feel longer.  In this instance I’d use pre delay in the reverb and darken the reverb  to achieve this.

author: chrissorem
content: An fx return is simple. Think of this. I have an echo chamber. I’m sending the vocal to a speaker in the echo chamber and I’m recording  the echo in the room with a mic. This would be the return. This concept is the same with an fx unit. You send a signal to the fx and the output of the fx is the return

author: BoozleBAM

author: chrissorem
content: I have a console so the vocal is being sent via a aux send. The aux can be eq’d and delayed before it physically hits the plate

author: chrissorem
content: The channel has the input, let’s say in this case it’s a vocal. And let’s say you have 2 auxiliary sends on the channel. The main fader is for your monitoring/mix. And the aux send can be anything you want. The physical out of the send me from the console can plug into a plate reverb or a headphone amp. And you can send a variable amount to either

author: BoozleBAM
content: I'm glad that you mention the 0.5 dB here. See, here's my thing with compression: I do like to absolutely smash my bass with compression because I like the sound of a really pinned down bass, and vocals is a given, but other than those two sources, I really don't compress. What I've found is that once I compress one thing,  I find myself going,  "Oh, this thing needs to be brought up, and then this thing and then this thing..." and then I end up in a "loudness war" with myself. I know tons of people who compress the day lights out of everything, and more power to them. Sometimes I wish I could make it work for me... I also find compression somehow takes away from the impact of things as well, in a way.

Something that’s helped me, especially with dense rock mixes, is recognizing all the frequency ranges add up;

So, how I use this, is I could do 2-4dB cuts around 1-2k in my guitars and overheads and room mics on drums, then suddenly I have a great little hole for vocals. And those elements all add up to enough 2k in the mix.

author: Marty Byrde
content:
I have two mixing questions for anyone that can help me answer…

1. Whenever I high pass my vocals (especially past 100hz) I start to hear some weird phase type of effect… idk what it is but I hate it. But when I don’t high pass my vocals past 100-120 hz, my vocals sounds too boomy, like the low end of my vocals is too overpowering the mix when I play it in my car…. Is there a way I can go around this?

2. Other than delay throws, When people put a constant delay on vocals it seems like they want the delay to be felt not heard….. if this is the case, how does the delay not being heard help the mix….? Or am I just thinking too deep into it?
Thanks in advance

author: Rob Domos
content:
1) I know exactly what you’re talking about. For me, a couple things have helped 

- try shelving the lows rather than use a HPF. I’ll even cascade a couple of shelves sometimes if I have to go crazy, or shelve 150 and HP 50. You can get similar amounts of attenuation and the shape of the phase rotation feels a little less fake.

- how much of this are you doing in solo? Often the phase fuckery bothers me in solo and doesn’t as soon as the 808 is bumping. 

- sometimes I just let the lowend be loose and say “fuck it. My mix, my aesthetic choice”. Seems like not many agree but I like lowend in my vocal.

author: MattKellerYes
content: Not sure if it’s the same thing at all, but once I was finishing up a mix and noticed a whole bunch of a similar super high hiss built up in the vocal tracks once the music had faded out…I hit up the vocal producer to ask about the noise, even sent him a screenshot of it. He told me there was none, even sent me a screenshot of it! After a little back and forth, I figured out that the pro tools session I was working off of from the producer of the track had been at 16 bits the whole time, and the vocal producer had sent over 24 but files…it was the noise pro tools added when the files got quantized down into my 16 bit session. Maybe it might be a similar situation?

author: bobby k
content: i've dealt with this a fair amount, but never thought to mention it here. For better or worse, I often end up with pretty air-tight first passes on the gainstaiging front. So sometimes, when a mix note is as simple as "turn up 808", the rest of the mix changes for obvious reasons. I'm hitting my multiband different, hitting my clipper different, hitting my limiter different; so if I were to simply execute that note, now the vocal, guitar, pretty much everything shifts a good bit in energy and I then spend time making the mix work again now that a big chunk of energy got pushed up in it. (side note - I like to mix a bit more gentle/tight on the low-end side since the lows are so hot in car systems, headphones, entertainment centers, etc. these days. Midrange is my home base.) Curious what your experiences have been with this sort of thing, and/or if you have recommendations.

author: joshbonanno
content: yeah, i typically try and avoid as much processing that will corner in to things like that as possible...even "turn the 808" notes up aside, the chances a producer is going to want to drop me a new file entirely is always there (sadly) and if dropping a new file in means the mix falls apart, thats a bad day for me also...so things like multiband...compression etc...i avoid doing any of that on busses or mixbus at all, and if i do its GENTLE. also, like @hyanrarvey typically it really is as simple as just turning it up and not thinking about it...everything affects everything.. and a louder 808 is going to make the vocal feel quieter, the mix feel a bit more compressed maybe etc...that is simply the nature of the note...sometimes i will even explain that to the artist if they come back and go "why does the vocal sound quiet now?"... "well, we turned up the 808 and the low end etc etc..." educate.

author: EliHeathMusic
content:
I’ve been thinking a lot about how I deal with resonance and unwanted harshness recently and would love to hear about how you all approach this (and maybe more broadly how you think about restraint and taste when using modern plugins). We have so many powerful tools at this point for cleaning up audio (eq, rx, soothe, spectral shaper, de-essing, etc) but when I listen closely to a lot of my favorite recordings from the last 70 years I’ll hear all sorts of weird resonances and abnormalities. 

Over time I’ve been getting better at finding a balance of how far to go with these tools and have also become aware of how easy it can be to go overboard sometimes. Beyond reps and intuition, are there things that have helped you hone in on this? And are you consciously adjusting your “threshold” based on the music or genre you’re working with or do you have a general taste for how you like to hear things regardless of the style and use other tools to get the character and vibe you’re going for.

In other words, do you think about how far you go with these tools as a creative and stylistic decision or more of a functional one?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
A year or so ago I went deep on this. 

First thing is, and you’ll hear this a lot around here, monitoring. Making sure your monitoring is good will allow you to hear where the esses are problematic and when you’ve gone too far, etc. 

Secondly, all my de-essing woes pretty much disappeared when I started using RX. 90% of the time I run DeEss module and slap Waves DeEss (around 7khz) on the end of the chain and it’s golden. May still have to clip fx / clip gain one here or there but it’s largely just handled.

author: Josh Bowman
content:
Oooff feel your pain that’s rough. This happens to me from time to time, not always that extreme tho.

Generally my first move is to listen while bypassing each thing and trying to identify what it’s making better and what gets worse, then if I decide to try and keep some of them I’ll attempt to move some of those plugs off the main mix buss and back onto a subgroup or instrumental buss. But no matter what it ends up with me looping sections and rebuilding the mix to match the rough vibe before I get into the actual creative fun part of the mix.

I have one producer i work with often who mixes into a comp on his all vocal buss and it’s slow and hitting like 3-6 db compression. It totally bones me while mixing so I usually end up rebalancing all the vocals section by section to match his mix before I “start mixing”. 

Sometimes I’ll just work into their buss shit and bypass the stuff/bands of each of plug that are only hurting and not helping. 

Real can of worms tbh. 

Last week I ran into the vocal buss issue- luckily it was a comp w side chain input so I did try out the sidechain, I pre fader sent all the tracks feeding it while copying automation to that send, then used a master fader to match the buss sc level to the original comps gain reduction  and it worked well in that situation and untied my hands while saving me from a whole vocal rebalance session. First time that approach ever actually worked though for me tbh. If its a comp that drums are driving into i find the sc input doesnt end up feeling the same usually.

author: Sam Segarra
content: Hi guys - anxiety-driven question here: when using 2 reverbs on vocals(in this case an "all vocal" bus) would you worry about matching predelay times? Does anyone have an opinion on that, beyond "whatever sounds good"? I have a chamber with no predelay and a plate with 101 ms currently.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I don't see it being a big problem, if one of the verbs is mixed relatively low. If they're both super wet, it will probably feel very obviously "off" *if* one of the pre-delay times are a bad fit.

If the verbs are in series (as opposed to parallel) then I could see pre-delay time being a bigger deal because the PD on the first verb would delay the PD of the second.

I could also see pre-delay time being a factor if the vocal is very staccato. That should be obvious, though.

Otherwise, it's good 'ol "use your ears" and I wouldn't give it too much thought as long as you're getting the effect that you want. If you're not sure, try matching PD times and see how it feels (better/worse?) then move on.

author: earwormfarmer
content:
I’ve also been loving the unfairchild plugin and it’s great on the mixbus imo. Recently have been using it for back-bus compression, a technique I heard Andrew Scheps talk about which is basically a copy of the mixbus minus drums. Mix bus stays uncompressed or less compressed. Back bus gets compressed more aggressively than I would do a mix bus. Blend that under the mix bus to taste. Really good for locking all the instrumentation together around vocals without dynamics getting pulled around by the drums. I think Andrew uses some kind of 1176 but the idea works with all kinds of compressors.

Mix bus and backbus both feed into a 2-bus where more processing may happen. Something like Pultec EQP1q, tape emultion, Pro L2? But I like to change things up!

author: Jack
content:
Going to assume you’re talking more Rumours than Aerosmith.

Drums: dbx 160, transient designer on close mics to thud things up, Fabfilter Saturns ‘dynamics’ knob works quite well to tighten things too, no slammin’ compression on room mics/overheads, sometimes hi-passing overheads into being ‘cymbal mics’ and giving the close mics their space 

Vocals: Dolby trick, not always super aggressively hi-passed, H3000/Microshift backing vocals

Guitars: acoustic 12 string layers, phasers/flangers, mid-forward drives, acoustic guitars often super hi-passed 

Bass: flatwound strings, picked 

Annoying answer: it’s mostly in the arrangement

author: masteredbyjack
content:
You could try spectral repair replace on some of the distortion (it may not work but can). Ive also found that this sort of thing can actually be better repaired in a full mix print than just on the vocal itself, my theory is that spectral replacements has more to grab from and it’s less obvious then

Of course I say all this without hearing it, there are cases I’ve seen where it can’t be saved from what I know

author: masteredbyjack
content:
I’ve found best results (mainly when I have had to do it on a mix but every once in a blue moon someone will send a vocal like this for me to look at before mastering) if you go in and select each bit of distortion, usually they appear as vertical lines and replace them separately and slowly

It can be painstaking but often the results are worth it (though there is of course a trade off it’s not perfect)

author: bobby k
content: Some badass feedback has already been given but something I have to remind myself of every day is to focus mostly on the drum buss and mic levels/polarity. if a frequency is killing you in one mic, it’s probably in most of the others. Try EQing the buss and avoid over processing individual mics. Also, a de-esser might make a better tool than soothe for what you’re dealing with! Last thing, I’d suggest finding the mic with the best tone and building around that. sometimes people mix just the close mics and let the bleed create that glue. If you’re really up to it, you could drop the stems in a Dropbox and DM myself (or anyone else interested) to get a better idea of how “bad” it is and give more direct feedback.

author: JustinLeu
content:
I also love consistency with monitoring levels…

I have a mix start level “loud” which is not actually loud, maybe a touch above conversation level? And then 2 DIM settings that I spend a lot of time at when locking in levels. 

DIM 1 is quiet enough to where I would be frustrated if people were talking.

DIM 2 is just barely audible enough to work on, if anything else is going on in the room I could not work.

I find that these consistent levels allow consistent results…specifically with drum/vocal levels. Quieter listing makes it easier to hear balance issues for me.

author: Sei046
content:
I’m struggling with some vocals that have a sort of “grain” or distortion in the top end.  Something around the 6-7k region but it extends across most of the top end.  I didn’t notice it really when tracking. It’s paired with a very low mid heavy vocal so it’s making adding high end and clarity difficult. I blamed my chain for days but when I opened another vocal done through the exact same chain the following day from another artist it was like butter so it’s obviously inherent to the vocal which makes sense in hindsight.  

Any ideas on how to bring out some more clarity in the top end and not exaggerate that? I’ve tried sooth, had a brief look at declicking in rx, spectre. What’s worked the best so far has been using Accentize spectral balancer to clamp the top end and then clariphonic to bring it back up and that has helped. 

It’s the sort of thing you’d imagine rx to reduce the noisy component in that frequency range would help but your air is essentially a noisy component. 

Anyone ever came across this grain? 

The style of music doesn’t demand crazy top end so I could just embrace the warmth but I’d love a bit more articulation. 

Sorry for the long post

author: BatMeckley
content:
This goes back to “what helps you get the job done quicker?” 

You can 💯 make something ace with stock Ableton plugs. But if a plug-in for 29.99 helps you ace one gig it’s paid for itself hundreds if not thousands of times over. 

I don’t want anyone to go into crushing debt for new toys. And financial stress can really negatively affect some people’s work. Other people it lights a fire under. Personally, if I want to de-ess, which is something I do many many times over in every song I’ve worked on, $30 seems like a steal to just have something that one click works. But everyone values their time differently.

author: cian riordan
content: If its a piano or acoustic song that's very light on the rhythm section (or none at all), I'll definitely take this approach. Making a piano sound as big as you can then trying to shoehorn a vocal in there doesn't make much sense. But for pop/rock stuff, so much of the energy of the song is in the rhythm tracks that in my brain it would be difficult to work backwards. The building a house analogy is tired, but it has always served me well in this regard.

Guys something I’m struggling with lately is getting something to sit behind, lets say a vocal. Let’s say it’s a drum kit, stereo acoustics, bass etc. I’m struggling to maintain a solid and clear kit that doesn’t get in the way of a vocal in something like a country genre for example. 

If I want the snare good and bright and present but not seem like it’s at the same plane of the vocals. Transient control, room ambience, obviously pure level?

author: Sei046
content:
I would definitely say the chain, say fx, pre, mic etc is almost inconsequential against the vocal performance. Every extra minute spent on trying to iron it all out there will save you hours in editing and mixing. I’ve often considered selling a piece of gear and then had a really stellar vocal go through only to realise there was nothing wrong with the gear. I’m sure you’re sick of reading it but the performance is everything. You can’t REALLY EQ air and body into a vocal that isn’t there. You can’t try simulate it alright. And you can’t create actual excitement with compression, just try and trick the brain into thinking there’s excitement. A 57 into any preamp into any interface with a stellar performance will sound amazing. 

After that is just treatment, and it’s essentially pointless discussing chains because it’s so song and vision dependant. 

A boring answer I know but you’ll save a lot of headache and heart ache the sooner you learn it. 

It’s like when you hear a new compressor plugin just explode a drum room and it sounds amazing. Analogue glue, explosive release, so much groove. And then you slap it on the lacklustre room and performance you actually have in front of you and it doesn’t seem to sound so amazing any more.

author: James Cronier

author: spookydrums
content:
Yeah, love soothe, using it to control  the low mid resonances on this thus far. Maybe I could dig in a bit harder for the highs with it. Bloom didn’t work, it made it sound a bit more plastic-y and actually made the grainyness more pronounced. I haven’t gotten good results with bloom on female vocals so far, but I know that one day it will be just the thing needed. I think that probably RX will yield the best results, but for some reason I find myself resisting digging in with RX on this, probably because I know it’s going to be hard work and I’m a little lazy. I don’t have Ozone, but maybe this is what will push me over the edge to try it, hmmm. 

I was thinking that maybe some sort of tape thing could work, but I couldn’t get it to work with Tupe inmediately and the UAD Ampex made it brighter and more distorted. It kind of feels like it’s already on the edge of breaking up too much and becoming unpleasant, a bit like being touched softly on the arm when you have a fever and it’s almost painful. author: Josh Bowman
content: Often if its something i can catagorize into two or three different problems "IE quiet parts too soft, loud harsh parts, boomy parts" etc il just cut the regions into multiple audio tracks feeding a routing folder for the lead vocal and then do my different soothe/eq on the split out tracks to treat each problem before they hit any main lead vocal processing. author: Brian Reynolds
content: I'm generally using different verbs for different elements. The only element I generally put more than one verb on in the DAW is vocals. All melody parts are getting printed with choices or lack there of, from the pedal board on the way in. Even if I'm using the same verb across elemets. I'll make a different send for the drums than I will the guitars. Melody parts I'll usually swim together. Unless own spaces are needed. I'm using whatever EQ or options on the verb plugin to get the tone I'm searching for. Than nearly all sends get a Pro Q EQ after. Usually just doing HP and LP. To remove clutter. Though a Q dip or boost occasionally occurs.

author: Beck Nebel
content: Sunday question: How do you reset your perspective when you’ve been hyperfocused on one element of a mix (like vocals) for too long? What helps you step back and hear the bigger picture again?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
This doesn’t answer your question, but maybe it’ll help prevent this issue in the future:

I don’t think focusing on one element for a long time is ultimately helpful for the process. 

Vocals need a LOT of processing usually, so I find doing one element of that at a time, rather than all of them in one fell swoop, to be helpful. 

I like to start with an autotune, basic eq & comp & some simple ambience to out the vocal inside the song. 

Fix what’s really sticking out and then move on to other elements. 

Go back and get the esses & breaths in order 

Move back to other shit 

Come back and melodyne for real, focus on the areas that have been bugging but also tightening up timing as much as possible. 

The back to other shit. Then back for delay & ambience throws (usually toward the end of the process)

author: Josh Bowman
content: Or just listen/work on it without the vocals for a bit and then bring them back in

Also think it's good to purposely contradict / counterbalance your workflow habits periodically.

e.g. if you're hyper-focused on the vocals, even if for good reason, even if they're the focus of the song and/or need a lot of work, what happens if you intentionally spend the next hour focusing on other elements?

@Nomograph Mastering 

There’s so many layers to this conversation. 

One layer is: *are methods of reframing what you’re hearing inherently a crutch for poor monitoring?*

The 400hz high pass that you monitor through part time on every master would imply not. 

As someone with pretty good monitoring (80% of a Gerhard room and MUM 8s), I personally still find these kind of things very useful within a mixing context. 

I think you’re imagining a whackamole scenario of revolving bandpasses throughout the process and repeatedly throwing off the brain’s fr curve, when in reality it’s a once per mix check at the 85% mark that takes about 5 minutes total to see if anything that’s been overlooked jumps out when adjacent information isn’t distracting from it.

The way this helps me hone in on relationships between elements that I’ve been neglecting is pretty significant. I lean heavily “vocal > everything” when I mix, and nearly every time I do this bandpassing reframe I notice something I’d missed in the interplay between the rest of the elements and the whole project is upgraded as a result. 

I think it’s totally fair to warn against the pitfalls of such maneuvers in the same way that it’s fair to warn against abusing energy drinks, but when it’s just once a week before an intense workout, an energy drink is actually a big win with little to no downside.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Right, one of the frustrating things about it is that it sounds like it is doing more than it shows.

If you hyper focus it in one area and then listen to the delta, that can be the best way to address the annoying resos. And not have it mess with stuff you want in the signal.

If there is just one or two dissonant harmonics on a vocal mic that you never want in the signal, a notch filter is way better.

If it is an overall poorly tracked or annoying vocal, 1 or 2 strategic instances of soothe can really sort it out most of the time.

author: spectrummasters
content:
Q for the gang , I’d be interested on hearing any strategies re : 
How do you handle a mix where the lead vocal is consistently powerful from the first verse, but the band’s dynamics follow a quiet verse/loud chorus structure?

Pulling the vocal down in the verse to match the band makes the chorus feel off, since the singer didn’t actually sing at a different level  in either section I had this situation for the last project I just finished and ended up splitting the (needed ) difference on level for the vocal between sections and adding saturation in the chorus, which worked — but I’d love to hear how others approach this kind of mismatch in vocal vs. band dynamics

author: spectrummasters
content: Thanks Chris , cool ideas . To clarify , sorry if it was unclear , I’ve finished the mixes and everyone’s happy . I went for subtly lower level in the verse and then level up slightly in the choruses with more parallel distressor . It seemed to mitigate . But I was thinking about if I come across it again . With this band I hope to produce for them moving forwards and would hope to be able to subtly encourage the vocalist to come back off the mic a bit and a little less power in appropriate sections ….. but I’m thinking  I’ll get a similar thing again from other bands .

author: Slow Hand
content:
Conceivably any vocoder would be sufficient because the harmonic richness depends on the carrier signal you feed into it, which could easily be any bright synth that you have on hand.

That said, even if you have a darker carrier signal you can usually “tilt” the vocoder bands towards more high end energy and less low end if you want it brighter.

Have you tried Izotope’s *Vocal Synth 2*? It has lots of vocoder-adjacent effects that will do similar things.

author: Slow Hand
content: Last thing I’ll add, vintage hardware vocoders may have far less articulation for the upper detail in voices because of their limited number of bands (16 bands vs. 48, or 100)

author: Gabriel Tyranny

For example, I find myself using a mouse to automate vocals. content:
Actually, it feels like the biggest point of friction in all of making music, not just mixing. I usually have to mentally prepare myself and dedicate a whole day to batch work through automating vocals while reminding myself I enjoy mixing so I don’t give up.

That alone makes me feel like my process should change, but I also love the quality jumps I get after that time so I just dunno. Maybs I gotta suck it up - But hoping there are solutions I’m not thinking of.

author: cian riordan
content: That doesn’t account for the compression used during tracking, nor the bus compression on the vocal bus.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content: I call them router busses but I mean like vocal bus

author: cian riordan
content: This is on the lead vocal track, which is getting fed into a vocal bus that has 1-3dB of compression acting on all of the vocals (leads and bgvs, as well as fx sends)

author: cian riordan
content: Not to mention the myriad other variables — ie, maybe there’s other instruments masking the vocals and that’s why you need so much automation.

author: cian riordan
content: Once you start carving out and sorting out the arrangement, ideally it’s just small rides on the vocals to get things to sound clear

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
On the vocal channel I usually use a series of things that will oftentimes have 2 or 3 stages of compression going lighter than this at probs -3 to -5, again depending.

Do you have any recording chain opinion on one compressor doing this much lifting vs a series of lighter hitting comps?

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I was usually automating it before much compression to then apply compression as mostly a ‘texture’ / ‘seasoning’ to dress the vocal to be mixed in with the track with some light comping - VS using it to control volume.

Maybe I overcompensated cus I used to use it to balance vocals and BOY did I make it sound so pumpy and squashed.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
I’ll explore this further - I greatly appreciate all your input.

Do you generally have a practice for how much vocals get compressed in the preamp when recording though? Again, probably not cus there’s no one size fits all, but figured I’d ask.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Taking notes - The track I sent you was a but experimental in that I ended up using the UAD Studer A800 as a psuedo-compressor on the main vocal channel and again with different settings on the vocal bus - Giving it compression through the tradeoff of frequencies and saturation and whatnot. I ended up loving the texture it gave my vocals but felt I wasn’t tapping into the full capability of the concept I was trying to use in practice.

Slam dance it is - I’m excited to try it honestly, I’m usually so frugal with each plugin but use many layers to create a depth of sound, so legit excites me to see what happens when I’m not holding back.

author: JustinLeu
content:
Also have done quite a few live recordings (mostly ccm) depending on how it is edited/tracked, the drum bleed in to the vocals will be something to figure out. 
A few things I have had a lot of success with:

-Waves “Clarity” run at a light setting can be surprisingly helpful (you can automate the depth too)
-izotope music rebalance can help with this too, but use it super sparingly and on a new playlist. 
-RX can clean up a multitude of sins…both editing issues and annoying random audio issues.

As far as rate, it really just depends. The ccm stuff I have done is always just as much if not more work than studio stuff I get. Charge accordingly, I would do full rate if you can.

author: revolution
content:
anyone want to have a chat about **clip gaining vocals** in a beginner friendly way?

I recently cold DMd some random discord artists who sent me a few things to be able to practice mixing. Im totally new to doing any kind of intentional or thorough mixing. I got back beginner stuff (hip hop) and so far only two track projects,;so I'm primarily focused on vocal clean up, mix, and production. 

I have a vocal that is loud and energetic but I believe was recorded too close to the mic (or too loudly). I cleaned up the take in RX as best I could and did some slight de-clipping on the really bad peaks. I've imported it back to PT, and took some of the basic tips from the podcast notes into consideration. I want to clip gain the vocal and try to even it out without being transformative or destructive of the performance, but still taking enough liberties to improve it and learn something.

author: revolution
content:
I already had the instinct myself to use clip gain a good bit when I record my friend or demos for my friend, so I was excited to get the validation about how useful/important this can be (especially for weaker performers), but thinking of how to holistically do it with the intention of prepping the vocal is causing a bit of overthink perhaps. There's also the question of more granular clip gain for de-essing or plosives, etc., that makes me wonder what would be overdoing it or what is even needed and how to judge that.

Usually any "mixing" or editing I do is related to ideas I create or am part of capturing and have vision/inspiration and get some level of enjoyment out of it. This inspiration usually provides intention or some direction even in my ignorance. In this case I'm completely detached and uninspired essentially, while this makes me more objective, I have a hard time hearing where I want to take the vocal. 

I would appreciate some perspective and insight into the granular thought process one might take with the source material I have, having more experience and know-how. I will push through on my own and seek out feedback that way as well, but some live soundboarding would be nice. I appreciate you regardless if you read this and if you have any input at all. ty!!

If you are interested in listening or discussing it, ping or DM me. We could chat about it in vc and I could stream. Thanks again, I hope good discussion can come of this in a way that is granular or useful for curious beginners.

author: Ingmar Carlson
content:
Yeaaa I’ve been anticipating it more and more. Tough to gauge how much of it is coming from an actual shift in perspective on our role, or if people aren’t listening as clinically until mix time, or if it’s just sheer procrastination/indecision in the final hour. I’d like to say it’s a moot point but it’s really been happening more often enough to get me thinking about it. 

Can’t say I’ve had a lot of success with setting boundaries or renegotiating when this stuff happens, though, so very curious what y’all are doing. I’m more amenable to any of the above when we’re doing full rate, of course, but the irony I find is it’s less likely to happen on those projects – and when it does they’re prob more willing and able to adjust. 

Also there are a variety of shades of this that  feel very different to me. Some version of, “hey, do you do vocal tuning?” is a pretty different ask than, “Yooo can we tune these vocals?” The former obviously starts a proper conversation about it; the latter puts me in a position of feeling like I’m pulling some “hidden fees” from behind my back. Feels icky when our collective goal is to get the record finished, and I usually just end up caving. Which in turn perpetuates the cycle, and so on…

author: Dalliance
content: How often are you left with tuning, timing, and audio clean up tasks when the session is sent over for mix? Do you guys communicate with the client and let them know editing isn't mixing and charge extra? Every other session I get is literally half produced vocals.

author: Dalliance
content: I always fix it obviously because I'm not going to send out something half baked since there's my name under it. I am just curious how other mixing engineers go about it. I don't find it logical to make a mixing engineer, who is paid for a niche skill (mixing multiple sources together so that they create the best possible blend),  time edit layers and layers of backing vocals, so that consonants fall where consonants should be. Literally anyone with little knowledge of editing can do that and it's going to cost a fraction. When it comes to vocal tuning, I thinka vocal producer should do that.

author: Dalliance
content:
Thanks for sharing your input, Josh. 

I work with rappers, so yeah, some of these sessions sound like they were recorded in a restaurant on 3 different mics. And as a bonus there’s printed autotune with wrong settings and artifacts which we all know is super fun to fix. 

I do not mind fixing it because I’m confident I can do it better than anyone around here (location), but the fixing part tends to take more than mixing itself. And that is why I’m asking how you guys include that work in your talks with the clients.

author: Dalliance
content:
I've had clients where I produced the shit out of backvocals. I'm talking delay throws with paralell fx chains triggered by Envelope followers with automation over automation that took a good amount of time to dial in. I completely killed it because the track was empty without it, but the feedback went something like "chill out with the creativity." Which just made me realize that sometimes it does not pay off to go the extra mile with people who do not appreacite your input. 

The "sees the differential" resonates with me, but not only with the market, but also the client. I'm telling you some of these people will tell you what's wrong with the "filter" but won't notice the kick is panned left, so I hardly doubt the artists, mush less listeners, notice the lack of clicks  pops, gain automation, just right amount of sibilace, and just enough tuned vocals. What they do notice is that "it slaps". 

We've just had an indie artist break through the market here. From hundreds of monthly listeners to hundreds of thousands. Dude must've recorded the music on his phone and mixed it himself. I'm purposefully omiting the word "master." And well, the listeners do not care and still consume the melody and the lyrics, so I don't know what would have to happen for people to appreciate sonic quality per se

author: JustinLeu

author: Chase H
content:
I’m in the middle mixing an album for a band that records their vocals on an Aston Spirit mic that I always struggle with esses on when mixing and I’m struggling to get their Esses to where they are happy with them.

It’s a male and female both singing so my gut instinct was to choose just one S to be present most of the time.
On the 2nd revision and left the Esses completely alone after hearing they hated how they sounded the first pass (manually de essed with volume automation) and they dislike the Esses being untouched much more.

Next approach I’m going to try tomorrow is get them to choose an S they like and manually use that to replace the others with.

If that doesn’t work does anyone have another suggestion I should try?

author: DavidEngquist
content:
I suppose there’s quite a difference between the two approaches you’ve described so far (choosing one S to be present vs leaving them completely alone). Maybe they’ll like it more with both being sort of present and equally attenuated? 

I’ve found Sonible smart deess to be pretty powerful in reshaping esses quickly, it can really pull stuff down and also shape the tone in a few different ways.

author: Jonathan Jetter
content: I’ve owned most of the fancy de-essers and ultimately stopped using them.

author: JustinLeu
content:
I agree with @Jonathan Jetter  that the simplest solutions really work 99% of the time. 

My guess is it is simply a level issue. Don’t be afraid to crank away on the waves deesser….you will know when you’ve gone too far, and sometimes will be surprised how much you need to do for it to sound “natural”.

They also may be annoyed with the “flamming” of the esses or consonants, depending on how the vocals are being mixed (duets style vs lead/bgv) 

Which ever vocal is the lead needs to win, if it is split lead I would advise organizing the tracks accordingly and then attenuate the non-lead track esses more…and line them up as needed. 

I am doing exactly the same as @Jonathan Jetter  and pretty much in that order.

Also food for thought, most of these fancy tools did not exist 10 years ago and engineers have made esses sound great/believable since sound recording began. 

I used to obsess over them too and I eventually realized it is almost always a level thing not some mystery treatment. 

Last thought would be on “replacing” esses. That tends to be most useful when the phrase timing does not work, ie. too short for the timing of the phrase. Usually leaving the tonality of the esses makes a performance feel more real and human.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Could always automate the de-esser for specific parts and/or use the clip fx EQ on a high shelf if the top is too bright on specific esses. Massey De-Esser in split band or Lindell 902 are my most musical sounding favourites for this.

author: Chris Lyon
content:
From my experience, if you focus it on low mids rather than harsh unpleasant frequencies while sidechaining, it can make room for the body of vocals or important instruments to cut through.

A lot of the time, those resonances are the defining characteristics of each sound so side chaining even to harsh high-mid info can allow the character of a focus track to cut while limiting the stacking of those possibly harsh frequencies with other tracks. 

Experiment with the sidechain in mid/side unlinked and you can get more aggressive with sidechaining the lead vocal to the instrumental. In a dense pop mix, it can be a lifesaver.

author: bryan cook
content:
Is “All Acapella” a standard stereo print now?

For stereo prints, in addition to main/instro/tv, I’ve always done LV only, BGV only, sometimes multiple bgv passes if there is a very different counter, etc. 

Then gotten even deeper with bgvs in the stems. 

Never any comments for 15+ years.

Recently I was asked by VEVA to deliver an all acapella. Is this something we always send now? I always thought giving Lv and bgv separate would be ideal. They could blend it later. But I guess they want blended too. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: bryan cook
content:
The only thing about having only stems be broken out vocally is it’s hard to mix and match stems and stereo prints since stereo prints start tight to the top of the song and stems start on a musical beat so they can be imported and be on click/grid. 

Are you all having equal spacing at the top of your stereo prints and stems?
